Learn more about paperfolding at MIT: http://mitsha.re/1MUtapV

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/wbGK309yYD4

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/FwBK301GcWa

messages:
Researchers from CSAIL - MIT have developed a soft robotic cube that uses a series of spring-loaded metal tongues to jump, bounce, and roll. In this video, we watch the process of building a cube in just one minute.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/wbGK309yYD4

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Building a soft robotic cube.

Engineers at MIT have fabricated transparent gel robots that can perform a number of fast, forceful tasks for the first time. These robots may have future applications including assisting in surgical operations.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/XEZI308zNIE

Video produced and edited by: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Hydrogel robot footage: Hyunwoo Yuk/MIT Soft Active Materials Lab. Fast and forceful gel robots.

At two times during the year, the setting sun aligns with the Infinite Corridor at MIT. In mid-November and in late January, when this occurs, and atmospheric conditions are right, sunlight streams down the entire 825 feet of the corridor. This celestial phenomenon is known as MIThenge.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. MIThenge.

A glimpse of the morning snowfall.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Snowy campus.

Two MIT chalkers caught in the act with good tidings. ☃

Featured chalk artists: Junior, Aaron Lin and Freshman, Sunny Tian.
Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. MIT Chalkers.

A team of MIT engineers show they can predict a liquid's droplet size distribution, including the likelihood of producing very big and very small droplets, based on one main property: the liquid's viscoelasticity, or stickiness. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/UboJ306YRGd

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
High speed video: Bavand Keshavarz/Gareth H. McKinley/nnf@mit.edu
Music sampled from, "Air Hockey Saloon," by Chris Zabriskie. Predicting the range of droplet sizes for sticky fluids.

MIT engineers have transformed spinach plants into sensors that can detect explosives and wirelessly relay that information to a handheld device similar to a smartphone. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/9Ehb305K63a

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Infrared/fluorescent images: Min Hao Wong. Plant-to-human communication.

Imobilare is a b-boy crew at MIT that provides opportunities for students to learn how to breakdance and improve their b-boying skills. Here, two members show us how they breakdance their way toward the end of the semester.

Learn more about Imobilare: http://imobilare.mit.edu/

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
B-boys: Tomohiro Maeda and Jeffrey Lu, Class of 2018. Study Break.

MIT researchers have come up with a simple, inexpensive system for developing artificial muscles. The key ingredient? Nylon fiber.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/7tXK306sGbC

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Muscles Made of Nylon.

Heat is a powerful force that can affect a material in many ways. For example, almost all solid materials when heated, inevitably expand. It is only in very rare instances certain materials do the opposite and actually shrink when heated. It is this class of "metamaterials" a team of engineers are interested in. 

Learn more: http://news.mit.edu/2016/3-d-printed-structures-shrink-when-heated-1025

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Heat-induced shrinkage.

Inspired by hairy, semiaquatic mammals such as beavers and sea otters, a group of MIT engineers are fabricating fur-like rubbery pelts learn how these mammals stay warm and even dry while diving underwater. 

Learn more: mitsha.re/6e2J304T00N

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Furry Wetsuits.

A group of MIT researchers took a detailed look at 125 U.S. auto models and found those emitting less carbon are the least expensive to drive overall. Their CarbonCounter app allows you to look up emissions rates for your vehicle or one you are considering buying or leasing. (Learn more: http://mitsha.re/oUM1304C6iZ)

Visit their online app: http://carboncounter.com/

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. CarbonCounter: Online app allows consumers to research low-emi...

Red Bull Flugtag is an annual event in which competitors attempt to fly a homemade aircraft off a platform 33 feet in the air. This year, Flugtag came to Boston and the MIT Monkey Ballers entered the competition. 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. MIT Monkey Ballers build a plane for Red Bull Flugtag 2016.

A rugged new hydrogel hybrid from MIT Mechanical Engineering could be used to make artificial skin and longer lasting contact lenses. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/FwBK301GcWa

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. New hydrogel that doesn't dry out.

How to draw the MIT seal in less than 2 minutes: 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT.

#MIT2016 marks 50 years of the cardinal jackets worn at Commencement by 50-year alumni.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. The Red Coats Are Coming.

In the heart of MIT's campus, the MIT Museum Studio and Compton Gallery lets students share their creative visions in the fields of science, technology, architecture, history, and art. 

Watch: http://mitsha.re/Zm9YP 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Engineers in CSAIL - MIT have developed an ingestible origami robot that can deliver drugs and remove accidentally swallowed batteries. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/zeUF300969v

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Robotic surgeon in a pill.

Engineers have developed a material that can protect and tighten skin, smooth wrinkles, and potentially be used to deliver drugs to treat skin conditions. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/4bKe3002OEA

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Engineering a second skin.

Spring is just around the corner... 🌞

Photo: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT undergrads don't take normal classes in January. So what do they do they do instead? LOTS. Enjoy a visual snapshot of Independent Activities Period at MIT.

Learn more about IAP: http://web.mit.edu/iap/

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Independent Activities Period: A Visual Journey.

Top 15 posts of 2015 – No. 7: MIT's origami microbot on the move! Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) A tiny origami robot from CSAIL - MIT climbs, swims, and carries loads twice its weight! Read more: http://mitne.ws/1HwBZro  

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT.

#TBT Wow! A 1957 time capsule meant to be sealed for 1,000 years was unexpectedly unearthed during construction at the MIT.nano site. More from MIT News: http://mitsha.re/UNSpl  

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Time capsule discovered at MIT.

Physics fun: A new model developed by MIT engineers predicts the force required to tie simple knots.

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Untangling the mechanics of knots.

"Our vision is to eliminate waste." MIT spinoff LiquiGlide brings nonstick coating to consumer packaging. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1BTLIqK 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Engineering nonstick coatings to reduce waste.

A tiny origami robot from CSAIL - MIT climbs, swims, and carries loads twice its weight! Read more: http://mitne.ws/1HwBZro  

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. MIT origami microbot.

At the MIT Costume Shop, students transform paper into incredible garments!

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. MIT Costume Shop.

"I think a goal that we should have is to get more people to look through a telescope." 

Observe@MIT allows the MIT community to view the cosmos above campus. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/1F4RZOr

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Gazing at the cosmos with Observe@MIT.

MIT's origami team, OrigaMIT, has been building an enormous three-dimensional fractal out of business cards. Here's a look at their effort to build a level-3 Menger sponge!

Learn more about paperfolding at MIT: http://mitsha.re/1MUtapV

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Building a Menger Sponge 3-D fractal at MIT.

19 snow events and counting in 2015. Thank you to the facilities team keeping MIT running this winter!

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT with photos by Dominick Reuter. In the Snow: Winter 2015 at MIT.

During MIT's Independent Activities Period, students participating in the "Forces Frozen" workshop experimented with structural 
ice shells made from fabric frozen in place. Watch: http://mitsha.re/1yMxHaP

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Forces Frozen: Structures made from frozen fabrics. Through the power of shape and curvature, very thin shells can achieve impressive strength and stiffness, even when they are made only from frozen water-soak...

Top 10 posts of 2014: No. 1 - Robo-cheetah

MIT's robotic cheetah can now run and jump on its own! Full story: http://mitne.ws/1s2M0pT

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT.

Top 10 posts of 2014: No. 6 - Math at MIT

"If we can understand how mathematics relates to the world, then we can make a better world.”

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT.

We love chemistry! Enjoy this inside look at MIT's Club Chem. 

Club Chem website: http://mitsha.re/1waa3nn 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Club Chem at MIT.

What happens when 500 MIT students teach 3,000 high-school students over one weekend at MIT? Welcome to MIT Splash! 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/1u9Veg1 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. SPLASH! at MIT.

messages:
It's the last day of classes! 🎉

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares. gph.is.

Hooray for the signing of the U.S. Constitution in 1787! #ConstitutionDay

Welcome Class of #MIT2020. We see you! 

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT ❤️ Buzz Aldrin ScD '63 to the moon and back! 1969: #Apollo11

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. i.giphy.com.

Hello bicyclists 🚴🏻 , here is a map (pdf) to help you get around MIT on two wheels. http://mitsha.re/lKHk300mWSq  #NationalBiketoWorkDay 

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Moving Day is TODAY! We're commemorating the 100th anniversary of our move from Boston to Cambridge. All are welcome to the festival parade and river crossing competition. 
Details: http://mitsha.re/4nsJuh #MIT02139

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

This and every #EarthDay, we honor the planet that sustains, feeds, and nourishes us. 🌍

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Today we honor Tim the Beaver and his counterparts around the world. #InternationalBeaverDay

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT 

For more about Tim: http://mitsha.re/10p3Gb. i.giphy.com.
Happy #SquareRootDay! 4/4/16 is the fourth of nine Square Root Days this century.  Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Happy #LeapDay from MIT!

Illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Happy Groundhog Day from MIT!  

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. media.giphy.com.

The wait is over. Congrats to early-action students admitted to MIT! #MIT2020

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Happy #MoleDay! October 23rd is the day we celebrate Avogadro's number, 6.02 x 10^23.

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

It's Postdoc Appreciation Week! Postdoctoral researchers like Lin Zhou (pictured, at right, with Institute Professor Millie Dresselhaus) are making huge contributions to MIT and to the world.

Learn about Zhou's recent work developing large, potentially versatile sheets of two-dimensional materials: http://mitsha.re/StyHB

Photo: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Happy first day of spring! Vernal equinox arrives today in the Northern Hemisphere.

Photo illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Top 10 posts of 2014: No. 2 - Space-junk-be-gone

An MIT algorithm tested on the International Space Station could guide robotic retrieval of space junk: http://mitne.ws/1uIyN2z 

Image: NASA and Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Live-action role-playing is a longtime Institute tradition. MIT News reports on the venerable MIT Assassins' Guild, which has been going strong since 1983: http://mitne.ws/1u6tg89  

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

October 23rd is the day we celebrate Avogadro's constant, 6.02 x 10^23. Happy #MoleDay!

Illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Spacesuit of the future from MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics shrink-wraps to astronauts’ bodies. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1udtXK0 

Photo: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT's robotic cheetah can now run and jump on its own. Full story and video: http://mitne.ws/1s2M0pT

An MIT algorithm tested on the International Space Station could guide robotic retrieval of space junk. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1uIyN2z

Neuroscientists at MIT reverse memories’ emotional associations and identify the brain circuit that links feelings to memories. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1opt8cB  

Illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT Mechanical Engineering researchers have discovered new potential for renewable energy where the river meets the sea: http://mitne.ws/1q0ivRJ

Illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

A new theory formulated by MIT Mechanical Engineering researchers predicts magnets may one day act as wireless cooling agents. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1thGWNP

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT researchers find a more efficient way to time traffic lights. 🚥 Full Story: http://mitne.ws/1rHz0EU 

(Photo: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

For the first time, MIT neuroscientists have demonstrated that they can control muscle movement by shining light on spinal cord neurons. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1yRc2x4  

(Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

#WorldCup science: How do soccer balls curve in flight? An MIT mathematician provides new insights. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1qogZef  

(Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Surprising findings in the first study comparing brains of adults with former and current #ADHD: http://mitne.ws/1hM0ZAf

New electrochemical approach has the potential to efficiently turn low-grade heat to electricity. Full story: mitne.ws/Sj3dLz
