A new algorithm enables computers to identify actions much more efficiently. Full story: http://mitne.ws/T2taQ5 

(Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT; video stills from Nesnad/Wikimedia Commons) Timeline Photos.

Genetic material hitchhiking in our cells may shape physical traits more than we thought. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1mivn4r 

(Collage by Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT; yeast image by Masur/Wikimedia Commons; mitochondria image by Nevit/Wikimedia Commons) Timeline Photos.

Researchers have invented a new type of tiny, smartphone-readable particle that could be deployed to help authenticate currency, electronic parts, and luxury goods, and other products. More: http://mitsha.re/1hNDK1s 

(Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.
Just in time for #allergy season: A new study reveals the hidden science of how coughs and sneezes float through air. More: http://mitsha.re/R0nvcu (Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.
New study shows the #Euro leading to uniform prices across countries. More: http://mitsha.re/1mvHMAn (Illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

MIT senior Nathan Kipniss relishes challenges in stem cells and symphonies. More: http://mitne.ws/1hwmb7T (Photo by Allegra Boverman, cell graphic by Nathan Kipniss/Weiss Lab, and photo collage by Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary: Information to follow at http://emergency.mit.edu. More information at: http://emergency.mit.edu. In the event of a campus emergency, news and information will be posted to this site and to the MIT home page. More info at: http://emergency.mit.net/ Due to an ongoing winter storm, MIT will be closed on Monday, Feb. MIT will provide further information at http://emergency.mit.edu/ MIT Emergency Information.
messages:
Due to the expected blizzard, MIT will be closed tomorrow, Tuesday, March 14, for all non-essential personnel, starting at 7 a.m. EDT. For details and updates, visit http://emergency.mit.net/.

While MIT Admissions offices will be closed and no tours or info sessions will be given, Pi Day regular-action admissions decisions will still be revealed March 14 at 6:28 PM EDT via http://decisions.mit.edu. More info: http://mitadmissions.org/

Due to ❄️️❄️️❄️️, MIT will be closed for non-essential personnel starting tonight, Feb. 12, at 11 p.m. through tomorrow, Feb. 13, at 6 p.m. Daytime classes are cancelled but it is expected that classes beginning at or after 6 p.m. tomorrow will be held. More information: http://emergency.mit.edu.
Winter weather advisory: MIT is closed for all non-essential personnel today, Feb. 9, due to snow. More information at: http://emergency.mit.edu.

The MIT community will honor Officer Sean Collier at a memorial dedication and picnic April 29th: http://mitne.ws/1aZPVgC. Join us for a moment of silence today at 2:49 PM ET to honor those affected by the Boston Marathon bombings. #oneMIT #OneBostonDay

Image courtesy of Höweler + Yoon Architecture; Squared Design Lab. Collier Memorial dedication and community picnic to honor fallen MIT officer. MIT community invited to April 27 lecture and April 29 memorial dedication and picnic in honor of Officer Sean Collier.
MIT will remain closed for non-essential personnel on Tuesday, Feb. 10, due to a state of emergency declared by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. More info at: http://emergency.mit.net/
Due to an ongoing winter storm, MIT will be closed on Monday, Feb. 9, except for essential personnel. For updates, visit http://emergency.mit.net.

What will you do with your extra snow day? For those in the area, MIT remains closed until 5 p.m. today. More info: http://emergency.mit.net

MIT snow pyramid photo by dan4th/Flickr. Timeline Photos.

Due to the blizzard, MIT will close at 7pm today and will remain closed Tuesday, except for essential personnel. More information: http://emergency.mit.net/emergency/ MIT Emergency Information. MIT Google People Offices login MIT is committed to the safety and security of every member of the MIT community.

Do you know The Boston Marathon length in smoots? 26.2 miles = 24,794.3 smoots, or about 24.8 kilosmoots from start to finish! 

Wishing everyone participating today a happy and safe run, especially members of the #MITStrong team, who are running in memory of MIT Police Officer Sean Collier. http://mitstrong.mit.edu. Timeline Photos.
One year stronger: The MIT community will pause Friday to honor Officer Sean Collier and celebrate the #MITStrong marathon team. More: http://mitsha.re/1itI76w. Timeline Photos.

“He touched so many lives around campus." 

A year later, MIT keeps police officer Sean Collier’s memory alive. Full story: http://ow.ly/vEsiQ  

(Image courtesy of The Boston Globe) Timeline Photos.
Two weeks and counting: 39 members of the #MITStrong team continue training — and fundraising — for their run at the Boston Marathon. http://mitne.ws/1e0Gm10. Timeline Photos.

#MITStrong is getting ready for the Boston Marathon. The group spoke with NECN this week to explain why they are “running to remember”.  MIT Strong: Group honoring fallen officer in Boston Marathon. School staff members, alumni, undergraduates and an officer are running in memorial of Sean Collier, shot and killed after last year's marathon.

Due to the snowstorm, #MIT will be closed for all nonessential personnel all day on Friday, Jan. 3. More: http://mitsha.re/1cM73mX. MIT Emergency Information. Due to the snowstorm, MIT will be closed for all nonessential personnel all day on Friday, Jan. 3. This closing is effective from 11 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 2; MIT anticipates resuming normal operations at 12 a.m. on Saturday, Jan. 4.
Panoramic view of the memorial ceremony held for MIT Police Officer Sean Collier on April 24, 2013. Photo: Julien de Wit. Remembering MIT Police Officer Sean Collier.
From Wilmington to Cambridge, Mass., thousands have gathered at events to commemorate Officer Collier. Remembering MIT Police Officer Sean Collier.

Photos: Members of the MIT community joined law enforcement officers from the United States and Canada today in paying tribute to MIT Police Officer Sean Collier in MIT's Briggs Field. http://mitne.ws/17iM72u. Timeline Photos.
Watch live now: The memorial for Officer Sean Collier — http://webcast.mit.edu/i/institute/2012-2013/memorial/ Timeline Photos.

Reminder to the general public: Today's memorial service for Officer Sean Collier is only open to the MIT community and law enforcement members. Those without proper ID will be turned away at the gates. The memorial will be webcast starting at 11:50 a.m. and is viewable at http://mit.tv/15EXkfW.

This letter was sent to MIT students and faculty on April 23 regarding the cancellation of classes for Wednesday's memorial in honor of Officer Sean Collier. Classes canceled on Wednesday, April 24 - MIT News Office. Letter from chancellor, provost and faculty chair sent to MIT community.
Join at 2:45: Human chain along Vassar from Collier memorial at Stata to Campus Police HQ for 2:50 statewide silence #MITStrong #BostonStrong.
MIT announces plans to commemorate Officer Sean Collier, including Wednesday event for community, law enforcement: http://mitne.ws/ZHWYxJ.

Community members pay respects at shooting site; makeshift memorial set up to honor fallen Officer Sean Collier. View photos: http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2013/slideshow-remembering-officer-sean-collier.html. Timeline Photos.

The MIT community is beginning the process of healing from the recent tragic events on campus and around the Boston area. At this time, the Institute is working on plans to remember Patrol Officer Sean Collier; details will be announced as they become available. MIT community members who seek resources in dealing with this tragedy should visit http://together.mit.edu/.
‘He loved us, and we loved him’ — MIT community recalls fallen officer Sean Collier, who made a big impression in 15 months at MIT. Read more: http://http://mitne.ws/YA8meV. Timeline Photos.

MIT community members living both on- and off-campus should continue to follow direction from local, state and national authorities in regard to the ongoing police investigations. Pertinent MIT information will continue to be posted at http://emergency.mit.net as needed.

We are saddened to report that the victim in last night's shooting is Patrol Ofc. Sean A. Collier, 26, of Somerville http://mitne.ws/117pudn. MIT officer killed in the line of duty identified as Sean Collier, 26 - MIT News Office. Campus patrol officer, a resident of Somerville, Mass., had worked at MIT since 2012.
Students and community members should remain in their residences and dorms while police activities continue in the Greater Boston area. Continue to check emergency.mit.net for more information.
Statement: MIT Police Officer dies in line of duty http://mitne.ws/15lcg2q.
MIT Police have determined that the suspect in this evening's shooting is no longer on campus. It is now safe to resume normal activities. Please remain vigilant in the coming hours.
Please remain indoors. Police have NOT determined that the campus is safe.
Situation is still volatile. Remain indoors until further information, updates at http://emergency.mit.net.
The shooter remains at large, police continue to search the campus. Please REMAIN INDOORS until further notice.
Police are sweeping the campus in relation to the shooting near Building 32/76 (Stata/Koch), continue to stay indoors until further notice.
Shooting incident continues to be investigated. Stay vigilant, stay indoors and away from Building 32/76 (Stata/Koch) http://emergency.mit.net.
Responding agencies continue to investigate active shooter incident at  building 32 (Stata). Please stay indoors and away from the area.

There is a report of an active shooter in the vicinity of Bldg. 32 (Stata). Please stay clear of the area. Information to follow at http://emergency.mit.edu. MIT Emergency Information. MIT is committed to the safety and security of every member of the MIT community. In the event of a campus emergency, news and information will be posted to this site and to the MIT home page.

MIT is monitoring the situation in Boston carefully. MIT Medical has been alerted. MIT Police urge people to stay away from Boston if possible. MIT will provide further information at http://emergency.mit.edu/ MIT Emergency Information. MIT is committed to the safety and security of every member of the MIT community. In the event of a campus emergency, news and information will be posted to this site and to the MIT home page.

A follow-up to this morning's incident. Police find no evidence of gunman reported on campus - MIT News Office. Authorities expect to investigate Saturday morning tip that prompted an all-campus alert.
Cambridge Police have issued an all clear. MIT returning to normal operations. MIT Police will continue to monitor the campus. Updates at http://emergency.mit.net.

This morning information was received from Cambridge Police that there was a person with a long rifle and body armor in the Main Group Building of MIT.  Multiple law enforcement agencies have responded, please stay clear of the area until the authorities can confirm that it is safe to enter.  More updates to follow on http://emergency.mit.net.

The Institute will be closed tomorrow, Monday, Oct. 29, due to Hurricane Sandy. Full details available at http://emergency.mit.net/ MIT Emergency Information. On Monday, October 29, due to Hurricane Sandy, the MIT campus will be closed for all non-essential personnel for all shifts (first, second and third shifts that begin on Monday). All classes are canceled for Monday.

clusters.summary:
“We’re hoping that some of the information we’ve been able to glean from our study will help us to approach a new understanding of heart development, and also lead to the possibility of using cells that are generated in a dish to replace heart cells that are lost as a consequence of aging and disease,” says Laurie Boyer, an associate professor in the MIT Department of Biology. A new way to see RNA molecules in the brain, from a team at MIT: http://mitsha.re/bV90301Wgas

GIF courtesy of the researchers. More of the best of the week on MIT News: New research into the moon's battered history and an examination of how people approach risk when it comes to their finances. The best of the week at MIT News: Peer back at the light from the first stars, and travel along with an MIT senior who's helping to make an impact around the world. Promising development in the field of genetics: Researchers at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard and the McGovern Institute for Brain Research today unveiled their discovery of a new gene editing system, CRISPR-Cpf1.
messages: The researchers’ converter is a step-down converter, meaning that its output voltage is lower than its input voltage. In particular, it takes input voltages ranging from 1.2 to 3.3 volts and reduces them to between 0.7 and 0.9 volts. Researchers devise efficient power converter for internet of things. Design reduces converter’s resting power consumption by 50 percent.

What if we could develop robots that were a more natural extension of us and that could actually do whatever we are thinking? Brain-controlled robots. CSAIL system enables people to correct robot mistakes using brain signals.

A study led by MIT and others has found that the rigging of Volkswagen vehicles to pass emissions tests will lead to 1,200 premature deaths in Europe due to resulting air pollution. Study: Volkswagen’s excess emissions will lead to 1,200 premature deaths in Europe. Countries hit hardest by automaker’s emissions scandal include Germany, Poland, France, and Czech Republic.

By encoding the strategies of high-performing human planners in a machine-readable form, researchers from CSAIL - MIT were able to improve the performance of competition-winning planning algorithms by 10 to 15 percent on a challenging set of problems. Researchers add a splash of human intuition to planning algorithms. Incorporating strategies from skilled human planners improves automatic planners’ performance.

MIT computer scientist Regina Barzilay believes doctors, biologists, and patients could improve cancer treatments with the help of machine learning. Putting data in the hands of doctors. Computer scientist Regina Barzilay empowers cancer treatment with machine learning.

Engineers in MIT IMES have found that a dietary supplement could be useful in treating obstructive sleep apnea in certain patients. A possible new approach to stopping obstructive sleep apnea. Dietary supplement derived from tree bark shows promise for treating the disorder.

MIT startup Sistine Solar creates custom solar panels designed to mimic home facades and other environments, with aims of enticing more homeowners to install photovoltaic systems. Solar panels get a face-lift with custom designs. Startup aims for wider U.S. solar adoption with photovoltaic panels that can display any image.

Astronomy news: Scientists from MIT and elsewhere have discovered seven Earth-sized planets around the nearby dwarf star TRAPPIST-1. Might life exist on one or more? 3Q: Julien de Wit on the discovery of seven temperate, nearby worlds. Planets may harbor conditions suitable for sustaining liquid water — and thus life.

Many scientists are pursuing ways to treat disease by delivering DNA or RNA that can turn a gene on or off. However, a major obstacle to progress in this field has been finding ways to safely deliver that genetic material to the correct cells. Nanoparticle screen could speed up drug development. New test helps identify particles for gene delivery or RNA interference.

Quantum entanglement, which Einstein once skeptically viewed as “spooky action at a distance,” is, in fact, real. Stars align in test supporting “spooky action at a distance”. Physicists address loophole in tests of Bell’s inequality, using 600-year-old starlight.

Want to find an exoplanet of your own? Now you can, using a public dataset of 1,600 nearby stars. Scientists make huge dataset of nearby stars available to public. Users can search database of 1,600 stars to find signs of new exoplanets.

MIT scientists have uncovered how long the solar nebula — gas and dust that would be come the solar system — lasted. Scientists estimate solar nebula’s lifetime. Study finds the swirling gas disk disappeared within the solar system’s first 4 million years.

A new center for #autism research at MIT's McGovern Institute for Brain Research will investigate the genetic, biological, and neural bases of autism spectrum disorder. New Center for Autism Research established at MIT’s McGovern Institute. A $20 million gift from Lisa Yang and Hock Tan ’75 SM ’75 will catalyze multidisciplinary autism research.

MIT researchers have designed a voltaic cell sustained by stomach acids. The system can generate enough power to run small sensors or drug-delivery devices that can reside in the GI tract for extended periods. Engineers harness stomach acid to power tiny sensors. Ingestible electronic devices could monitor physiological conditions or deliver drugs.

MIT researchers have now developed a theoretical model to predict the spectrum of light absorbed by aggregates of these pigments, based on their structure. How photosynthetic pigments harvest light. New model could help scientists design materials for artificial photosynthesis.

MIT's new Election Data and Science Lab aims to improve how the U.S. election system works. MIT Election Data and Science Lab launches. Founded by political scientist Charles Stewart III, the Election Lab focuses on non-partisan research, data, and analysis to improve elections.

Scientists in the MIT Department of Chemistry have discovered a new path to making drugs more effective. Catalyst adds fluorine-containing groups to make new compounds. Introducing such groups to potential drugs could make them more effective.

Researchers at CSAIL - MIT have developed a new computational model of a neural circuit in the brain. Model sheds light on purpose of inhibitory neurons. Study suggests computational role for neurons that prevent other neurons from firing.

Todd Mostak, a former researcher at CSAIL - MIT, is using graphic processing units (GPUs) to develop an analytic database and visualization platform called MapD, which is the fastest of its kind in the world, according to Mostak. Split-second data mapping. New type of database-analytics platform queries and maps billions of data points in milliseconds.

Neuroscientists at MIT have adapted an MRI scanner to make it easier to scan infants’ brains as the babies watch movies featuring different types of visual input. A glimpse into the workings of the baby brain. MRI scans reveal surprising similarities in activity patterns of infant and adult visual cortex.

“Step by step, we are making encouraging progress across the Institute,” says Don Holmes, director of maintenance and utilities in MIT’s Department of Facilities. Campus greenhouse gas emissions down 7 percent since 2014. MIT releases results of its second campus-wide inventory.

When it comes to perceiving music, the human brain is much more tuned in to certain types of rhythms than others, according to a new study from MIT. How the brain perceives rhythm. Study finds the brain is biased toward rhythms based on simple integer ratios.

Love #SciArt? Get to know Interstellate: http://mitsha.re/27eu307RU7v. Interstellate: Celebrating the the beauty of neuroscience. Caitlin Vander Weele, a graduate student in brain and cognitive sciences, launches a collaborative neuro-art pictorial magazine.

MIT researchers present a way to make atom interferometry with Bose-Einstein condensates even more precise, by eliminating a source of error endemic to earlier designs. Hyperprecise measurement with Bose-Einstein condensates. New atom interferometer could measure inertial forces with record-setting accuracy.

MIT scientists have found that extreme precipitation events in California and elsewhere should become more frequent as the Earth’s climate warms. Study finds more extreme storms ahead for California. New technique predicts frequency of heavy precipitation with global warming.

“I like the willingness of people to collaborate and be excited about new ideas.” —Elizabeth Nolan, associate professor, MIT Department of Chemistry. Exploring the tug-of-war over metals during infection. Chemist Elizabeth Nolan studies the battle between microbes and hosts for essential metals.

The researchers’ new coreset technique takes data sets with large numbers of variables and find approximations of them with far fewer variables. Making big data manageable. Technique shrinks data sets while preserving their fundamental mathematical relationships.

“Forests of carbon nanotubes can transfer ink onto a surface like massive numbers of tiny pen quills.” Printable electronics. New stamping technique creates functional features at nanoscale dimensions.

A distinctive neural signature discovered by MIT neuroscientists may explain why individuals with dyslexia have difficulty learning to read. Distinctive brain pattern may underlie dyslexia. Study suggests reduced plasticity could account for reading difficulties.

A new approach to microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), developed by a team of researchers at MIT, could offer a new way of making movable parts with no solid connections between the pieces, potentially eliminating a major source of wear and failure. 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Footage: Daniel Preston/Device Research Lab at MIT. Movable microplatform floating on droplets.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 1 - Gravitational waves detected

Using the LIGO observatory, a team led by MIT and Caltech researchers made the first direct detection of gravitational waves, confirming Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR. gph.is.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 6 - Happy Birthday, Einstein!

This year we honored the birth of Albert Einstein with the discovery of gravitational waves. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR 

Image via GIPHY. gph.is.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 9 - "We did it again!"

For the second time, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration detected gravitational waves from colliding black holes, further solidifying Albert Einstein's theory of relativity. For second time, LIGO detects gravitational waves. Signal was produced by two black holes colliding 1.4 billion light years away.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 10 - Cancer-fighting bacteria

MIT engineers programmed E. coli bacteria to destroy cancer cells. Cancer-fighting bacteria. Engineers program E. coli to destroy tumor cells.

A new MIT study estimates that, since 2008, access to mobile-money services  increased daily per capita consumption levels of roughly 2 percent of Kenyan households, lifting them out of extreme poverty. Study: Mobile-money services lift Kenyans out of poverty. Greater access to services raises daily spending, especially among female-headed households.

Researchers at MIT and Brigham and Women's Hospital have developed a new drug capsule that remains in the stomach for up to two weeks after being swallowed, gradually releasing its drug payload. This type of drug delivery could potentially assist in eliminating diseases such as malaria.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/5ONH306gIBy

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT
Animation: Diana Saville/Giovanni Traverso. Ultra-long-term drug delivery.

For this week's ‪#‎HourofCode‬, teach kids to build their own mobile app with our App Inventor: Welcome, Inventors! | Explore MIT App Inventor. Welcome, Inventors! App Inventor is a free, cloud-based service that you access using a web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari). With these beginner-friendly tutorials, you will learn the basics of programming apps for Android devices. You will need:      • A Mac or Windows computer (see system requir...

Celebrating science: For his work on gene editing, Feng Zhang of MIT and the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard is a co-runner-up for TIME's Person of the Year! Feng Zhang named a runner-up for TIME’s 2016 Person of the Year. MIT and Broad Institute scientist shares recognition with four other scientists for developing CRISPR gene-editing systems.

New hope for Alzheimer's patients? MIT researchers have developed a promising treatment using light stimulation. #MITBetterWorld

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/LUU9306UnMC

Video: Picower Institute for Learning and Memory
Animation: Sputnik Animation
Additional footage and music: Pond5. Light-based therapy for Alzheimer's disease.

MIT researchers working on the LIGO gravitational wave experiment were among the scientists awarded a Breakthrough Prize last night. Congrats to all! 

More from MIT News: http://mitsha.re/omSb306PA4P. $25 Million in Breakthrough Prizes Given in Science and Math. The awards went to more than a thousand physicists, life scientists and mathematicians in areas like genetics and string theory.

Despite many years of study, some of graphene’s fundamental properties are still not well-understood, including the way it behaves when something slides along its surface, until now: The science of friction on graphene. Sliding on flexible graphene surfaces has been uncharted territory until now.

MIT researchers have discovered astonishing behavior of water confined in carbon nanotubes. Inside tiny tubes, water turns solid when it should be boiling. MIT researchers discover astonishing behavior of water confined in carbon nanotubes.

Time to science! The LIGO gravitational wave experiment is back online, ready to make new discoveries about the universe. LIGO back online, ready for more discoveries. Upgrades make detectors more sensitive to gravitational waves.

MIT spinout Common Sensing aims to solve the nation’s diabetes-management issues by going digital. Data-driven diabetes management. Smart insulin-pen cap lets patients and doctors track dosage data to better manage treatment.

Researchers at MIT and Brigham and Women's Hospital have developed a new drug capsule that remains in the stomach for up to two weeks after being swallowed, gradually releasing its drug payload. New capsule achieves long-term drug delivery. Technology could aid in elimination of malaria and treatment of many other diseases.

“I realized that #physics was the most beautiful thing I’d ever studied.” —Libby Tolman, MIT Department of Physics. Fusing theory and practice. Grad student Libby Tolman melds the elegance of theoretical physics with practical applications of nuclear science.

New findings suggest a route toward using the world’s existing infrastructure for fuel storage and distribution, without adding net greenhouse emissions to the atmosphere. Turning greenhouse gas into gasoline. New catalyst provides design principles for producing fuels from carbon dioxide emissions.

Researchers from CSAIL - MIT have recently unveiled a prototype system called “MoVR” that allows gamers to use any VR headset wirelessly. Enabling wireless virtual reality. Developed at Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, “MoVR” system allows VR headsets to communicate without a cord.
MIT researchers have now demonstrated that genetic circuits can be isolated within individual synthetic “cells,” preventing them from disrupting each other. mitsha.re.

Scientists have found evidence that Pluto may harbor a liquid ocean just below its surface. Pluto’s icy, slushy heart. Data from New Horizons mission suggest a water-ice ocean lies beneath Pluto’s heart-shaped basin.

“I’m hoping that this structure will help people ... do something better for our planet.” —Catherine Drennan, MIT chemist and biologist. A step toward biodegradable plastics. Chemists discover structure of bacterial enzyme that generates useful polymers.

Researchers from CSAIL - MIT have presented a new way to train neural networks so that they provide not only predictions and classifications but rationales for their decisions. Making computers explain themselves. New training technique would reveal the basis for machine-learning systems’ decisions.

Researchers at MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital have moved a step closer to a treatment to rapidly awaken patients after administration of a general anesthetic. Study suggests approach to waking patients after surgery. Activating certain brain neurons may spur recovery from general anesthesia.

Researchers from MIT, Boston Children's Hospital, and Massachusetts General Hospital have joined forces in an ambitious new project to use magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to evaluate the health of fetuses. MRIs for fetal health. Algorithm could help analyze fetal scans to determine whether interventions are warranted.

“The goal of all this is to present the interesting stuff to the data scientists so that they can more quickly address all these new data sets that are coming in,” says Max Kanter MEng ’15. Automating big-data analysis. With new algorithms, data scientists could accomplish in days what has traditionally taken months.

Now MIT researchers have developed an imaging technique that, for the first time, enables three-dimensional mapping of serotonin as it’s reabsorbed into neurons, across multiple regions of the living brain. Mapping serotonin dynamics in the living brain. Imaging technique that creates 3-D video of serotonin transport could aid antidepressant development.

Behold "SCIENTIA," a new work by acclaimed sculptor Ursula von Rydingsvard, now gracing MIT's McGovern Institute for Brain Research! Monumental new sculpture commissioned for MIT's McGovern Institute. "SCIENTIA" is the newest addition to MIT's Public Art Collection.

Researchers at MIT and elsewhere have developed a new way of driving fluid droplets across surfaces in a precisely controlled way. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/3hqF305iFeT. gph.is.

What happens after celestial objects smack into bodies like the moon? A major study using satellite data reveals the fascinating details for the first time. Retracing the origins of a massive, multi-ring crater. Scientists reconstruct first hours after a giant impact created one of the largest craters on the moon.

A new study from MIT finds that positive and negative emotions are controlled by two populations of neurons that are genetically programmed to encode memories of either fearful or pleasurable events. A delicate balance between positive and negative emotion. Neuroscientists identify two neuron populations that encode happy or fearful memories.

Promising news in the search for a cancer cure: MIT researchers have harnessed the immune system to destroy tumors. Fighting cancer with the power of immunity. New treatment elicits two-pronged immune response that destroys tumors in mice.

MIT physicists are proposing a new experiment to detect a dark matter particle called the axion. 

If successful, the effort could crack one of the most perplexing unsolved mysteries in particle physics, as well as finally yield a glimpse of dark matter. Team simulates a magnetar to seek dark matter particle. Detecting “axion” particles may solve longstanding problem in particle physics.

MIT engineers say cellphones, laptops, and other electronic devices may face a higher risk of overheating, as a result of interactions between electrons and heat-carrying particles called phonons. Electron-phonon interactions affect heat dissipation in computer chips. Study shows particle collisions may explain overheated circuits, improve thermoelectric devices.

“I don't think you can hack the election.” —MIT political scientist Charles Stewart III. How healthy is the U.S. voting system? Professor Charles Stewart III explains why the U.S. electoral system is strong and how MIT research is making the voting process even more seamless.  .

“One thing you realize working in this lab is that we are really far away from the robot apocalypse.” —Sarah Hensley, MIT Class of 2017. Prepping a robot for its journey to Mars. Senior Sarah Hensley aims to improve Earth's most advanced humanoid robot, in advance of its trip to the Red Planet.

MIT scientists have discovered brains cells that make us hungry. Could anti-obesity drugs be next? A new player in appetite control. Brain cells that provide structural support also influence feeding behavior, study shows.

“It’s like Photoshop for 3-D materials, allowing you to design objects made of new composite materials that have the optimal mechanical, thermal, and conductive properties that you need for a given task,” says PhD student Kiril Vidimče. Designing for 3-D printing. “Foundry” tool from the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab lets you design a wide range of multi-material 3-D-printed objects.

Supercharger of the future: Introducing the first non-carbon supercapacitor, from scientists and engineers at MIT! #MITBetterWorld. New kind of supercapacitor made without carbon. Energy storage device could deliver more power than current versions of this technology.

Researchers at MIT and elsewhere have developed a technique to monitor Parkinson’s disease progression as patients interact with a computer keyboard. Monitoring Parkinson’s symptoms at home. Keyboard-monitoring technique can detect motor difficulties as patients type.

Kiosks from MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) and MIT DUSP may soon provide basic services after natural disasters like Hurricane Matthew. Art and science merge in a disaster readiness haven. Innovative off-grid PREPHubs structures house basic services needed in the aftermath of a disaster.

Researchers at MIT and other institutions have created tiny freeze-dried pellets that include all of the molecular machinery needed to translate DNA into proteins, which could form the basis for on-demand production of drugs and vaccines. To produce biopharmaceuticals on demand, just add water. Freeze-dried cellular components can be rehydrated to churn out useful proteins.

MIT scientists have now identified a way to improve the therapy for people suffering from phobias and more complicated conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Pinpointing a brain circuit that can keep fears at bay. Study suggests path to prolonging treatment effectiveness for phobias or post-traumatic stress disorder.
Discover a new planet this #AstronomyDay! 🌑  🔭   MIT+k12 Videos explains how: http://mitsha.re/4l1N304QYEa. i.giphy.com.

MIT researchers have designed nanosensors that can profile tumors and may yield insight into how they will respond to certain therapies. Nanosensors could help determine tumors’ ability to remodel tissue. Measuring enzyme levels could help doctors select appropriate treatments.

For children with speech and language disorders, early-childhood intervention can make a great difference in their later academic and social success. But many such children go undiagnosed until kindergarten or even later.

Researchers at CSAIL - MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital’s Institute of Health Professions hope to change that. Automated screening for childhood communication disorders. Computer system could help identify subtle speech, language disorders in time for early intervention.
A new shock-absorbing material from CSAIL - MIT could protect robots, drones, cellphones, and more. Full story: http://mitsha.re/rqhH304NR1A. i.giphy.com.

MIT chemists have now shown that they can package three or more drugs into a novel type of nanoparticle, allowing them to design custom combination therapies for cancer. High-capacity nanoparticle. Particles that carry three or more drugs hold potential for targeted cancer therapy.

New MIT discovery: These are the cells that remember who your friends are. Scientists identify neurons devoted to social memory. Cells in the hippocampus store memories of acquaintances, a new study reports.

A new study and "Carbon Counter" app from the MIT Institute for Data, Systems, and Society finds low-emissions vehicles cost less overall. How does yours stack up? Study: Low-emissions vehicles are less expensive overall. Detailed look at 125 U.S. auto models finds those emitting less carbon are the least expensive to drive.

The human digestive tract contains trillions of bacteria, many of which help digest food and fight off harmful bacteria.

Recent studies have shown that some of these bacteria may influence, for better or worse, human diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. Delivering beneficial bacteria to the GI tract. Method that transports microbes through the stomach to the intestine may benefit human health.

A new programming language called Milk lets application developers manage memory more efficiently in programs that deal with scattered data points in large data sets. Faster parallel computing. New programming language delivers fourfold speedups on problems common in the age of big data.

How are you feeling? A new device from Prof. Dina Katabi and two MIT grad students uses wireless signals to read your emotions. Detecting emotions with wireless signals. Measuring your heartbeat and breath, CSAIL device can tell if you’re excited, happy, angry, or sad.

MIT researchers and their colleagues are designing an imaging system that can read closed books. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/MDCe3043KEk. i.giphy.com.

For the first time, scientists have observed solitary behavior by individual atoms. For first time, researchers see individual atoms keep away from each other or bunch up as pairs. Observations of atomic interactions could help pave way to room-temperature superconductors.

Forbes has a conversation with CSAIL - MIT Director Daniela Rus. Q+A With The First Female Director Of MIT's Largest Research Lab. MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory is the largest on-campus laboratory as measured by research scope and membership. More than 250 companies have been hatched through CSAIL, including Akamai, iRobot, 3Com, and Meraki. CSAIL's research activities are divided into seven area...

“Our understanding of our environment is largely shaped by our memory for what’s currently out of sight,” says Caroline Robertson, a postdoc at McGovern Institute for Brain Research and a junior fellow of the Harvard Society of Fellows. How the brain builds panoramic memory. Neuroscientists identify brain regions key to linking different views of our surroundings.

Inspired by historical work showing that structure plays a role in the function of other classes of RNA such as transfer RNA, MIT biologists have now deciphered the structure of one type of lncRNA and used that information to figure out how it interacts with a cellular protein to control the development of heart muscle cells. Linking RNA structure and function. Biologists have discovered how an enigmatic type of RNA helps to control cell fate.

A new technique invented at MIT can precisely measure the growth of many individual cells simultaneously. Microchip enables fast, precise measurement of single-cell growth. Device that measures growth of many individual cells simultaneously could lead to rapid tests for antibiotics and other drugs.

Solar, or photovoltaic (PV), cells, which convert sunlight into electrical energy, have a large role to play in boosting solar power generation globally, but researchers still face limitations to scaling up this technology.

A team of researchers from MIT and the Masdar Institute of Science and Technology may have found a way around this seemingly intractable tradeoff between efficiency and cost. New solar cell is more efficient, costs less than its counterparts. Exposed in step-like formation, layers of new photovoltaic cell harvest more of sun’s energy.

Using light to print three-dimensional structures that “remember” their original shapes. 3-D printed structures “remember” their shapes. Heat-responsive materials may aid in controlled drug delivery and solar panel tracking.

MIT researchers have now added an extra layer of control over when and where the genome-editing system known as CRISPR occurs, by making the system responsive to light. Using light to control genome editing. New technique offers precise manipulation of when and where genes are targeted.

MIT researchers were trying to develop a new battery, but it didn’t work out that way. Instead, thanks to an unexpected finding in their lab tests, what they discovered was a whole new way of producing the metal antimony — and potentially a new way of smelting other metals, as well. New method developed for producing some metals. Using electricity rather than heat can reduce both energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions.

"I kept asking myself," says Gang Chen, the Carl Richard Soderberg Professor in Power Engineering, "Can we basically boil water on a rooftop, in normal conditions, without optically concentrating the sunlight?" Sponge creates steam using ambient sunlight. Bubble-wrapped structure requires no mirrors or lenses to focus the sun’s heat.

There are few things more frustrating than trying to use your phone on a crowded network. But researchers from CSAIL - MIT say that they have a possible solution. Solving network congestion. MegaMIMO system from the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab speeds data transfer by coordinating multiple routers at the same time.

How might we live on the newly discovered extrasolar planet Proxima b? Suggestions from MIT Professor Sara Seager: You wouldn’t be a happy camper if you relocated to Proxima Centauri’s planet. The universe has bajillions of planets, but for us, we're on the best one by far.

What happens when carbon dioxide flows through deep saltwater reservoirs? Study reveals new physics of how fluids flow in porous media. Key flow mechanisms, crucial to carbon sequestration and fuel-cell operation, have been visualized.
What would your cells tell you? Recording analog memories in human cells. Engineers program human cells to store complex histories in their DNA.

An MIT spinout is preparing to commercialize a novel rechargeable lithium metal battery that offers double the energy capacity of the lithium ion batteries that power many of today’s consumer electronics. Doubling battery power of consumer electronics. New lithium metal batteries could make smartphones, drones, and electric cars last twice as long.

A device from the MIT Department of Chemistry aims to improve ear infection diagnosis — and eliminate one of the leading causes of antibiotic resistance. A new eye on the middle ear. Shortwave infrared instrument from MIT could see deeper, help improve diagnosis of ear infections.

Will we find life on Mars? If so, this MIT technique could help. New technique may help detect Martian life. A novel interpretation of Raman spectra will help the 2020 Mars rover select rocks to study for signs of life.

A new study from the MIT Institute for Data, Systems, and Society finds switching vehicles to all-electric could yield a major reduction in U.S. transportation emissions. Can today’s EVs make a dent in climate change? Electric vehicles can meet drivers’ needs enough to replace 90 percent of vehicles now on the road.

A collaboration between MIT and Brazilian researchers has identified a promising drug target for three serious diseases. Targeting neglected diseases. New enzyme-mapping advance could help drug development.

Although epidurals are generally regarded as safe, there are complications in up to 10 percent of cases, in which the needles are inserted too far or placed in the wrong tissue.

A team of researchers from MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital hopes to improve those numbers with a new sensor that can be embedded into an epidural needle. Needles that hit the right mark. New sensor could help anesthesiologists place needles for epidurals and other medical procedures.

New material from the MIT Department of Chemistry could lead to energy-saving self-shading windows. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/8N5V303bjnr. i.giphy.com.

If you want to model the effects of wing flexion on the crack’s propagation, or vice versa, you need to switch back and forth between these two levels of description, which is difficult. 

A team of researchers have developed a new programming language that handles that switching automatically. User-friendly language for programming efficient simulations. New language can speed up computer simulations 200-fold or reduce the code they require by 90 percent.

A new study out of MIT and Brandeis University suggests musical preferences are cultural in origin and not hardwired in the brain. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/G24M302dDA9

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Are musical tastes cultural or hardwired in the brain?

Researchers from CSAIL - MIT and Indiana University at Bloomington describe a new system that permits database queries for genome-wide association studies but reduces the chances of privacy compromises to almost zero. Protecting privacy in genomic databases. System helps ensure databases used in medical research will not leak patients’ personal information.

“We’re trying to be that rational voice, saying, ‘Yes, there are risks in sports, but we can help you better understand that risk and intelligently mitigate it.’”. When to get your head out of the game. Wearable sensor for athletes detects potential head injuries, gathers data on hard hits.

A new study from MIT reveals that a brain region dedicated to reading has connections for that skill even before children learn to read. Study finds brain connections key to reading. Pathways that exist before kids learn to read may determine development of brain’s word recognition area.

Researchers from MIT and MIT Lincoln Laboratory report an important step toward practical quantum computers. Toward practical quantum computers. Built-in optics could enable chips that use trapped ions as quantum bits.

Unless you’ve been following the subject closely, you may not have heard of one of the biggest barriers slowing the revival of global economic growth over the last decade. The safety trap. Lack of secure investments is hindering growth globally, research finds.

The newest Airbus and Boeing passenger jets flying today are made primarily from advanced composite materials, but composite materials are surprisingly vulnerable. 

MIT aerospace engineers have found a way to bond composite layers in such a way that the resulting material is substantially stronger and more resistant to damage than other advanced composites. Carbon nanotube “stitches” strengthen composites. Method to reinforce these materials could help make airplane frames lighter, more damage-resistant.
An exhaustive search for so-called “sterile” neutrinos has come up empty. Neutrino search finds no evidence of “hidden” particle. If discovered, sterile neutrinos may explain dark matter.

“My lab’s goal is to really provide molecular insight” about membrane proteins, says Mei Hong, professor in the MIT Department of Chemistry. Analyzing dynamic proteins. Chemistry professor Mei Hong studies the structures of proteins embedded in cell membranes.

Researchers from CSAIL - MIT have recently developed an imaging technique called Interactive Dynamic Video (IDV) that lets you reach in and “touch” objects in videos. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/dfFW302QMaK. media.giphy.com.

Now a portable production system, designed to manufacture a range of biopharmaceuticals on demand, has been developed by researchers at MIT. Portable device produces biopharmaceuticals on demand. System would use microbes for manufacturing small amounts of vaccines and other therapies.

After thousands of hours of work, MIT researchers have released the first major database of fully annotated English sentences written by non-native speakers. First major database of non-native English. Resource could yield linguistic insights, practical applications for non-native English speakers.

A new app from researchers at MIT could allow homes, businesses, and institutions to monitor energy use of individual appliances and devices. What’s wasting power at home? Ask your app! New system from MIT can identify how much power is being used by each device in a household.

In a study of mice, an MIT team found that two of the genes that control cells’ circadian rhythms also function as tumor suppressors. Why working the night shift can pose a cancer risk. New study reveals a link between circadian clock disruption and tumor growth.

MIT researchers have developed a new technique for imaging brain tissue at multiple scales. Imaging the brain at multiple size scales. New technique can reveal subcellular details and long-range connections.

#BlackWomenDidThat: MIT Prof. Paula Hammond has engineered a new nanoparticle to treat drug-resistant cancer. A new superweapon in the fight against cancer. Cancer is a very clever, adaptable disease. To defeat it, says medical researcher and educator Paula Hammond, we need a new and powerful mode of attack. With her colleagues at MIT, Hammond engineered a nanoparticle one-hundredth the size of a human hair that can treat the most aggressive, drug-resis...

A new variation of the battery chemistry, which could be used in a conventional, fully sealed battery, promises similar theoretical performance as lithium-air batteries, while overcoming many of the drawbacks. New lithium-oxygen battery greatly improves energy efficiency, longevity. New chemistry could overcome key drawbacks of lithium-air batteries.

Every 3-D experience starts with those clunky glasses, but that could soon change. New movie screen allows for glasses-free 3-D at a larger scale. Prototype display enables viewers to watch a 3-D movie from any seat in a theater.

CSAIL - MIT researchers demonstrate a robot that, by learning from human workers, can help assign and schedule tasks in fields ranging from medicine to the military. Robot helps nurses schedule tasks on labor floor. System from Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab suggests where to move patients and who should do C-sections.

Biologists have long suspected that ants base their population-density estimates on the frequency with which they — literally — bump into other ants while randomly exploring their environments. Exploring networks efficiently. Analysis of ant colony behavior could yield better algorithms for network communication.

Don't trip: An MIT study finds vibrating boots could help astronauts — and the visually impaired — avoid obstacles. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/LGhK302vGqV 

GIF: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. i.giphy.com.
MIT engineers have programmed E. coli bacteria to destroy cancer cells. Cancer-fighting bacteria. Engineers program E. coli to destroy tumor cells.

Weird science from the MIT Department of Physics. MIT scientists find weird quantum effects, even over hundreds of miles. Neutrinos traveling 450 miles have no individual identities, according to MIT analysis.

Researchers at the MIT Laboratory for Computational Physiology have taken an alternative approach to clinical research by freely releasing ICU data to researchers globally, with a goal of crowdsourcing the knowledge generation process. Supporting clinical research with an intensive-care database. Crowdsourcing clinical data from some 40,000 patients could vastly improve research and critical-care decisions.

“This study suggests that preferences for consonance over dissonance depend on exposure to Western musical culture, and that the preference is not innate,” says Josh McDermott of the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences at MIT. Why we like the music we do. New study suggests that musical tastes are cultural in origin, not hardwired in the brain.

New software from researchers at CSAIL - MIT could make databases much easier for laypeople to work with. Democratizing databases. With a new tool, any competent spreadsheet user can construct custom database interfaces.

MIT biologists have discovered a possible explanation for how lithium works to treat patients with bipolar disorder. New clue to how lithium works in the brain. Biologists find a possible explanation for why the drug helps bipolar patients.
Researchers at CSAIL - MIT devise secure, efficient anonymity network: How to stay anonymous online. Network can protect users’ anonymity if all but one of its servers are compromised.

An MIT-led study finds small satellite clusters could be the future of Earth-sensing. How it works: http://mitsha.re/2lWQ302ao1d

GIF: Sreeja Nag/NASA. i.giphy.com.

Researchers at MIT’s research center in Singapore have developed a new microfluidic device that tests the effects of electric fields on cancer cells. New microfluidic device offers means for studying electric field cancer therapy. Low-intensity fields keep malignant cells from spreading, while preserving healthy cells.

Your smartphone and other wireless devices could soon detect trace amounts of toxic gases. Wireless, wearable toxic-gas detector. Inexpensive sensors could be worn by soldiers to detect hazardous chemical agents.
The portable Nima Sensor, first developed at MIT, helps maintain a gluten-free diet. Is your meal really gluten free? Portable sensor detects trace amounts of gluten in food at restaurants.

Researchers at MIT are making fluorescent polymer gels that change color when they’re shaken, heated, exposed to acid, or otherwise disrupted. The promise of fluorescent polymer gels. Color-changing materials could be used to detect structural failure in energy-related equipment.

Scientists at MIT and elsewhere have identified the “first fingerprints of healing” of the Antarctic ozone layer, published in the journal Science. Scientists observe first signs of healing in the Antarctic ozone layer. September ozone hole has shrunk by 4 million square kilometers since 2000.

A new way to see RNA molecules in the brain, from a team at MIT: http://mitsha.re/bV90301Wgas

GIF courtesy of the researchers. i.giphy.com.
MIT study finds China has an opportunity to massively increase its use of wind power. Winds of change? Study: China could go big on wind power — if it adjusts its grid operations.

Researchers at MIT and elsewhere have found a new way of using mid-infrared lasers to turn regions of molecules in the open air into glowing filaments of electrically charged gas, or plasma. New mid-infrared laser system could detect atmospheric chemicals. Laser pulses produce glowing plasma filaments in open air, could enable long-distance monitoring.

How can a vehicle navigate to stay within its lane when bad weather obscures road markings? Researchers from MIT Lincoln Laboratory have an answer. Pinpointing vehicles with high precision under adverse weather conditions. MIT Lincoln Laboratory radar system achieves centimeter-level localization; could help driverless cars stay in lane when road markings are obscured.

Researchers at CSAIL - MIT and Dartmouth College presented a new compiler for analog computers. Analog computing returns. New analog compiler could help enable simulation of whole organs and even organisms.

How can we ensure critical advances in biomedicine? A new report co-chaired by three from MIT calls for a merging of insights from engineering, physics, computer science, chemistry, mathematics, and the life sciences. A strategy for “convergence” research to transform biomedicine. Report calls for more integration of physical, life sciences for revolutionary advances in biomedical research.

Engineering from nature: MIT researchers have found nanofibers from silk can be combined to create an excellent filtration system. Silk-based filtration material breaks barriers. Engineers find nanosized building blocks of silk hold the secrets to improved filtration membranes.

Backed by decades of MIT research, spinoff Passport Systems Inc.
offers improved detection for nuclear and other threats at borders and seaports. Improved threat-detection. Scanners more rapidly and accurately identify radioactive materials at U.S. borders, events.

A new study from the MIT Institute for Data, Systems, and Society
finds energy storage systems can make solar and wind farms more profitable. Energy storage for renewables can be a good investment today, study finds. Systems that bank energy can add value to solar and wind projects.

Blinded with science: Researchers in the MIT Department of Physics have discovered a new way of generating light, using graphene. Researchers discover new way to turn electricity into light, using graphene. By slowing down light to a speed slower than flowing electrons, researchers create a kind of optical “sonic boom.”

Robots that sound so real, they fool humans. Artificial intelligence produces realistic sounds that fool humans. Video-trained system from MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab could help robots understand how objects interact with the world.

New software from CSAIL - MIT can turn any smartphone into an eye-tracking device. Here's how it works: http://mitsha.re/ViKp301kmvM

GIF: Christine Daniloff/MIT. i.giphy.com.

Researchers at MIT have developed a practical and physically-based way of treating the surface of materials called perovskite oxides, to make them more durable and improve their performance. Researchers find a way to extend life and improve performance of fuel cell electrodes. Surface treatment greatly reduces degradation of catalyst material.

“We did it again!” For the second time, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration has detected gravitational waves from colliding black holes, further solidifying Albert Einstein's theory of relativity. Full story: http://mitsha.re/7qYU301i1L1

This animation represents the merger of two black holes and the gravitational waves that ripple outward during the event. The black holes — representing those detected by LIGO on Dec. 26, 2015 — were 14 and eight times the mass of the sun until they merged into a single black hole 21 times the sun's mass. One solar mass was converted to gravitational waves. In reality, the area near the black holes would appear highly warped, and the gravitational waves would be difficult to see directly.

Video: LIGO/T. Pyle. LIGO again detects gravitational waves.

Mixtures of liquids and solids could lead to holographic displays, new optical devices. Mixing solids and liquids enhances optical properties of both. New approach can dramatically change the extent to which optical devices scatter light.

An MIT-led team has developed new models for how cells condense and separate their chromosomes before dividing. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/TQ5r301cYvl 

GIF courtesy of the researchers. media.giphy.com.

"The study of literature is about the experience of being human, and that's inseparable from the practice of medicine," Cara Lai '16. Powered by literature on her way toward an MD. Senior Cara Lai cites MIT Literature studies as key to her preparation for medical practice.

Cool news! MIT scientists have found the first direct evidence that black holes feed on clouds of cold gas. Scientists observe supermassive black hole feeding on cold gas. Findings suggest two dining styles for black holes.

Who wants to see a black hole? A new advance from MIT, Harvard, and the MITHaystack Observatory may finally make it so. A method to image black holes. New algorithm could stitch together astronomical measurements made across the globe.

New from the MIT Department of Chemistry: Compounds found in fungi could be used to treat cancer. A new approach to chemical synthesis. Communesins, originally found in fungus, could hold potential as cancer drugs.

MIT researchers report a new theoretical characterization of topological semimetals’ electrical properties that accurately describes all known topological semimetals and predicts several new ones. Physicists predict previously unseen phenomena in exotic materials. Better understanding of topological semimetals could help usher in future electronics.

During Matt Damon's commencement address he mentioned a simulation theory. Explore it further: http://mitsha.re/Y7qe3010r7w 
 
Image via GIPHY. i.giphy.com.

MIT's Feng Zhang and colleagues have created a new CRISPR system that edits RNA rather than DNA. Scientists Find Form of Crispr Gene Editing With New Capabilities. A common bacterium contains molecules that target RNA, not DNA. If it can be harnessed for use in humans, the process may lead to new forms of bioengineering.

Congrats to MIT's Rai Weiss, 2016 winner of The Kavli Prize in Astrophysics! Weiss shares the award and $1 million with Kip Thorne and Ronald Drever of Caltech for the detection of gravitational waves using the LIGO experiment. 

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/wyK8300R0X0

Images via the Kavli Prize. Timeline Photos.

MIT researchers let gravity do the work in new a rechargeable battery system. New concept turns battery technology upside-down. Pump-free design for flow battery could offer advantages in cost and simplicity.

You know it, you love it. Now, researchers studying “Super Mario Bros.” have found it to be an exceedingly complex game. 

Read more: http://mitsha.re/NtaV300NOqJ 

GIF by Christine Daniloff/MIT. i.giphy.com.

A team of MIT researchers has for the first time broken through a theoretically predicted ceiling on how much sunlight they can convert into electricity. Hot new solar cell. System converts solar heat into usable light, increasing device’s overall efficiency.

System from the RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT could cut explosives detection time from minutes to microseconds. Speedy terahertz-based system could detect explosives. Spectroscopic system with chip-scale lasers cuts detection time from minutes to microseconds.

Researchers at MIT have found a way to get the same amount of catalytic activity with as little as one-tenth the amount of precious metal. New nanoparticle catalysts could reduce need for precious metals. Process from MIT provides improved reactivity with much less platinum.

A new study is opening the way for new classes of alloys with previously unseen combinations of properties. New metal alloys overcome strength-ductility tradeoff. Promising new approach overturns widespead metallurgical assumption.

A collaborative project between researchers at MIT and the Masdar Institute of Science and Technology, aims to reduce Abu Dhabi’s heat island effect. New model from Masdar Institute-MIT collaboration to support a cooler, more sustainable Abu Dhabi. Tool will help urban planners reduce Abu Dhabi’s heat island and carbon footprint.

“Just as you can learn from successes, you can always learn from failures.” —Donald Little, senior in electrical engineering and computer science. Helping others in daily doses. Senior Donald Little uses computer science to improve people’s everyday lives.

Superbugs working together? A new MIT study finds bacteria resistant to different antibiotics can protect each other. Teamwork enables bacterial survival. Strains of E. coli resistant to one antibiotic can protect other bacteria growing nearby.

44 percent of all energy used in buildings in the United States goes toward heating and cooling, and this accounts for 20 percent of the nation’s carbon dioxide emissions. How to make cities more energy efficient. Retrofitting a small portion of buildings would have big impact on cities’ carbon emissions.

"Creating the Lincoln Laboratory Supercomputing Center has been a goal for the team for many years, and it is tremendously rewarding to see it come to fruition," said Jeremy Kepner,  laboratory fellow, and head of the MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) Supercomputing Center (LLSC). Lincoln Laboratory establishes a supercomputing center. New facility will enable interactive, high-performance computing for data analysis.

Four new majors and seven new minors, many that cross disciplines and schools, have been created. New undergraduate majors and minors to debut in fall 2016. Driven by student demand and the blending of fields, new opportunities include management tracks and minors in computer science, data science, and innovation.

How are certain diseases passed on through genes? A new MIT study sheds light on this important question. New approach to genetic analysis yields markers linked to complex diseases. Study identifies new gene variants that may be targets for treating arrhythmia.
A new CSAIL - MIT algorithm controlling teams of flying robots factors in moving obstacles. Robotic consensus. Control algorithm for teams of robots factors in moving obstacles.

Human love, visualized: Mother and baby in MRI as featured in Smithsonian Magazine. #MothersDay

Image: Rebecca Saxe and Atsushi Takahashi / Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, MIT / Athinoula A. Martinos Imaging Center at the McGovern Institute for Brain Research, MIT. Why I Captured This MRI of a Mother and Child. A venerable symbol of human love, as you've never seen it before.

MIT researchers have engineered a paper test that can diagnose Zika virus infection in just a few hours. A new paper-based test for the Zika virus. Inexpensive device can diagnose Zika in just a few hours.
A new MIT study finds dust mites don’t just cause allergies — they can also harm DNA. Asthma linked to DNA damage. Allergies induced by dust mites can harm DNA in lung cells.

Congratulations to scientists and engineers of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration who have won a special $3 million Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics for their work in detecting gravitational waves! LIGO researchers awarded Special Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics. Team that detected gravitational waves to share $3 million prize.

A fascinating new technique from the MIT Department of Physics spots active motion in cells. 

Watch: http://mitsha.re/4ncRwj. media.giphy.com.
A modular protein system from MIT lets scientists control RNA activity: Controlling RNA in living cells. Modular, programmable proteins can be used to track or manipulate gene expression.
Researchers from MIT and Brigham and Women's Hospital have designed an extended-release pill which could be used to reduce the dosage frequency of some drugs: http://mitsha.re/10pkku. i.giphy.com.

MIT engineers have opened “a window to industry” with the development of tiny graphene-based nanoscrolls that could be used for water filtration and more. For stronger, lighter, cheaper materials, scroll up. Researchers create perfect nanoscrolls from graphene’s imperfect form.

Researchers from MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital have developed a device that delivers chemotherapy directly to pancreatic tumors — a promising new approach to one of the deadliest cancers. 

Image: Bryce Vickmark. Implantable device targets pancreatic cancer. Chemotherapy delivered directly to tumors may slow the disease.

Meet MIT physicist Nuh Gedik, who peers into the high-speed activities of subatomic particles that inhabit exotic materials and physical states. Nuh Gedik: Peering into the heart of matter. MIT physicist uses laser beams to study exotic electronic phenomena at high speeds.

A new study co-authored by two MIT grad students has shown, in groundbreaking detail, that poor people live shorter lives than more affluent people in the U.S.

Graphic: Chetty et al./JAMA. New study shows rich, poor have huge mortality gap in U.S. In unprecedented detail, lifespan gap shown to be large and growing rapidly.

MIT neuroscientist Kay Tye's secret passion: breakdancing! She learned her moves as an MIT undergraduate. Watch: http://mitsha.re/10p2Mp  

Gif via Bboy Network Channel. i.giphy.com.

For National Robotics Week, a new system from CSAIL - MIT automatically 3-D prints dynamic robots in a single step, with no assembly required, using a commercially-available 3-D printer. http://mitsha.re/10mjj0. i.giphy.com.

What is fool's gold, anyway? MIT engineers probed the surface of pyrite like never before, revealing the science of this "foolish" element. #AprilFoolsDay. Probing the surface of pyrite. Common mineral gets first detailed examination of its surface electronic properties, thanks to team of MIT researchers.

Could the Flint water crisis happen in New England? MIT experts weigh in on water safety in the Northeast. #WorldWaterDay. Can Flint happen here? - The Boston Globe. The water crisis in Michigan is another wake up call that we need to invest in our infrastructure.

A new study from the MIT Senseable City Lab  suggests communicating cars could remove the need for traffic lights. http://mitsha.re/ZFbGz 

Image via GIPHY. media.giphy.com.

Important new work from the Picower Institute for Learning and Memory  raises hopes for treating Alzheimer’s-related memory loss. “Lost” memories can be found. Neuroscientists retrieve missing memories in mice with early Alzheimer’s symptoms.

How do whales dine? New research from MIT Mechanical Engineering finds these sea mammals feed in species-specific hotspots. Whales dine with their own kind. Mapping whale calls, researchers find the predators feed in species-specific hotspots.

Happy birthday, Albert Einstein! We got you a special gift this year: The first direct detection of gravitational waves 〰️〰️〰️ http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR

Image via GIPHY. media.giphy.com.

An impressive new system from CSAIL - MIT speeds Web page loading by 34 percent. System loads Web pages 34 percent faster by fetching files more effectively. "Polaris" system from MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab accelerates website load-time by decreasing network trips.

Super-small solar: Researchers in the MIT EECS Department have demonstrated the thinnest solar cells ever made — light enough to float on a bubble! Solar cells as light as a soap bubble. Ultrathin, flexible photovoltaic cells from MIT research could find many new uses.

More reason to watch what you eat: A new study links high-fat diet to an increased risk of cancer. How diet influences colon cancer. Study ties high-fat diet to changes in intestinal stem cells, may help explain increased cancer risk.

Clapperton Mavhunga, associate professor in the MIT | Program in Science, Technology, and Society, is working to shine light on Africa’s abundant technologies. http://mitsha.re/YYWUk. Timeline Photos.
