LIGO Detects Gravitational Waves. After a decades-long quest, The MIT-Caltech collaboration LIGO Laboratories has detected gravitational waves, opening a new era in our exploration of the uni...
Front page of The New York Times: LIGO found gravitational waves! Full report from Dennis Overbye '66: http://mitsha.re/Ygdqi. Timeline Photos.

“I would love to see Einstein’s face if he could read this article that we just put out! It’s a wonderful proof that all of this incredible stuff is in his equations.” –Prof. Emeritus Rainer Weiss http://mitsha.re/Yb4YY 

More on today's announcement of LIGO's discovery of gravitational waves: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR #EinsteinWasRight

Video: MIT News/MIT Video Productions. LIGO discovery: Einstein would be proud.

Did you know? The LIGO gravitational wave detector was conceived by Prof. Emeritus Rainer Weiss at MIT nearly 40 years ago as a way to prove Einstein’s theory of relativity. Q&A: Rainer Weiss on LIGO’s origins. MIT physicist developed the concept for LIGO as a teaching exercise.

How did scientists detect #gravitationalwaves from colliding black holes? Explainer from MIT News: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR 

Image: SXS. giphy.com.

Groundbreaking physics: Using the LIGO observatory, a team led by MIT and Caltech scientists has made the first direct detection of gravitational waves, proving correct Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity. Full story: http://mitsha.re/Yb0yR 

Image: LIGO/R. Hurt. giphy.com.

A new discovery about cement’s structure may lead to more durable, sustainable concrete — the world's most widely used construction material. Riddle of cement’s structure is finally solved. Findings may guide development of formulas to make the material more durable, less CO2-intensive.

“Everyone here has worked to become really clever at something. It's awesome to be a part of a collaborative community with people like that.” Computer science and engineering major helps people while having fun. Senior Sami Alsheikh helps others, solves problems, and has fun doing both.

How do low-income Indian women use technology? A new study from MIT's Comprehensive Initiative on Technology Evaluation aims to find out. Study to find tech choices of women with low income - Times of India. If you’ve ever had to buy a new phone or appliance, you’ve probably relied on one of those helpful consumer guides that review rival products. But can that approach be used for development, where tech is often prescribed as a problem-solver?

Solar power is an enabling force. See how the MIT Tata Center for Technology and Design is helping to bring solar microgrids to rural India: http://mitsha.re/XnFND 

Microgrid image via MIT Energy Initiative #MITIndia. Timeline Photos.
Honoring #MLKDay2016 — A sampler of MIT research on justice, equity, civil and human rights: http://mitsha.re/XatSH. Timeline Photos.

An Emmy for CSAIL - MIT! The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), the global Web-standards organization housed at CSAIL, received a Technology and Engineering Emmy Award Friday for its work making video content more accessible. http://mitsha.re/WUJiN

Photo courtesy of Karen Myers/W3C. Pictured (l-r): Yosuke Funahashi, Thierry Michel, Philippe Le Hegaret and Karen Myers. Timeline Photos.

MIT engineers have discovered a way to harness the energy of tiny bending motions. Harnessing the energy of small bending motions. New device could provide electrical power source from walking and other ambient motions.
A new MIT technique can trace a “family tree” of cells as they divide and specialize. Watch: http://mitsha.re/WHrsu. giphy.com.

This weekend in The New York Times, a look at how the MIT Tata Center for Technology and Design is helping to bring solar technology to rural villages in India. Electrifying India, With the Sun and Small Loans. A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.

Top 15 posts of 2015 – No. 4: Nearby Earth-sized exoplanet found. New exoplanet in our neighborhood. Though likely uninhabitable, planet is rocky, Earth-sized, and near enough for study of its atmosphere.
Top 15 posts of 2015 – No. 6: Weyl points, a major physics breakthrough. Long-sought phenomenon finally detected. Weyl points, first predicted in 1929, observed for the first time.

A new discovery from MIT and Harvard University scientists may lead to treatments to improve some symptoms of autism. Study finds altered brain chemistry in people with autism. Neuroscientists link autism to reduced activity of key neurotransmitter in human brain.

Just in time for Ludwig van #Beethoven’s 245th birthday, new research from the McGovern Institute for Brain Research finds neurons highly selective for music: http://mitsha.re/VZ5Db

Painting by Joseph Karl Stieler. Timeline Photos.

This week, MIT scientists announced an improvement to the CRISPR-Cas9 DNA editing system while advising caution in advancing gene-editing applications. MIT, Broad scientists overcome key CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing hurdle. Team re-engineers system to dramatically cut down on editing errors; improvements advance future human applications.

“There’s no way we can solve anything if we’re not actually speaking to each other.” –Alyssa Napier. Senior Alyssa Napier dedicates herself to improving MIT. Chemistry major works to address social justice issues.

Scientists at MIT are developing new strategies for an HIV vaccine. #WorldAIDSDay. Evaluating strategies for HIV vaccination. Study yields insight into generating antibodies that target different strains of HIV.

Happy #FibonacciDay! Today, 11/23, we celebrate the numbers of the Fibonacci sequence. MIT Department of Physics Prof. Leonid Levitov explores how they appear in nature: http://mitsha.re/UYO5D

Photo: Maia Weinstock. Timeline Photos.

Scientists at MIT have helped to discover the closest Earth-sized exoplanet yet. New exoplanet in our neighborhood. Though likely uninhabitable, planet is rocky, Earth-sized, and near enough for study of its atmosphere.

Congrats to Associate Professor Ed Boyden and all MIT researchers honored at this year's Breakthrough Prize awards! Edward Boyden wins 2016 Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences. MIT physicists share prize in fundamental physics; Larry Guth and Liang Fu win New Horizons Prizes.

Have ideas for sustainable fabrics and textiles? Enter the new Materials Matter contest from the MIT Climate CoLab and Nike. MIT Climate CoLab, in collaboration with Nike, launches new materials competition. Materials Matter competition, inspired by MIT research, seeks innovations that could help transform the way we view, make, and use materials.

A novel device from CSAIL - MIT lets you “see” through walls. Learn how it works: http://mitsha.re/U12Ld. How wireless “X-ray vision” could power virtual reality, smart homes, and Hollywood. By seeing silhouettes through a wall, CSAIL device could help with motion capture, fall prevention and even your heating bill.

A new MIT study quantifies the real human health consequences to Volkswagen's emissions cheat, the addition of software instructing its vehicles to perform more efficiently during tests. Study: Volkswagen’s emissions cheat to cause 60 premature deaths in U.S. Timely vehicle recall by German automaker would avoid some 130 early deaths, researchers say.

How can technology improve response efforts after a natural disaster? The MIT Lincoln Laboratory is developing tools to assist agencies in the wake of events such as today's powerful earthquake in Asia. Technology confronts disasters. Research and development at MIT Lincoln Laboratory will help agencies better respond to disasters and humanitarian crises.

Can physics be taught like soccer? In an effort to help students master physics, MIT researchers are developing new teaching techniques that break down physics concepts into specific skills. http://mitsha.re/TAjnV #STEMeducation. Can Physics Be Taught Like Soccer? Physicist puts Swedish psychologist Anders Ericsson's 'deliberative practice' to an online test.

MIT spinout EyeNetra's mobile eye-tester may lead to vision-corrected virtual realty displays. http://mitsha.re/TzZoS. Smarter lenses. Newly launched mobile eye-test device could lead to prescription virtual-reality screens.

Meet senior Kristen Finney, who works w/ GlobeMed at MIT to improve care for HIV patients in Togo. Senior Kristen Finney and GlobeMed lend a helping hand. MIT students partner with a clinic in Togo to improve health care for HIV/AIDS patients.

New study from the MIT School of Engineering: Fueling up on the moon is the best route to #Mars. To save on weight, a detour to the moon is the best route to Mars. For a piloted mission to Mars, fueling up on the moon could streamline cargo by 68 percent.

Promising development in the field of genetics: Researchers at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard and the McGovern Institute for Brain Research today unveiled their discovery of a new gene editing system, CRISPR-Cpf1. New system for human genome editing has potential to increase power and precision of DNA engineering. CRISPR-Cpf1 offers simpler approach to editing DNA; technology could disrupt scientific and commercial landscape.

New from RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT: engineered viruses that can kill dangerous bacteria, including those for which there are no effective antibiotics. Viruses join fight against harmful bacteria. Engineered viruses could combat human disease and improve food safety.

A fascinating new system from CSAIL - MIT and Boston Children's Hospital converts MRI scans into 3-D-printed heart models in a matter of hours. Personalized heart models for surgical planning. System can convert MRI scans into 3D-printed, physical models in a few hours.

Happy #ProgrammerDay! Celebrate by learning about the first new cache-coherence mechanism in 30 years — developed at MIT and cleverly nicknamed 'Tardis' for its time-saving powers. First new cache-coherence mechanism in 30 years. More efficient memory-management scheme could help enable chips with thousands of cores.

Thanks to researchers at MIT, new open-source data make it possible for anyone with a smartphone to navigate Nairobi, Kenya, using the city's network of matatus, or privately owned minivans. Digital Matatus project makes the invisible visible. Novel research project produces the first map of an informal transportation system in Nairobi.

A fascinating new study from the Saxe Lab suggests young children's brains can be remodeled to take on new functions. Young brains can take on new functions. Visual cortex of blind children can be remodeled to process language.

New techniques developed by researchers from the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory could yield computers guaranteed never to lose data: http://news.mit.edu/2015/crash-tolerant-data-storage-0824. Crash-tolerant data storage. Formally verified working file system could lead to computers guaranteed never to lose your data.

Could a new discovery from MIT and Harvard Medical School spell the end of #obesity? http://mitsha.re/R8YjP. A metabolic master switch underlying human obesity. Researchers find pathway that controls metabolism by prompting fat cells to store or burn fat.
Scientists at McGovern Institute for Brain Research discover neurons that weigh costs, benefits in forming habits: http://mitsha.re/R6oVT. Timeline Photos.

Breakthrough science: A team from the MIT Department of Physics and RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT has created a Bose-Einstein condensate in a record-high magnetic field. A new look at superfluidity. MIT team creates a superfluid in a record-high magnetic field.

Have you heard? Business Insider has ranked MIT as the No. 1 computer science and engineering school in the U.S.! The 50 best computer science and engineering schools in the US. If you want to work in tech or engineering, these schools are your best bets.

Researchers at CSAIL - MIT and the Qatar Computing Research Institute have discovered a key vulnerability in Tor, the world's most popular anonymity network. Shoring up Tor. Researchers mount successful attacks against popular anonymity network — and show how to prevent them.

From MIT, a new way to program bacteria to sense, memorize, and respond to signals in the human body! Researchers develop basic computing elements for bacteria. Sensors, memory switches, and circuits can be encoded in a common gut bacterium.

Science breakthrough: MIT Department of Physics researchers have confirmed the existence of the massless “Weyl point.” Long-sought phenomenon finally detected. Weyl points, first predicted in 1929, observed for the first time.

Massachusetts is considered a national hub for #robotics, and MIT has a lot to do with that! The one war Massachusetts can win. About 150 robotics companies have sprung up in Massachusetts as the state rivals Silicon Valley and Pittsburgh for industry supremacy.

#TBT Jay Forrester SM '45 with the Whirlwind computer in the MIT Digital Computer Lab, 1957. Learn about Forrester's pioneering contributions to systems engineering in the current MIT Technology Review: http://mitne.ws/1NOFlpx

Photo: MIT Lincoln Laboratory (Official) Timeline Photos.

How does nitrous oxide, a.k.a. “laughing gas,” work as an anesthetic? Researchers at MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital have discovered what N2O does to the brain. Uncovering the mechanism of our oldest anesthetic. MIT researchers reveal brainwave changes in patients receiving nitrous oxide, or “laughing gas.”

Quantum-dot spectrometer developed by researchers from the MIT School of Science fits inside a smartphone. Read more: http://mitne.ws/1CahZKt

Image: Mary O’Reilly. Chemists design a quantum-dot spectrometer. New instrument is small enough to function within a smartphone, enabling portable light analysis.

New techniques from CSAIL - MIT researchers can help identify students at risk for quitting #MOOCs. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1U84qRu. Helping students stick with MOOCs. New techniques could help identify students at risk for dropping out of online courses.

Introducing phagemids: A new weapon in the fight against antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Researchers develop a new means of killing harmful bacteria. Engineered particles are capable of producing toxins that are deadly to targeted bacteria.

"Then it dawned on me. I could make this happen. I could make robots just like R2-D2. That’s when I decided that I wanted to be a pioneer in the field of robotics." –Helen Greiner '89 SM '90. Why Robots Are As Interesting As Humans. Helen Greiner, co-founder of iRobot, on the moment she decided Artificial Intelligence was her destiny.

What if happy memories could reverse #depression? Fascinating new study from the Picower Institute for Learning and Memory: http://mitne.ws/1HXDPSr. Recalling happier memories can reverse depression. Artificially reactivating positive memories could offer an alternative to traditional antidepressants.

New study by researchers from the MIT Engineering Systems Division uses cellphone data to detect real-time unemployment. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1JThPrS. Can phone data detect real-time unemployment? Study: Usage patterns vary when people are not working.

Researchers at RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT supercool molecules to 500 nanokelvins - almost absolute zero: mitne.ws/1Mo7F1w #physics. MIT team creates ultracold molecules. At near absolute zero, molecules may start to exhibit exotic states of matter.

They missed winning the DARPA Robotics Challenge by mere inches, but in the end, the MIT DRC Team made amazing strides in controlling humanoid robots. Congrats on a fantastic showing! Robotics competition generated groundbreaking research. MIT team based robotic control algorithms on cutting-edge theory.

On #WorldOceansDay, discover the beautiful diversity of marine plankton recently uncovered by Oceans at MIT researchers. Uncovering diversity in an invisible ocean world. New research indicates marine plankton are not only more diverse than previously thought, but also profoundly affected by their environment.

After three years in development, the MIT DRC Team's humanoid robot is ready for battle at this week's DARPA Robotics Challenge finals. Go Tech!! 

Video: Lillie Paquette/MIT School of Engineering  #DARPADRC. Team MIT prepares for the DARPA Robotics Challenge. This is "Team MIT prepares for the DARPA Robotics Challenge" by MIT School of Engineering on Vimeo, the home for high quality videos and the people who love them.

“I want to be able to work with patients that have real, substantial concerns, and to be able to drive the advancements in the lab that will help them most.” –Daniel Zhang '15. Bringing biochemistry to life with color. Senior biology and chemistry major Daniel Zhang helps build noninvasive cancer diagnostic tools.

New discovery from the MIT Department of Physics: Earth-sized #exoplanets with circular orbits, similar to our solar system. Circular orbits identified for small exoplanets. Observations of 74 Earth-sized planets around distant stars may narrow field of habitable candidates.

Jumping cheetah! This MIT #robot clears hurdles while running at 5 mph. Watch: http://mitne.ws/1eD1MTf

“I wanted to be at MIT because I love the open, free-spirited, collaborative place that it is.” –Associate Professor Ed Boyden. Seeking deeper understanding of how the brain works. Edward Boyden develops techniques to study the brain, and how it operates, in finer detail.
Remembering our fallen service members this Memorial Day. Timeline Photos.

A new MIT report details the ways in which funding basic research can benefit us all. New MIT report details benefits of investment in basic research. Authors highlight 15 research opportunities that could help boost the U.S. economy, benefit society.

Happy DNA Day! Did you know we can now edit the genome with a system called CRISPR-Cas9? Learn how it works with this video from the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT. Genome Editing with CRISPR-Cas9. This animation depicts the CRISPR-Cas9 method for genome editing – a powerful new technology with many applications in biomedical research, including the pot...

A new detector developed by researchers from the MIT Department of Physics “sees” single electrons and could help measure neutrino mass: http://mitne.ws/1EnRgLa. New tabletop detector “sees” single electrons. Magnet-based setup may help detect the elusive mass of neutrinos.

Ever wondered where certain regions of the brain are located? Watch as MIT neuroscientist Nancy Kanwisher explores the brain's anatomy: http://mitsha.re/1avSpCo. The Neuroanatomy Lesson | Nancy'sBrainTalks.
How patents predict technological improvements: http://mitne.ws/1cwDQQy. Patents forecast technological change. New method uses patent data to estimate a technology’s future rate of improvement.
