A new coating technology may offer scientists a way to quickly mass-produce tailored nanoparticles that are specially coated for specific applications, including medicines and electronics. More: http://mitne.ws/13oeVI1. Timeline Photos.

Researchers from MIT and elsewhere have built an optical switch that can be turned on by a single photon. The advance could lead to new designs for both classical and quantum computers. http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2013/computing-with-light-0704.html. Timeline Photos.
Atom-thick photovoltaic sheets could pack hundreds of times more power per weight than conventional solar cells. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/17fJcYU. Timeline Photos.
On the hunt for neutrinos: MIT physicist Joseph Formaggio seeks new ways to detect and measure the elusive particles. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/11Nb569. Timeline Photos.

Researchers around the world are seeking ways to “scrub” carbon dioxide from the emissions of fossil-fuel power plants. Now, researchers at MIT have devised a scrubbing system that requires no steam connection, can operate at lower temperatures, and could be added relatively easily to any existing power plant. http://mitne.ws/136s61D (Photo courtesy of Michael Stern) Timeline Photos.

A new algorithm devised at MIT finds the most efficient way to balance taxi trips and shuttle trips to minimize wasted trips. This development could help “mobility on demand” one-way car sharing systems on the road today. http://mitne.ws/14kJPh0. Timeline Photos.
An MIT study has found that a gene associated with longevity also regulates the body’s circadian clock. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/146UNGL. Timeline Photos.
CSAIL - MIT researchers have developed an algorithm that can accurately gauge a person’s heart rate by measuring tiny head movements in video data. More: http://mitne.ws/11plxE5. Timeline Photos.

A new system developed at MIT enables the conversion of an ordinary camera into a light-field camera that can capture high‑resolution, multiperspective images. Take a look: http://mitne.ws/19R4TBY. Timeline Photos.

New software developed at MIT can be used to help people practice their interpersonal skills until they feel more comfortable with situations such as a job interview or a first date. More: http://mitne.ws/11AExLf.
Meet Juliet Simpson, who conducts research at the MIT Sea Grant College Program. JULIET SIMPSON, Coastal Ecologist.

New MIT study analyzes potential of a new treatment to reopen clogged arteries that combines the benefits of angioplasty balloons and drug-releasing stents, but may pose fewer risks. http://mitne.ws/10iMiGg (Image by Vijaya Kolachalama: An artery wall with pieces of the balloon's drug coating attached.) Timeline Photos.
Best of the Week: See how nanotechnology could help fight diabetes. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

“The first step is to understand what is not working well, and then we can focus on developing a better solution.” – MIT biological engineering senior Paula Trepman is helping to tackle problems in global health care. http://mitne.ws/14wEp35. Timeline Photos.
"Surprising finding" in MIT research may lead to a new way to kill cancer cells. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/10V7GjS (Image: Jennifer Jordan and Dragony Fu) Timeline Photos.
New study helps resolve an old conundrum about the origins of coral-reef formations. More: http://mitne.ws/10IOoE9 (Photo: NASA Earth Observatory) Timeline Photos.
New lithium-air battery research could lead to improved batteries for electric cars. More: http://mitne.ws/17l6azV (Photo: Jin Suntivich) Timeline Photos.

Best of the Week: At any given time, cirrus clouds cover nearly one-third of the globe. They cool the planet by reflecting incoming solar radiation and warm it by trapping outgoing heat. See what they're made of: http://mitne.ws/15teMVx (Photo: Peter DeCarlo/Drexel University) Timeline Photos.
Best of the Week: While searching for a way to produce oxygen on the moon, MIT researchers found a method to make steel with zero emissions http://mitne.ws/143WYve. Timeline Photos.
New MIT study identifies influenza viruses circulating in pigs and birds that could pose a risk to humans. http://mitne.ws/10fL15G (Image: CDC) Timeline Photos.
New MIT-led study uses big data to examine the daily travel behavior of individuals in two major cities. http://mitne.ws/15G70Y7 (Graphic: Christian Schneider) Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers are developing systems to allow vehicles to collaborate with drivers to plan routes and schedules. http://mitne.ws/15e84mc. Timeline Photos.
Wind power — even without the wind: Innovative storage system could enable offshore wind farms to deliver power whenever it’s needed. http://mitne.ws/ZzNsRW. Timeline Photos.

New research at MIT could dramatically improve the efficiency of fuel cells, which are considered a promising alternative to batteries for powering everything from electronic devices to cars and homes. Find out more:  http://mitne.ws/14O3BpR. Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers have taken a step in understanding the turbulence in plasmas that could potentially bring practical fusion power closer. More: http://mitne.ws/ZKK5aW. Timeline Photos.
On-demand video of today's memorial service for Officer Collier is now available: http://mit.tv/11lgTE2.

MIT researchers have unraveled the structure of bone with almost atom-by-atom precision, after many years of analysis by some of the world’s most powerful computers and comparison with laboratory experiments to confirm the computed results. More: http://mitne.ws/14vKh0N. Timeline Photos.

Wondering just what nanowires and nanotubes are and what they can do? We explain: http://mitne.ws/ZoWdZb

(This Scanning Electron Microscope image shows an array of nanowires. Credit: Kristian Molhave/Opensource Handbook of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology) Timeline Photos.

In a new paper, MIT physicists describe a new way to predict the risk of collapse in a natural population based on variations in population density in neighboring regions. Early warning signs of population collapse - MIT News Office. Spatial measurements of population density could reveal when threatened natural populations are in danger of crashing.

Nearly half of the world’s population is at risk of infection by the dengue virus, yet there is no specific treatment for the disease. Now a therapy to protect people from the virus could be a step closer, thanks to a team at MIT. More: http://mitne.ws/12AyHzX

(Image: This transmission electron micrograph depicts a number of round, dengue virus particles. Credit: Frederick Murphy/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) Timeline Photos.
Best of the Week: New research involving nanowires, revealing experiments on ionic thrusters and more. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

A new report by researchers at MIT and elsewhere finds that materials manufacturers will likely be unable to meet targets for carbon-emissions reductions by 2050. See what can be done about it: http://mitne.ws/10dKWP5. Timeline Photos.

New research carried out at MIT and elsewhere has demonstrated for the first time that when inserted into a pool of liquid, nanowires — wires that are only hundreds of nanometers (billionths of a meter) across — naturally draw the liquid upward in a thin film that coats the surface of the wire. The finding could have applications in microfluidic devices, biomedical research and inkjet printers. Read the full story: http://mitne.ws/10k8MpA 
. Nanowires can lift liquids without power | MIT Video. New research has demonstrated for the first time that when inserted into a pool of liquid, nanowires naturally draw the liquid upward in a thin film that coats the surface of the wire.

MIT researchers have modeled the structure of a protein known as alpha synuclein — which is most commonly associated with Parkinson’s disease — and found that it can take on either of two proposed states: floppy or rigid. The findings suggest that forcing the protein to switch to the rigid structure, which does not aggregate, could offer a new way to treat Parkinson’s, says Collin Stultz (center), an associate professor of electrical engineering and computer science at MIT. http://mitne.ws/10k8WNI. Timeline Photos.

If robots are ever going to move effectively around our homes or workspaces performing complex tasks, they will need to be more aware of their own limitations, according to researchers at MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL). http://mitne.ws/16htX0y 

(Illustration: Allegra Boverman and Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Simulating the flow of grains in silos, and in other geometries, has proven a tricky, centuries-old problem for scientists. Now researchers at MIT have devised a model of granular flow in three dimensions. The team found the model accurately predicts the results of granular flow experiments, including a flow configuration that has long puzzled scientists. http://mitne.ws/ZQMU7p. Timeline Photos.

New solar-cell design based on dots and wires: MIT researchers improve efficiency of quantum-dot photovoltaic system by adding a forest of nanowires. http://mitne.ws/14iYa0J

Images: Scanning Electron Microscope images show an array of zinc-oxide nanowires (top) and a cross-section of a photovoltaic cell made from the nano wires, interspersed with quantum dots made of lead sulfide (dark areas). A layer of gold at the top (light band) and a layer of indium-tin-oxide at the bottom (lighter area) form the two electrodes of the solar cell. Courtesy of Joel Jean, et al/Advanced Materials. Timeline Photos.

Hitting HIV where it hurts: By pinpointing weak spots in viral proteins, scientists could hobble HIV's rapid evolution — and its ability to outrun new vaccines. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/WRUxMj

(Image: This scanning electron micrograph shows HIV particles infecting a human T cell. Credit: National Institutes of Health) Timeline Photos.

In order to prove the stability of a control system for a robot that’s colliding with the world — when a walking robot’s foot hits the ground, or a grasping robot’s hand touches an object — it’s necessary to evaluate not only every possible configuration of the point of the contact, but also every possible solution of the resulting equations. That’s what CSAIL - MIT researchers  have found a way to do. See how they did it: http://mitne.ws/ZA9hhg. Timeline Photos.

In a recent paper, researchers show how to apply principles from control theory to formal verification. The result could be particularly useful in the area of approximate computation, in which designers of computer systems trade a little bit of computational accuracy for large gains in speed or power efficiency. Can control theory make software better? Techniques used to ensure that airplanes won't stall out in flight could be adapted to prove that computer programs won't divide by zero.

Best of the Week: An explanation of a quantum-mechanical phenomenon that was recently observed for the first time, and an examination of what researchers are doing to change how cancer is diagnosed and treated. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

New study offers insight into some of the precise impairments caused by the loss of dopamine in brain cells affected by Parkinson’s disease. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/Y8a7Cw

(Image: Polarized light micrograph of dopamine crystals, by Spike Walker/Wellcome Images.) Timeline Photos.

Scientists believe the new approach of nanoscale drug delivery can push modern medicine further. Delivering RNA or DNA to specific cells offers the promise of selectively turning genes on or off, while nanoscale devices that can be injected or implanted in the body could allow doctors to target drugs to specific tissues over a defined period of time. Find out more:  http://mitne.ws/Ynh26N 

Image by Paula T. Hammond and Erik C. Dreaden: Human breast cancer cells (purple) are targeted by nanoparticles (green) developed by MIT professor Paula Hammond. The particles bind to receptors overexpressed by cancer cells. Timeline Photos.

Researchers have found that some widely used formulas for predicting how rapidly technology will advance — notably, Moore’s Law and Wright’s Law — offer superior approximations of the pace of technological progress. The new research is the first to directly compare the different approaches in a quantitative way. http://mitne.ws/XPjx4X. How to predict the progress of technology. MIT researcher finds Moore's Law and Wright's Law best predict how technology improves.

Preventing glass from fogging or frosting up is a longstanding challenge with myriad applications: eyeglasses, cameras, microscopes, mirrors and refrigerated displays, to name but a few. So far there has been no systematic way of testing different coatings and materials to see how effectively they work under real-world conditions. Until now: http://mitne.ws/XQr9Vx. MIT-developed coating could prevent frost buildup | MIT Video. A team of MIT researchers has found a coating that outperforms others not only in preventing foggy buildups, but also in maintaining good optical properties without distortion.
Best of the Week: Why “icing” a kicker in (American) football is virtually useless. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

Exploring the brain, and the world: MIT Brain and Cognitive Sciences major Joy Ekuta has pursued her studies and research interests from Israel to Mexico, among other places. Read more about her travels and goals: http://mitne.ws/YYWRxT. Timeline Photos.

The Little Devices group at MIT has developed a solar-powered autoclave, used to sterilize surgical tools, that can be built and repaired in developing countries using locally available parts and materials. The device would cost less than existing kerosene or electric sterilizers and would require no fuel or power. Read the story: http://mitne.ws/YxQmA5

In this video, D-Lab instructor José Gómez-Márquez talks about other medical technologies he has developed for use in the developing world. TR35: José Gómez-Márquez | MIT Video. Jose Gomez-Marquez, program director for the Innovations in International Health program at MIT, demonstrates some of the medical technologies he is developing for use in countries such as Nicaragua.

Drawing upon the chemical composition of rock features on Mercury's surface, MIT scientists have proposed that the planet may have harbored a large, roiling ocean of magma very early in its history, shortly after its formation about 4.5 billion years ago. http://mitne.ws/XndqW1. Mercury may have harbored an ancient magma ocean. Massive lava flows may have given rise to two distinct rock types on Mercury's surface.

A new technique developed by MIT researchers provides the first direct views of how drops and bubbles adhere to surfaces — and how they let go. The findings could be applied to engineering industrial surfaces with controlled adhesion in applications ranging from large desalination and power plants to consumer products.

Find out more about this research: http://mitne.ws/15sZxsV. Scanning droplets | MIT Video. Animation showing how the base of a water droplet forms small "necks" as it moves across a surface that has pillars etched on it.

Your smartphone snapshots could be converted into professional-looking photographs with just the touch of a button, thanks to a processor chip developed at MIT. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/W1qQc1. Timeline Photos.

Standard public-key encryption is secure as long as an attacker knows nothing other than the public key. But financial institutions and other large organizations seek security against more sophisticated attacks, called chosen-ciphertext attacks (CCAs), in which the attacker also has examples of successful decryption. 

CSAIL - MIT researchers have devised a new technique for taking one of these vulnerable, error-prone CCA schemes and turning it into a secure CCA scheme. This could result in the development of more-secure encryption protocols. http://mitne.ws/XbsiFJ. Timeline Photos.

Engineers at MIT have built an automated system that can rapidly produce 3-D, micron-resolution images of thousands of zebrafish larvae and precisely analyze their physical traits. Researchers say the system offers a comprehensive view of how potential drugs affect vertebrates. http://mitne.ws/VSs1Fv. Timeline Photos.
Find out what happens when humans and robots switch roles in a manufacturing setting: http://mitne.ws/W4j3a6. Timeline Photos.

MIT engineers have created genetic circuits in bacterial cells that not only perform logic functions, but also remember the results, which are encoded in the cell’s DNA and passed on for dozens of generations. The circuits could be used as long-term environmental sensors, efficient controls for biomanufacturing, or to program stem cells to differentiate into other cell types. http://mitne.ws/TUWcz8

(Image: Liang Zong and Yan Liang) Timeline Photos.

Best of the week at MIT: A new mathematical framework for evaluating compressed-sensing schemes, and "invisible" particles that could enhance thermoelectric devices. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

From India to Stanford, crossing over to the startup world and now at MIT, Devavrat Shah has spanned disciplines to devise algorithms that can predict consumer preferences or what topics will trend on Twitter. Find out more about his work: http://mitne.ws/YUmfcz. Timeline Photos.

A new approach developed by researchers at MIT and Rutgers University could improve the efficiency of devices that harness power from temperature differences. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/VIrxH6 

(Image: This diagram shows one of the core-shell nanoparticles embedded in a host material. The motion of electrons, as shown by brown lines, is bent in such a way that they appear to be unaffected by the presence of the particle, thus allowing them to pass with little resistance.) Timeline Photos.

This 12-foot-high system housed in an MIT lab has demonstrated the principles of a new humidification-dehumidification system that cleans "produced water" from natural gas wells. The new technology — which MIT researchers say requires far less energy than previous systems — could lead to inexpensive, efficient desalination plants in developing countries. http://mitne.ws/VzPdbs. Timeline Photos.

Quantum dots have the potential for many applications, but have faced a series of hurdles to improved performance. Now, an MIT team says that it has succeeded in overcoming all these obstacles at once. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/11dGAuN. Timeline Photos.

Best of the Week: A young physicist finds her focus in the study of tiny particles, and mechanical engineering students develop new medical devices to meet the needs of local doctors. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

Researchers at MIT’s Research Laboratory of Electronics have come up with a new mathematical framework for evaluating compressed-sensing schemes that factors in the real-world performance of hardware components. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/Xpid6R. Timeline Photos.

MIT chemists have devised a way to identify which proteins are present in different compartments of the mitochondria. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/14AcRv7

(Image: Jeff Martell, Hyun-Woo Rhee and Peng Zou) Timeline Photos.

MIT professors Esther Duflo, Eric Lander and Walter Lewin will lead three new MITx courses this spring, joining three existing MITx courses that will be offered again this semester. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/XV0LGu. Timeline Photos.

An MIT course offers students a chance to work with local doctors in the development of new medical devices — and sometimes these projects end up becoming real products. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/14syg9v. Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers have devised ceramic materials that are highly hydrophobic, but are also durable in the face of extreme temperatures and rough treatment. http://mitne.ws/140yULb. Timeline Photos.
The age of big medical data: Check out the various ways researchers at MIT are looking for clinically useful correlations amid mountains of information. http://mitne.ws/14ew6t4. Timeline Photos.

MIT study on long non-coding RNA could be a first step toward the development of regenerative drugs for patients whose hearts have been damaged by cardiovascular disease or aging. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/WpjR7m. Timeline Photos.

Putting the squeeze on cells: By deforming cells, researchers can deliver RNA, proteins and nanoparticles for many applications. Read more at http://mitne.ws/UUSa7Q

(Image: As cells squeeze through a narrow channel, tiny holes open in their membranes, allowing large molecules such as RNA to pass through. Credit: Armon Sharei and Emily Jackson) Timeline Photos.

A team of scientists from MIT and the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute recently created a time-lapse montage of the daily labors of multiple marine microbial species over a two-day period. http://mitne.ws/SwkDSV

(Image: Colorized, scanning electron micrograph of naturally occurring marine bacterioplankton.) Timeline Photos.

A field experiment conducted in Morocco and co-authored by an MIT economist showed that residents are willing to pay more in order to have water piped into their homes. And despite the impact on their finances, people in households that gain running water report significant improvements in happiness. http://mitne.ws/W4pecZ. Timeline Photos.

The gene that causes Huntington's disease does most of its damage in the basal ganglia, shown in pink. Now, MIT researchers are investigating the details of how methylation might drive the neurodegenerative symptoms seen in Huntington’s disease, with an eye toward developing potential new treatments. http://mitne.ws/X8U2HZ

(Image: U.S. Food and Drug Administration) Timeline Photos.

In 2011, two MIT computer scientists proposed an optical experiment that would harness the laws of quantum mechanics to perform a computation impossible on conventional computers. Last month, four different research groups reported the completion of versions of the experiment. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/W4vGTq. Timeline Photos.

In a study of fruit flies, MIT researchers identified a glial-cell mutation that makes the flies much more prone to epileptic seizures. Counteracting the effects of the glial mutation may be a promising new strategy for developing epilepsy treatments. http://mitne.ws/Xe6Z3W

(Human astrocyte image: Wikipedia/Bruno Pascal) Timeline Photos.

Astronaut Barbara Morgan talked to the finalists of MIT’s annual Zero Robotics competition, in which teams of high-school students directed small satellites aboard the International Space Station. http://mitne.ws/VI37vv. Timeline Photos.
Best of the week: MIT engineers have developed a new polymer film that can generate electricity using water vapor as a power source. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.
Best of the week: A look at how MIT researchers are designing tools that could help advance medical discoveries: http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.
See how an MIT researcher devised a new way to manipulate heat. http://mitne.ws/RJYNuF. Timeline Photos.
Check out what researchers from MIT’s Research Laboratory of Electronics did with MIT's logo! http://mitne.ws/XkLqQZ. Timeline Photos.

A team of MIT researchers has found, for the first time, exactly how different molecular components work together to block the flow of blood from a cut. Now, they are working on applying that knowledge to the development of synthetic materials that could be used to control different kinds of liquid flows, and could lead to a variety of new self-assembling materials. http://mitne.ws/TJqHqB. Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers are designing tools to analyze cells at the microscale, which could lead to big medical discoveries. http://mitne.ws/ZlLMX4. Timeline Photos.

Best of the week: A genomic cut-and-paste technique allows scientists to edit DNA in precise locations, and a redesigned p-type transistor developed at MIT could offer a tantalizing path forward for the microchip industry. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

A coated surface with nanostructured patterns that was recently designed, built and tested by MIT researchers could make for more efficient power generation and desalination. http://mitne.ws/TNu26I. Timeline Photos.

Researchers at MIT, the Broad Institute and Rockefeller University have developed a new technique for precisely altering the genomes of living cells by adding or deleting genes. The researchers say the technology could lead to new therapies, among other potential applications. http://mitne.ws/UJ9Fsp. Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers have set a new bar for transistor performance with the development of a redesigned p-type transistor, a basic component of all computer chips. http://mitne.ws/XmpgSe. Timeline Photos.
Happy 2013! Take a look at some of the technologies of the future that are being researched today at MIT. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.

As we welcome 2013, take a look back at some of the ways MIT researchers explored the universe in 2012.
http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers built some pretty amazing little machines in 2012. Check them out: http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.

This year, MIT researchers engineered a device that delivers a tiny, high-pressure jet of medicine through the skin without the use of a hypodermic needle. The device can be programmed to deliver a range of doses to various depths — an improvement over similar jet-injection systems that are now commercially available. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.

Cheaper, quieter and fuel‑efficient biplanes could put supersonic travel on the horizon.

http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.

Software that can "see" someone's pulse? In the past year, research at MIT has made it possible.
Full story: http://mitne.ws/V6PrqM. Making the Invisible Visible in Video | MIT Video. MIT researchers have developed new software that amplifies variations in successive frames of video that are imperceptible to the naked eye.
Software that makes it possible to actually "see" someone's pulse in a video, chips as mini Internets — what else will the future unveil? http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.
A new spectroscopy technique developed at MIT and Case Western Reserve University could help doctors better identify breast tumors. http://mitne.ws/TZqLAV. Timeline Photos.
Research and studies at MIT are seeking out ways to help build the future of manufacturing in the 21st century. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers continue to examine social issues, including the “gender gap” and its impact on the political aspirations of young women. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.
Can you tell which of these smiles is showing happiness? A computer system developed at MIT can. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.
We peer into the brain to begin our look back on your favorite stories of 2012. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear. Timeline Photos.
As the holiday shopping season winds down, we just have to ask: If you could have any of these not-yet-to-market innovations from MIT, which would you want?

Study that used cellphone data says roadway congestion can be alleviated throughout a metropolitan area by altering the trips of drivers in specific neighborhoods: http://mitne.ws/R6V0ao. Timeline Photos.

MIT researchers have uncovered a fundamentally new kind of magnetic behavior, which could possibly lead to advances in data storage or communications. http://mitne.ws/UErJ4S. MIT researchers discover a new kind of magnetism - MIT News Office. Experiments demonstrate ‘quantum spin liquid,’ which could have applications in new computer memory storage.

A possible path to earlier cancer detection: Researchers at MIT have developed nanoparticles that can home to a tumor and interact with cancer proteins to produce thousands of biomarkers, which can then be easily detected in a patient’s urine. http://mitne.ws/SGfIzF. Timeline Photos.
At 11:30 today, the MIT Symphony Orchestra to host memorial for Connecticut tragedy in Lobby 7 http://mitne.ws/U0OoKt.

Find out how porcupines could help engineers design better medical devices. http://mitne.ws/S4QTwZ 

(Photo: Mike Cuccarese) Timeline Photos.

More of the best of the week on MIT News: New research into the moon's battered history and an examination of how people approach risk when it comes to their finances. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

The best of the week at MIT News: Peer back at the light from the first stars, and travel along with an MIT senior who's helping to make an impact around the world. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

Peering back in time, scientists find that the earliest stars may have blinked on when the universe was 750 million years old. http://mitne.ws/SIQkY2

(Image: European Southern Observatory/M. Kornmesser) Timeline Photos.

When Arfa Aijazi was accepted to MIT, she believed that she "didn’t need to apply anywhere else.” Since then, the senior has taken full advantage of opportunities to help make an impact around the world. Read her story: http://mitne.ws/SvbZ4t. Timeline Photos.
Do you have a consistent approach to your financial choices? A new study shows that at most a third of us do. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/RwIQJk. Timeline Photos.
Real life Transformers? MIT researchers unveil reconfigurable robot design! The robotic equivalent of a Swiss army knife. Reconfigurable robot a step toward something that can become almost anything.

Best of the week: A look inside the MIT EECS Department; combating boredom; outreach on the water; and seeing up close and far away http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. MIT News Office | Best of the Week for Nov. 11-16.

Are you up in our neck of the woods, leaf peeping this weekend? If so, you'd be surprised how much carbon dioxide those beautiful leaves carry with them. The mathematics of leaf decay - MIT News Office. A mathematical model reveals commonality within the diversity of leaf decay.

Diving into a pool from a few feet up allows you to enter the water smoothly and painlessly, but jumping from a bridge can lead to a fatal impact. The water is the same in each case, so why is the effect of hitting its surface so different? Probing the mysteries of cracks and stresses - MIT News Office. Analysis of molecular-level fracture and stress mechanisms could have broad implications for understanding materials’ behavior.

“The operational scenario that was envisioned for this was a hazmat situation where people are suited up with the full suit, and they go in and explore an environment,” says Maurice Fallon, a research scientist in the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. “The current approach would be to textually summarize what they had seen afterward — ‘I went into this room on the left, I saw this, I went into the next room,’ and so on. We want to try to automate that.” Automatic building mapping could help emergency responders - MIT News Office. A prototype sensor array that can be worn on the chest automatically maps the wearer’s environment, recognizing movement between floors.

“We’re hoping that some of the information we’ve been able to glean from our study will help us to approach a new understanding of heart development, and also lead to the possibility of using cells that are generated in a dish to replace heart cells that are lost as a consequence of aging and disease,” says Laurie Boyer, an associate professor in the MIT Department of Biology. Probing matters of the heart - MIT News Office. New study of stem cell differentiation could help researchers better understand the genetic basis of heart disease.

NASA, MIT's Lincoln Laboratory and others have opened up a contest (for those 18 and younger) to name an asteroid. So, what would you name it? 

Learn more about the contest at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/nasa-announces-asteroid-naming-contest-for-students-0905.html. Timeline Photos.

“What it does is take whatever carbon is available, and stores it in the form of a polymer, which is similar in its properties to a lot of petroleum-based plastics,” Brigham says. By knocking out a few genes, inserting a gene from another organism and tinkering with the expression of other genes, Brigham and his colleagues were able to redirect the microbe to make fuel instead of plastic. Teaching a microbe to make fuel - MIT News Office. Genetically modified organism could turn carbon dioxide or waste products into a gasoline-compatible transportation fuel.

A team of researchers from the MIT Department of Physics and Harvard University has achieved a crucial long-term goal of efforts to create quantum devices: the ability to convert a laser beam into a stream of single photons, or particles of light, in a controlled way. Single-photon transmitter could enable new quantum devices - MIT News Office. Long-sought goal for quantum devices — the ability to transmit single photons while blocking multiple photons — is finally achieved.

MIT chemistry professor Stephen J. Lippard, who has spent much of his career studying platinum drugs, has now identified a compound that kills cancer cells better than cisplatin, the most commonly used platinum anticancer drug. The new compound may be able to evade cancer-cell resistance to conventional platinum compounds. New drug candidate shows promise against cancer - MIT News Office. Platinum compound may offer an alternative to cisplatin, a widely used chemotherapy agent.

“You have all this data, and clearly, if you want to store it, what people would naturally do is compress it,” says Bonnie Berger, a professor in MIT's Department of Mathematics. “The problem is that eventually you have to look at it, so you have to decompress it to look at it. But our insight is that if you compress the data in the right way, then you can do your analysis directly on the compressed data. And that increases the speed while maintaining the accuracy of the analyses.” Searching genomic data faster - MIT News Office. Biologists’ capacity for generating genomic data is increasing more rapidly than computing power. A new algorithm will help them keep up.

Researchers led by an MIT postdoc have analyzed an artificial system that models the light-capturing method used by deep-sea bacteria. Researchers explain how dye-based nanotubes can help harvest light’s energy - MIT News Office. Tiny cylinders help reveal how natural-light-harvesting antennae collect light with exceptional efficiency.

MIT physicist and CERN researcher answers questions on the Higgs boson announcement from CERN this morning. 3 Questions: Physicist Christoph Paus discusses newly discovered particle - MIT News Office. Dozens of MIT physicists were part of the team that found what might be the Higgs boson. What does their discovery mean, and what’s next for particle physics?

“Random-matrix theory allows us to understand how disorder in a material affects its electrical properties" - Jiahao Chen, MIT Chemistry Department . New technique allows simulation of noncrystalline materials. Multidisciplinary team develops mathematical approach that could help in simulating materials for solar cells and LEDs.
Harnessing heat radiation that most solar cells ignore. All-carbon solar cell harnesses infrared light.

“I will never get over the thrill when I see a new terrain for the first time" Researchers find evidence of ice content at the moon’s south pole. Scientists map Shackleton crater, whose unusually bright floor may hint at the presence of ice.

In under two minutes, learn how these polymers may change the future of microchips.  Tinier Wires [Video] Researchers at MIT have found a new way of making complex three-dimensional structures using self-assembling polymer materials that form tiny wires and junctions.

"...new research shows that the region may be ripe for another devastating earthquake" Researchers find building seismic strain in Azerbaijan. Deformation caused by colliding tectonic plates may threaten Azerbaijani capital, oil supplies to Europe.

"The secret lies in a pattern of tiny inverted pyramids etched into the surface of the silicon. These tiny indentations, each less than a millionth of a meter across, can trap rays of light as effectively as conventional solid silicon surfaces that are 30 times thicker." Textured surface may boost power output of thin silicon solar cells. MIT team finds new approach to trapping  light efficiently in thin-film silicon solar cells.

The researchers, led by Rahul Sarpeshkar, an associate professor of MIT EECS Department, fabricated the fuel cell on a silicon chip. New energy source for future medical implants: sugar - MIT News Office. Implantable fuel cell built at MIT could power neural prosthetics that help patients regain control of limbs.

Using a technique known as “nucleic acid origami,” chemical engineers have built tiny particles made out of DNA and RNA that can deliver snippets of RNA directly to tumors, turning off genes expressed in cancer cells. Researchers achieve RNA interference, in a lighter package - MIT News Office. Pared-down nucleic acid nanoparticle poses less risk of side effects, offers better targeting.

“We are witnessing an unprecedented period of growth in unstructured digital data on the Web and in the cloud. And this will only further accelerate through the rapid growth of mobile devices such as smartphones and connected cars,” said Intel’s CTO, Justin Rattner. MIT, Intel unveil new initiatives addressing ‘big data’ - MIT News Office. An Intel research center based at MIT will be the cornerstone of a new research project dubbed ‘bigdata@CSAIL.’

Using stiffer pavements on the nation’s roads could reduce vehicle fuel consumption by as much as 3 percent — a savings that could add up to 273 million barrels of crude oil per year, or $15.6 billion at today’s oil prices. This would result in an accompanying annual decrease in CO2 emissions of 46.5 million metric tons.  Civil engineers find savings where the rubber meets the road - MIT News Office. Study shows that pavement deflection under vehicle tires makes for a continuous uphill drive that increases fuel consumption.

“As a child I always dreamed about inventing machines. But when I started taking computer science classes, physics classes and engineering classes, I realized that what I found most exciting was when new physics enables new applications,” says Soljacic, who in 2008 won a MacArthur Fellowship, commonly known as the “genius grant.” A physicist and an inventor. New technologies from Marin Soljacic’s lab could have a far-reaching impact on daily life.

In a new paper, published in Cell today, the researchers showed that staggering the doses of two specific drugs dramatically boosts their ability to kill a particularly malignant type of breast cancer cells. One-two punch knocks out aggressive breast cancer cells - MIT News Office. New MIT study shows that staggered delivery of cancer drugs is far more effective than administering them at the same time.

Scientists on a planetary-heat-seeking mission have detected the first infrared light from a super-Earth — in this case, a planet some 40 light-years away. And according to their calculations, 55 Cancri e, a planet almost twice the size of Earth, is throwing off some serious heat. First light from a super-Earth spotted - MIT News Office. Detection reveals a searing planet.

You have to give Donald Sadoway points for style: Not many professors come to the last class of a semester dressed in black tie, decorate the table with linen and a vase of fresh roses, and toast their students with champagne. But then, Sadoway has a tendency to do things differently. Taking an innovative approach to battery design - MIT News Office. Donald Sadoway’s radical rethinking of electricity storage could revitalize renewable-power technologies.

At the IEEE International Symposium on Performance Analysis of Systems and Software earlier this month, researchers from MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) presented a new method for improving the efficiency of hardware simulations of multicore chips. Unlike competing methods, it guarantees that the simulator won’t go into “deadlock” — a state in which cores get stuck waiting for each other to relinquish system resources, such as memory. Simulating tomorrow’s chips - MIT News Office. A new system makes hardware models of multicore chips more efficient, easier to design and more reliable.

“You normally have to put a lot of energy into converting carbon dioxide into something useful,” says Kimberly Hamad-Schifferli, an associate professor of mechanical engineering and biological engineering. “We demonstrated hybrid copper-gold nanoparticles are much more stable, and have the potential to lower the energy you need for the reaction.” . Hybrid copper-gold nanoparticles convert CO2. May reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

A team of MIT researchers has developed a new type of nanoparticle that can synthesize proteins on demand. Once these “protein-factory” particles reach their targets, the researchers can turn on protein synthesis by shining ultraviolet light on them — effectively creating cancer drugs at the site of the tumor. Nano-sized ‘factories’ churn out proteins - MIT News Office. Tiny particles could manufacture cancer drugs at tumor sites.

“I think this concept could become an important part of the future of photovoltaics,” says the paper’s senior author, Jeffrey Grossman, the Carl Richard Soderberg Career Development Associate Professor of Power Engineering at MIT. A new dimension for solar energy - MIT News Office. Innovative 3-D designs from an MIT team can more than double the solar power generated from a given area.

Ever have trouble understanding how fluid dynamics works? Why cold water and hot water affect weather? Check this out. Weather in a tank. Fluid dynamics plays a central role in determining Earth's climate. Ocean currents and eddies stir up contents from the deep, while atmospheric winds and wea...

Miles' work includes work on printable, flexible solar cells that can be added to paper or fabric. Read more about that work here: http://mitne.ws/w7kErY. MIT student inventor Miles C. Barr receives Lemelson-MIT Student Prize - MIT News Office. $30,000 Lemelson-MIT Collegiate Student Prizes awarded to inventive students at three leading universities.

Free of charge, the I2E website has been online since July, and users have already carried out approximately 2,000 simulations. New tool for analyzing solar-cell materials - MIT News Office. Website offers a way of optimizing solar cell materials and production.

“When you start to explain how difficult it would be to find the connectome of an entire brain, people ask, ‘What’s the point? That seems too far off.’ But even finding or mapping the connections in a small piece of brain can tell you a lot." My connectome, myself - MIT News Office. Neuroscientist Sebastian Seung is on a quest to map brain connections that reveal how our memories and personalities take root.

“You can use anything green, even grass clippings” as the raw material, Mershin says. Harnessing nature’s solar cells - MIT News Office. Photovoltaic panels made from plant material could become a cheap, easy alternative to traditional solar cells.

clusters.summary:
Find an event near you: http://mitsha.re/RRW8S2 

Scratch is a project of the Lifelong Kindergarten group of the MIT Media Lab. Researchers at the MIT Media Laboratory and the University of California at Berkeley have developed a new display technology that automatically corrects for ... A brief video history of the magnificent Paradiso Synthesizer created by the MIT Media Lab's Joe Paradiso. MIT announced today the launch of a new Laboratory for Social Machines at the MIT Media Lab, with major investment from Twitter. With the MIT Media Lab as a founding anchor member, a new Ethics and Governance of Artificial Intelligence Fund will support work around the world that advances the development of artificial intelligence in the public interest. In a video released this month, a group at MIT's Media Lab demonstrated how a group of tiny robots can track the rails of a zipper and seal you into your clothing -- and you won't need to lift a finger.
messages:
This week, the MIT Media Lab held a conference celebrating one if its founders, the late MIT Prof. Seymour Papert. For the occasion, the LEGO Foundation created special Papert minifigures, and announced a new fellowship in his honor. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/nbKt308qr4C

Photo: Lego Foundation. Timeline Photos.

"STEM matters to me because it fuels my mission to show compassion through computation." Meet Joy Buolamwini, a grad student in the MIT Media Lab and MIT Center for Civic Media, whose work on algorithm bias helped her win a national contest highlighting the next generation of women in STEM. Learn more about Buolamwini and the Search for #HiddenFigures contest: http://mitsha.re/8aBf3088eWa. Algorithmic Justice League.

With the MIT Media Lab as a founding anchor member, a new Ethics and Governance of Artificial Intelligence Fund will support work around the world that advances the development of artificial intelligence in the public interest. MIT Media Lab to participate in $27 million initiative on AI ethics and governance. Fund establishes a global initiative to advance artificial intelligence research for the public good.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 5 - Celebrating Engineers Week

Engineering is all around us. InFORM is a dynamic display that can render 3-D content so users can interact with digital information in a tangible way. Image: Tangible Media Group, MIT Media Lab. media.giphy.com.

Top 16 posts of 2016: No. 16 - Circuit jewlery

The MIT Media Lab developed temporary tattoos that double as digital interfaces. MIT’s DuoSkin turns temporary tattoos into on-skin interfaces. Your next tattoo could be functional as well as aesthetic. A new MIT Media Lab product called DuoSkin created in partnership with Microsoft Research turns..
A Nightmare on Ames Street 😱 Happy Halloween from the MIT Media Lab! Scene at MIT: A nightmare on Ames Street. The Media Lab has never looked spookier . . . thanks to the Nightmare Machine.

Barack Obama talks AI, robo-cars, and the future of the world with MIT Media Lab Director Joi Ito: mitsha.re/EzGR30570s9 via WIRED. Barack Obama Talks AI, Robo Cars, and the Future of the World. The president in conversation with MIT's Joi Ito and WIRED editor-in-chief Scott Dadich.

The Electome tool from the MIT Media Lab will provide journalists with an analysis of presidential debate related tweets. #Election2016. Q&A: How Twitter explains the 2016 election. “Electome” project charts the national conversation in unique detail.

Megan Smith ’86, SM ’88 and other thought leaders offer advice to students on how women in STEM fields can develop skills for navigating life and work. Media Lab conference addresses gender bias, diversity, and inclusion in STEM. Megan Smith ’86, SM ’88 and other thought leaders offer advice to students on how women in STEM fields can develop skills for navigating life and work.

New from the MIT Media Lab: Temporary tattoos that double as a digital interfaces. More, via TechCrunch: http://mitsha.re/ibeu303fvnu. DuoSkin:Functional, stylish on-skin user interfaces. DuoSkin is a fabrication process that enables anyone to create customized functional devices that can be attached directly on their skin. Using gold metal leaf,…

The ATLAS Experiment at CERN in Switzerland has granted MIT Media Lab researchers unique access to a live feed of particle collisions detected at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), the world’s largest particle accelerator. Music of the (data) spheres. A new MIT project taps into particle collisions to generate music and forge harmony between science and art.

Researchers at the MIT Media Lab have opened a hairy new chapter in 3-D printing! Learn more: http://mitsha.re/7Vij301muRL

GIF courtesy of the Tangible Media Group. tmg-trackr.media.mit.edu.

A promising study from the MIT Media Lab finds mobile apps can help teach literacy in poor communities. Can technology help teach literacy in poor communities? Project to provide children with tablets loaded with literacy apps reports encouraging results in Africa, U.S.

Amphibian, a project from the MIT Media Lab, lets you explore underwater worlds virtually. http://mitsha.re/10y13W

Gif: Living Mobile Group. giphy.com.

A project out of the MIT Media Lab just made government data more valuable and accessible to a wider audience. Website Seeks to Make Government Data Easier to Sift Through. Data USA, a project by the M.I.T. Media Lab and Deloitte, is free to use and its software code is open source, so that developers can build custom applications.

New from The MIT Press and MIT Media Lab: The Journal of Design and Science, an open-access platform providing novel connections between science and design. MIT Media Lab and MIT Press launch Journal of Design and Science. Journal will offer a new, open-access alternative for academic publishing.

Engineering transforms the world. Join MIT in celebrating Engineers Week! #EWeek2016

Video clip: Tangible Media Group, MIT Media Lab. media.giphy.com.

Professor Emeritus Marvin Minsky, a giant in the field of artificial intelligence and a longtime MIT mainstay, has died. Marvin Minsky, “father of artificial intelligence,” dies at 88. Professor emeritus was a co-founder of CSAIL and a founding member of the Media Lab.

Just in time for this week's #HourofCode: A new PBS KIDS  ScratchJr app, co-developed at the MIT Media Lab, is helping children learn programming basics! New PBS KIDS ScratchJr app launches. Developed in collaboration with the MIT Media Lab and Tufts University, the PBS KIDS ScratchJr app helps children ages 5-8 learn coding concepts.

BioLogic, a new "bio-skin" from the MIT Media Lab's Tangible Media Group, peels back in response to humidity and sweat. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/UlyJL. Biologic. Learn more about the project by watching the "Making of Biologic" here: https://vimeo.com/142212881 Initiated from MIT Media Lab, BioLogic is our attempt….

In celebration of the MIT Media Lab's 30th anniversary, LEGO and the LEGO Foundation unveiled a model of the lab constructed out of Lego bricks!

Watch a video about MIT's collaboration with LEGO, empowering children to be creative thinkers: http://mitsha.re/U2nU0. Timeline Photos.

Music + technology = innovative symphonies! Learn about MIT Media Lab professor Tod Machover's new tech-infused works debuting at the LUCERNE FESTIVAL: http://mitsha.re/RNw2q

Photo: Stefan Deuber. Timeline Photos.

After hitchBOT's recent demise, MIT Media Lab's Kate Darling describes humans' ability to relate emotionally to robots and other objects. MIT's Kate Darling: what the death of hitchBOT teachs us about humans (Wired UK) Two weeks ago hitchBOT, a hitchhiking robot who was roaming the world relying on the kindness of strangers, was vandalised. HitchBOT's demise didn't come as a shock to everyone though -- including Kate Darling, an expert in robot ethics at MIT Media Lab.

Researchers from the MIT Media Lab have developed a new system that can eliminate many of the washed-out spots that plague overexposed images. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/R5QSW. A camera that can’t be overexposed? MIT team says it’s possible. Some MIT researchers think they’ve found a way to make digital photography even more idiot-proof. By combining next-generation camera hardware with new image-processing algorithms, a team from the school’s Media Lab says it’s possible to eliminate many of the washed-out spots.

Happy Star Wars Day! Watch the MIT Media Lab recreate Princess Leia's hologram: http://mitne.ws/1DPkpb7 #Maythe4thbewithyou

Photo: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Watch and see how MIT learns. http://mitsha.re/1DLnGNx. How MIT Learns. A glimpse into the experience of creative learning at MIT. Learning Over Education Initiative @ MIT Media Lab http://learn.media.mit.edu Video & animation….

New thumbnail-mounted wireless track pad could operate digital devices. Read more: http://mitne.ws/1Jb57SE 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT http://mitne.ws/1Jb7o0j. NailO: A thumbnail-mounted wireless track pad. Researchers at the MIT Media Lab are developing a new, wearable device that turns the user's thumbnail into a miniature, wireless track pad. (Learn more abou...
In a visit to the MIT Media Lab this week, noted behavioral scientist Temple Grandin shared her insights about how to support and encourage people living with autism.

This device from the MIT Media Lab converts text to speech for the visually impaired. Finger-mounted reading device for the blind. Audio feedback helps user scan finger along a line of text, which software converts to speech.

Zipperbot can help you dress yourself. MIT’s zipper robots could dress you — if you let them. This is a robot that has an eye for style. In a video released this month, a group at MIT's Media Lab demonstrated how a group of tiny robots can track the rails of a zipper and seal you into your clothing -- and you won't need to lift a finger.

All-star MIT women entrepreneurs pave the way for gender balance in tech: http://mitsha.re/18jZg1a #womenintech. All-star MIT women entrepreneurs pave the way for gender balance in tech. On Thursday night MIT held its first Women in Innovation and Entrepreneurship networking reception in the sparse and modern Gagosian-like gallery space of the MIT Media Lab. The event was organized and hosted by two of MIT’s most prominent women in tech, Erika Ebbel Angle, founder and chairman of Sc….
Explore this decade of data with a presentation by Prof. Alex "Sandy" Pentland of the MIT Media Lab: http://mitsha.re/1Fo2jR9. Timeline Photos.

MIT announced today the launch of a new Laboratory for Social Machines at the MIT Media Lab, with major investment from Twitter.  MIT launches Laboratory for Social Machines with major Twitter investment. Program aims to develop collaborative technologies to tackle complex social problems.

A new system from the MIT Media Lab combines your screens into one experience. MIT Invents A Magic Lens That Combines All Your Screens Into A Single Experience. With THAW, smartphones can seamlessly interact with what's happening on laptop and tablet screens. And that's only the beginning.
The Place Pulse project from the MIT Media Lab maps our urban perceptions. http://mitsha.re/1sVY7mI. Timeline Photos.

Happy 87th birthday to artificial intelligence pioneer Marvin Minsky, MIT professor emeritus, cofounder of CSAIL - MIT, and a leading force behind the MIT Media Lab! 

Listen to Minsky describe his contributions to AI: http://mitsha.re/1lKetJ0
Take Minsky's course, The Society of Mind, on MIT OpenCourseWare: http://mitsha.re/1lKgcOx

Photo: Bcjordan/Wikimedia Commons. Timeline Photos.

Little kids can code, too! ScratchJr, a new version of Scratch for children ages 5-7, is now available as a free app. Details: http://mitne.ws/1pqbJUZ  

ScratchJr: http://www.scratchjr.org
Lifelong Kindergarten group from the MIT Media Lab: http://llk.media.mit.edu. Timeline Photos.

New vision-correcting electronic displays from the MIT Media Lab could let users dispense with glasses. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1nNkdX0

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SNdapCs6vR8. Vision Correcting Displays. Researchers at the MIT Media Laboratory and the University of California at Berkeley have developed a new display technology that automatically corrects for ...

A brief video history of the magnificent Paradiso Synthesizer created by the MIT Media Lab's Joe Paradiso. #tbt. The Paradiso Synthesizer. MIT News - March 14, 2012 In 1973, Media Lab associate professor Joe Paradiso was an undergraduate at Tufts University, and didn't know anyone who had built ...

In his latest web series, actor/director George Takei — better known as Sulu from the original Star Trek — pays a visit to MIT. He notes being amazed with a place where "researchers work for human connection, empathy, and art." George Takei Gets Schooled at MIT | Takei's Take Boston. George Takei visits the MIT Media Lab and the MIT AgeLab, where he takes a test drive in Miss Daisy, a car designed to respond to the needs of aging drivers....

"The next great engineering platform will be living matter itself." Forget Robots. We’ll Soon Be Fusing Technology With Living Matter | Business | WIRED. WIRED sat down with Joi Ito, the director of the MIT Media Lab, to discuss this phenomenon of convergence, where digital bits from the computer world are fusing with atoms here in the physical world (see gallery above). The trend is advancing, he says, and it won't stop at gadgets. For Ito, the next….

To mark World Telecommunications & Information Society Day, a new project from the MIT Media Lab: 20 Day Stranger, in which you can share snippets of your life anonymously with someone you don't know. #WTISD. For 20 Days Your Best Friend Online Could Be a Total Stranger. Social media is all about connecting with people you know, people you sort of know, or people you want to know. But what about all those people you didn’t know you wanted to know? They’re out there, too, and the new iPhone app 20 Day Stranger wants to put you...

Kids can code! Take part in #ScratchDay this Saturday, 5/17. Find an event near you: http://mitsha.re/RRW8S2 

Scratch is a project of the Lifelong Kindergarten group of the MIT Media Lab. Learn more: http://llk.media.mit.edu . Scratch Day 2014. Vimeo is the home for high-quality videos and the people who love them.

Two entrepreneurs who met at the MIT Media Lab are building STEM toys for a new generation. More: http://mitsha.re/1gDDxPj  

(Photo: Makey Makey) Timeline Photos.

The Hybrid Basketry project from the MIT Media Lab combines 3-D printing with hand-woven patterns.  Hybrid Basketry. Contemporary 3D printing and traditional craft rarely meet in the same creation. The Hybrid Basketry project merges these two distinct traditions: 3D-printed...

At the 2014 TED Conference, MIT Professor Hugh Herr spoke about the bionic limbs he is building that let us run, climb, and dance: http://mitne.ws/1gKj7ss. The new bionics that let us run, climb and dance. Hugh Herr is building the next generation of bionic limbs, robotic prosthetics inspired by nature's own designs. Herr lost both legs in a climbing accident 30 years ago; now, as the head of the MIT Media Lab’s Biomechatronics group, he shows his incredible technology in a talk that's both technical….

At the TED Conference in Vancouver today, Boston Marathon bombing survivor Adrianne Haslet-Davis will dance on a prosthetic leg that the MIT Media Lab's Hugh Herr, himself a double amputee, designed and engineered. Story via WBUR 90.9 FM: http://mitsha.re/1qVmIa5. Timeline Photos.
Inexpensive ‘nano-camera’ developed by MIT Media Lab can operate at the speed of light. More: http://mitne.ws/1eqAbiy. Timeline Photos.

A carving tool designed at the MIT Media Lab allows the user to control the carving process while aided by a computer guidance system that is preprogrammed with the desired three-dimensional shape. More: http://mitne.ws/I4rqzH. FreeD: MIT 'smart tools' meld personal technique with computerized controls. It's often easy to tell at a glance the difference between a mass-produced object and one that has been handcrafted: The handmade item is likely to have dist...

MIT grad student David Sengeh writes about the Human Bionic Project. Find out more: http://bionic.media.mit.edu/#/ The Human Bionic Project: visualizing real-life Iron Man. In my doctoral research at the MIT Media Lab, I work with a real life Tony Stark (Iron Man) in many ways. My thesis adviser Hugh Herr is a double...

MIT Media Lab researchers have devised a new approach to generating holograms that could lead to color holographic-video displays that are much cheaper to manufacture than today’s monochromatic displays. More: http://mitne.ws/11On8zM. Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary: 16.00x makes the basics of spaceflight accessible to every... A new study by researchers from MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics shows that a combination of exercise and artificial gravity can mitigate the effects of weightlessness in space. Congrats to Martin York, grad student in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics, who was named the @usairforce Cadet of the Year! And MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics will be a part of the spectacle. “I think it’s important for young women and girls to get role models,” says Marlyse Reeves, a senior in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. This painting portrays Sheila Widnall, Institute Professor in the MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics department and former Secretary of the United States Air Force.
messages: Congrats to Martin York, grad student in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics, who was named the @usairforce Cadet of the Year! Martin York named U.S. Air Force Cadet of the Year. Graduate student in AeroAstro recognized for exemplary military performance, academics, and physical fitness.

“I think it’s important for young women and girls to get role models,” says Marlyse Reeves, a senior in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. Growing a network of role models. Senior Marlyse Reeves is building a supportive community of women in aerospace engineering.

“My parents are physicists, and maybe I wanted to rebel, so I went into engineering.” —Hamsa Balakrishnan, associate professor in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. Ready for takeoff. Hamsa Balakrishnan develops algorithms to reduce airport congestion.

Awww... Graduating MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics student Morris Vanegas created a sentimental photo album with his master's thesis on variability in sensor placement on the human body. This Guy Did a Romantic Photo Shoot With His Student Thesis. There is no love that is greater than the love between a student and his thesis.

It's a bird ... it's a plane ...  it's Flugtag! And MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics will be a part of the spectacle. Run, jump, fly: Student aviators to compete in national Flugtag competition. AeroAstro grad students are building a human-powered aircraft that will (hopefully) fly over the Charles River.

“I want to study hard and use my career to be able to do something to give back.” — Raichelle Aniceto, senior in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. Ideas in orbit. From MIT to the moon, and on campus, senior Raichelle Aniceto builds new connections.

Students around the world can rocket into space with a free edX course taught by MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics professor/astronaut Jeff Hoffman! 

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Rocket into space with MIT professor and astronaut Jeff Hoffman. Spaceflight is exciting, and you don’t have to be a “Rocket Scientist” to share in the excitement! 16.00x makes the basics of spaceflight accessible to every...

A new study by researchers from MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics shows that a combination of exercise and artificial gravity can mitigate the effects of weightlessness in space. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1RTH6Tw

Photo: Bill Litant/MIT AeroAstro. Working out in artificial gravity. A combination of exercise and artificial gravity may lessen negative effects of weightlessness in space.

Top 10 posts of 2014: No. 3 - Flying cars

A flying car by MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics spinoff Terrafugia moves from science fiction to reality: http://mitsha.re/1mfLOAM. Timeline Photos.

This week, MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics, the nation’s first program in aeronautical engineering, celebrates 100 years of flight. Highlights from the department's remarkable achievements in MIT Spectrum: http://mitsha.re/1wofYCD 

Photos/photo illustrations: Len Rubenstein #AeroAstro100. Timeline Photos.

President Obama nominates MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics Professor Dava Newman for NASA's No. 2 leadership spot. More: http://mitne.ws/1zf547D

Photo: Patrick Gillooly. Timeline Photos.

Team from MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics finds a one-way ticket to Mars will require a lot more innovation: http://mitne.ws/111cbkT  #MarsOne

Image courtesy of Bryan Versteeg/Mars One. Mars One (and done?) MIT team independently assesses the technical feasibility of the proposed Mars One mission.

Secret's out: This week, Google unveiled its new #ProjectWing drone-delivery initiative, led by Nicholas Roy of MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics and CSAIL - MIT.  Inside Google's Secret Drone-Delivery Program. For two years, the company has been working to build flying robots that can deliver products across a city in a minute or two. An Atlantic exclusive.
Happy #NationalAviationDay! A brief history of flight innovation from MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics: http://mitsha.re/1pYf79T. Timeline Photos.

MIT is everywhere — including low earth orbit! 

Story about SPHERES from MIT News: http://mitne.ws/1q0x6gk
More on the MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics SPHERES project: http://mitsha.re/1q0wIi5. Timeline Photos.

Behold "Double Bubble," an MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics-designed jetliner that burns far less fuel than a Boeing 737.  A Jetliner For A Fuel-Starved Future. Slimming down the classic passenger jet.

Today is #ArmedForcesDay, honoring American military service members. This painting portrays Sheila Widnall, Institute Professor in the MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics department and former Secretary of the United States Air Force. Widnall was the first woman to lead a branch of the U.S. military. http://mitne.ws/1nPvnLi 

(Image courtesy of artist Everett Raymond Kinstler) Timeline Photos.

"When on Mars, jump, don't run." WIRED takes a look at the next-generation spacesuits designed by MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics' Dava Newman.  . A closer look at MIT's next-gen spacesuits (Wired UK) Dava Newman's designs put the squeeze on astronauts -- and save them precious energy.
A flying car by MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics spinoff Terrafugia moves from science fiction to reality: http://mitsha.re/1mfLOAM. Timeline Photos.

“We know that pilots aren’t always looking out the window, and we know that people don’t always pay attention in whatever they’re doing,” says Mary “Missy” Cummings, associate professor of MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. “The question is: Can you get people to pay attention enough, at the right time, to keep the system performing at a high degree?” Driving drones can be a drag - MIT News Office. Study shows distractions may alleviate boredom and improve drone operators’ performance.

“They’re so small that you can put several [thrusters] on a vehicle,” says Paulo Lozano, a professor in MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. He adds that a small satellite outfitted with several microthrusters could “not only move to change its orbit, but do other interesting things — like turn and roll.” MIT-developed ‘microthrusters’ could propel small satellites - MIT News Office. As small as a penny, these thrusters run on jets of ion beams.

“These are very fine particles, not big flakes,” says Kerri Cahoy, the Boeing Career Development Assistant Professor of MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics.  Researchers calculate size of particles in Martian clouds of CO2 snow. Mars’ carbon dioxide ‘snowflakes’ are about the size of red blood cells.

clusters.summary: The MIT Community Service Fund (CSF) was established in 1968 by a vote of the faculty to provide financial assistance to support MIT students, faculty, and s... “'The world needs students with an #MIT education”: President L. Rafael Reif yesterday welcomed the Class of 2017 to the Institute. Learn more about President Reif at http://president.mit.edu/ Homepage | MIT's Office of the President. Those are some themes of the the final report, released today, of the Institute-Wide Task Force on the Future of MIT Education, convened 18 months ago by President L. Rafael Reif to envision the MIT of 2020 and beyond. In addition to marking the beginning of L. Rafael Reif to envision the MIT of 2020 and beyond. The report's release “marks the beginning of an exciting new period of educational experimentation at MIT,” Reif said. MIT is a community of people eager to solve hard problems in service to the nation and the world. Thanks to our students, faculty, staff and network of 100,000 alumni around the globe, the Institute hums with bold ideas and inspired solutions. We invite you to join us in the work.

In an article for POLITICO, Professor Sanjay Sarma calls attention to the security of the Internet of Things, writing, “if leaders don’t think this through, and don’t create a framework for it to succeed, there’s a real chance that the full potential of the Internet of Things could be compromised.” Read more: http://mitne.ws/1Hxtqy7. I helped invent the Internet of Things. Here’s why I’m worried about how secure it is. I'm a mechanical engineering professor at MIT, and 17 years ago, with my colleagues David Brock, Kevin Ashton and Sunny Siu, I helped launch the research effort that laid some of the groundwork for the Internet of Things. As you might imagine, my life is pretty connected.

#tbt: Did you know that MIT played a critical role in the development of penicillin? 58 years ago this month, one MIT chemist took on penicillin, and won. It was organic chemistry's Manhattan Project: two governments, nearly 40 laboratories, 1,000 chemists, all in the midst of the Second World War, all searching together for a way to synthesize penicillin from scratch.
