In advance of next week's #TechReunions, a Class of 1896 reunion on the beach. #tbt

More on upcoming MIT Alumni Association reunions: http://mitsha.re/1po2J4E 

(Photo courtesy of MIT Museum) Timeline Photos.
In honor of MIT alumni who gave their lives in service to our country, MIT's Lobby 10 has been renamed "Memorial Lobby". Read the full story: http://mitne.ws/1vNKbMB #MemorialDay. Timeline Photos.

An ad for the 1930 class ring featuring MIT's new mascot, the beaver. #tbt #MIT2014 #throwbackthursday 

(Image courtesy of the MIT Museum) Timeline Photos.

Happy #NationalMaritimeDay! The Francis Russell Hart Nautical Collections are among the oldest and most extensive archives of nautical technology in the USA. The collections date from the 16th century to recent cutting-edge technologies. http://mitsha.re/1lQZQEa

(Photo: Stephanie Leishman) Timeline Photos.

Happy International #MuseumDay! The MIT Museum recently opened a new exhibit, “Daguerre’s American Legacy: Photographic Portraits (1840-1900) from the Wm. B. Becker Collection,” which runs through Jan. 4. More: http://mitsha.re/1kOPLab

Additional info on the MIT Museum: http://web.mit.edu/museum/
Learn about International Museum Day - ICOM: http://mitne.ws/1mwWg4C. Timeline Photos.

Happy Astronomy Day! To celebrate, watch the universe evolve over 13.8 billion years in this incredible new simulation by prof. Mark Vogelsberger & colleagues. http://mitsha.re/1fQLt4I. Timeline Photos.

Finishing touches on the MIT Chapel, which was dedicated 59 years ago today. More: http://mitsha.re/1kSauZt

#MIThistory #throwbackthursday #tbt. Timeline Photos.

May the 4th be with you! MIT physicists recently announced the creation of a new photonics system that works like a real-life light saber: http://mitsha.re/1iXcDqf  

(Photo: Pascal/Flickr) #StarWarsDay. Timeline Photos.

WGBH-TV debuted 59 years ago this week from its original broadcast studio on the MIT campus. In the 1950s and 60s, MIT and WGBH jointly produced "MIT Science Reporter," a pioneering show asking scientists and engineers to explain their work to a general audience. More: http://museum.mit.edu/150/34

Watch "MIT Science Reporter" videos: http://mitsha.re/1iJTPuz #tbt #throwbackthursday #scicomm. Timeline Photos.

New work by MIT's Anna Frebel on the faintest galaxy ever detected reveals surprising new facts about the universe’s early evolution. More: http://mitsha.re/1fwqGnl  

(Photo courtesy of Anna Frebel) Timeline Photos.

MIT's Joan Jonas, pictured here during a performance of her work "The Shape and the Scent of the Feel of Things," has been selected to represent the US at the Venice Biennale. Read more: http://mitsha.re/1ix9aP5 (Photo: Paula Court) Timeline Photos.

MIT spinout Cambrian Innovation is using microbes to treat and create power from wastewater — and significantly reduce CO2 emissions in the process. http://mitsha.re/1fbdX9j  

(Image courtesy of Cambrian Innovation) #sustainability #startups #MIT. Timeline Photos.

45 years ago today, the legendary #JanisJoplin rocked #MIT. Front page of The Tech covering her performance: http://mitne.ws/1rtSGrg. 45 Years Ago: Janis Joplin Plays MIT in a Time of National Protest - 100.7 WZLX. In a time of war, Janis Joplin and her music was a symbol of peace. She put that on display at a show at MIT, on the same day 500 students marched on the Boston Common in protest against the Vietnam War.

A program led by MIT students teaches girls to love #dancing, #math, and #science, all at the same time. http://mitsha.re/1icSfMu

Watch a news clip about the program: http://mitsha.re/1pyg3El
Connect with SHINE: http://www.shineforgirls.org

(Photo courtesy of Kirin Sinha) #STEAM #STEM #MIT. Timeline Photos.

A new study finds hundreds of subpopulations of a microbial species coexist in each drop of seawater. More: http://mitsha.re/1mEtbU0

(Image: Carly Sanker/MIT) #oceans #genetics #MIT. Timeline Photos.
Try your hand at the MIT entrance exam from 1876. #tbt http://mitsha.re/P0NP4e. Timeline Photos.

The flick of a hand brings to life a seemingly inanimate object made with >1,000 motors. The latest in #interactive furniture, from MIT's Tangible Media Group. MIT Unveils The Shapeshifting Furniture Of The Future. The Transform, from MIT's Tangible Media Group, changes shape depending upon how users interact with it. Imagine a chair that could transform from an...

It's Campus Preview Weekend! Yesterday, in addition to a carnival, "burger bonanza," and a cappella, students enjoyed ice cream made with liquid nitrogen. Follow @MITCPW on Instagram for more photos: http://mitsha.re/1gSe6IL #CPW2014. Timeline Photos.

Happy birthday, #MIT! The Institute was founded on April 10, 1861 — two days before the start of the Civil War. William Barton Rogers (pictured) was the driving force behind MIT's establishment; in addition to conceiving plans for the Institute, he went on to become MIT's first President. More: http://mitne.ws/1heBCo9 #throwbackthursday #tbt #mithistory. Timeline Photos.
Happy International Beaver Day! http://mitsha.re/1h9dl2N #beaversrule. Timeline Photos.
Guess where on campus you'd find this famous nose. Also, whose nose is it? #guesswhere #guesswho #MIT. Timeline Photos.
Yummm. MIT #entrepreneurs Wei Wu MBA ’15 and Jamison Go SM ’15 have been printing cupcakes! http://mitsha.re/1gtxcod (Photo courtesy of 3Delicious) Timeline Photos.
In celebration of National Poetry month, a poem by Alexandra de Rosa '13. #poetry #spring Read more poems: http://mitsha.re/ObSDDx. Timeline Photos.

Giddy physicists including #MIT’s Alan Guth and Andrei Linde of Stanford University packed an MIT auditorium this week to celebrate one of the field’s biggest breakthroughs: the first direct evidence of what happened in the fraction of a second after the #BigBang. Afterward, Guth spoke with MIT News about the meaning of the discovery. More: http://mitne.ws/1piVh6t. Timeline Photos.
Novel MIT MechE design for #WorldWaterDay: How to filter water using little more than a tree branch: http://mitne.ws/1eZpEKa. Timeline Photos.
Listen to MIT physicist Alan Guth discuss yesterday's Big Bang breakthrough with NPR's Robin Young from Here and Now: http://mitne.ws/1ehJoMj (Photo courtesy of NPR Here and Now) Timeline Photos.
Photo: "Sunset through the infinite corridor" by @yinren via Instagram. See this and other images on MIT's Instagram account @MITpics: http://mitsha.re/MITpics. Timeline Photos.

Pi Day is just around the corner... What are some fun ways to celebrate? 
#piday #MIT. Timeline Photos.
Pi Day is only days away... Timeline Photos.

This Friday is March 14, also known as Pi Day (3.14). What makes this year extra special is that we are in the 3rd month of the year 2014, which could also be expressed as 3.14. Are you prepared for Pi Day?!  Pi(e) Day at MIT. Because 2018s are happening: http://mitadmissions.org/blogs/entry/there-will-be-pi-day Starring: * Allan K. '17 * Ana V. '15 * Anna H. '14 * Ceri R. '16 * Co...

MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference underscores teams’ interest in #statistics. More: http://mitne.ws/1pWsQyj

(Image: Christine Daniloff, MIT) Timeline Photos.
Happy Birthday, Nicolaus Copernicus! You knew the sun was at the center and you contributed to the scientific revolution. Here's to you. #happybirthday. Timeline Photos.

New working papers on #MOOCs challenge common misconceptions, offer surprising insights about how students engage. More: http://mitne.ws/1eQ7YBt

(Image courtesy of Andrew Ho and Isaac Chuang) Timeline Photos.
Today we celebrate Tim the Beaver’s 100th birthday! Happy birthday, Tim. Learn about the history of MIT's mascot: http://mitsha.re/TimBeaver100. Timeline Photos.

Tim is turning 100 this Friday! 

Read the MIT Alumni Association's interview of Tim the Beaver: http://mitsha.re/1ajP2II. Tim the Beaver: An Exclusive Interview. MIT’s mascot turns 100 in January and crouched down for a tell-all interview with Slice of MIT.
As we ring in 2014, a look back at some of the best stories from #MIT in 2013! http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0. Timeline Photos.

Happy Holidays from all of us at #MIT! 

(Image: Christine Daniloff) Timeline Photos.
Concepts familiar from grade-school algebra have broad ramifications in #computerscience. More: http://mitne.ws/1d5KzeF. Timeline Photos.
Happy Thanksgiving from all of us at #MIT! Tell us: what #technology are you most #thankful for this year?

Researchers find that huge craters on the near side of the #moon may not tell the whole story about the intensity of #asteroid impacts about 4.1 billion years ago. More:  http://mitne.ws/1baxrpu (Image: Sean Smith/NASA) #space. Timeline Photos.

"I want to serve the people who serve." — Laura Lu’s years at #MIT have included cancer research, ROTC leadership, and prosthesis trials — and she aims to put her talents to use one day as a Navy surgeon. http://mitne.ws/1cqvXuc. Timeline Photos.
Scientists have developed a tool that could prove, or disprove, one of the leading theories regarding dark matter. More: http://mitne.ws/17iXR9F. Timeline Photos.
Are you applying or thinking of applying to MIT? Read on!: http://mitadmissions.org/apply.
With U.S. history and constitutional law on his mind, senior Cory Hernandez envisions a society that welcomes all — starting with MIT. Read more: http://mitne.ws/H1wPXE. Timeline Photos.
UROP is calling at http://instagram.com/mitpics. Timeline Photos.
From our http://instagram.com/mitpics: Playing a giant Connect Four at #MIT. Timeline Photos.
From our http://instagram.com/mitpics: A #ThrowbackThursday look at the arrival of the Class of '76 to the #MIT campus in 1972. #TBT. Timeline Photos.

While students at #MIT, Inaki Berenguer MBA ’09 and Andres Blank MBA ’09 created Pixable, an app that uses algorithms to scan a user’s social-media accounts, collect the most relevant photos, and aggregate them in one place. Read about their journey: http://mitne.ws/16RDNrM. Timeline Photos.
Astronaut Franklin Chang-Diaz (Sc.D. 1977) performed three spacewalks in June 2002 outside Endeavour during the STS-111 mission. (Photo: #NASA) #TBT. Timeline Photos.
Can you guess where you can find this sign at MIT? Timeline Photos.

Seen around campus: Photo from our Instagram account (@MITpics) of some very cool-looking equipment used in research that aims to advance carbon-fiber composites. Archived story: http://mitne.ws/12APro5. Timeline Photos.
Photos from across campus taken on June 7, 2013. MIT's 147th Commencement exercises.
A view of Killian Court, site of today's MIT Commencement ceremony, from inside Lobby 10. Watch the live webcast of the celebration: http://mitsha.re/125YcJ9. Timeline Photos.

Video: As we approach MIT's 2013 Commencement celebration, watch five graduating seniors discuss their time at the Institute and what they look forward to in the future. http://youtu.be/R4P9xx9ysTI. Timeline Photos.
With a recently released programming framework, researchers show that a new machine-learning algorithm outperforms its predecessors. Read more: http://mitne.ws/16oTpVO. Timeline Photos.

The entire MIT community is invited today at noon in Killian Court. Come enjoy aero/astro-themed food and entertainment as we thank Dean for Undergraduate Education Daniel Hastings for his leadership and service. Timeline Photos.

Yesterday’s final matchup in the 2.007 Design and Manufacturing contest featured Sophie Seidell, left, who finished second, and winner Aleksya Aguirre. Here, Seidell's robot operates autonomously using preprogrammed commands, while Aguirre awaits the signal to pick up her remote control. (Photo: Tony Pulsone) Timeline Photos.

Information for June graduates from the Registrar. MIT Commencement - Graduates - A message from the Registrar. Congratulations! You have worked hard to reach this point, your graduation from MIT. We want to see each one of you walk across the stage. As you prepare to receive your degree, please keep these things in mind:
Researchers at MIT have found that ionic thrusters may be a far more efficient source of propulsion than conventional jet engines. Read on: http://mitne.ws/10q8q3f. Timeline Photos.
Can you guess where you would find this at MIT? Timeline Photos.

How hard could it be to protect the identity of one unnamed cellphone user in a data set of hundreds of thousands or even millions? According to a new paper, it's more difficult than you might think. Read more: http://mitne.ws/YCOJZh. Timeline Photos.

Researchers at MIT, Columbia University and elsewhere have found strong evidence that volcanic activity did indeed trigger the end-Triassic extinction some 200 million years ago. http://mitne.ws/14as0ET. Timeline Photos.

Whether working on clean water for a Ugandan village or studying concrete reinforced with natural fibers, MIT senior Marisa Simmons is a civil engineer looking out for the world. http://mitne.ws/Ydz1Rp

(Photo courtesy of Marisa Simmons) Timeline Photos.
Class is in session for pi. Timeline Photos.

Big pi on campus! 

(Photo by David Castro/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Congratulations to Professors Shafi Goldwasser and Silvio Micali, who have won the Association for Computing Machinery’s (ACM) A.M. Turing Award for their pioneering work in the fields of cryptography and complexity theory. Read more: http://mitne.ws/YZGzmC

(Photo: Jason Dorfman, CSAIL/MIT) Timeline Photos.

A new technique for solving ‘graph Laplacians’ is drastically simpler than its predecessors, with implications for a huge range of practical problems. Read more http://mitne.ws/12guhi2. Timeline Photos.
Happy Valentine's Day from #MIT. Timeline Photos.
On this Valentine's Day, what could be better than having 600 pounds of chocolate at your disposal? The MIT Laboratory for Chocolate Science is on it: http://mit.tv/11sfK2o. Timeline Photos.

See a slideshow of submitted photos from this weekend's historic snow storm: http://mitsha.re/11BiFpl (including a special guest at the student-organized snowball fight on Killian Court) Timeline Photos.

The peaks of the Himalayas are a modern remnant of massive tectonic forces that fused India with Asia tens of millions of years ago. Previous estimates have suggested this collision occurred about 50 million years ago. Now MIT researchers have found that this dramatic tectonic collision occurred 10 million years later than previously thought. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/WMTwn6

(Photo: Pierre Bouilhol) Timeline Photos.
Do you know what the "Königsberg bridge problem" has to do with the topic of graphs? Read on: http://mitne.ws/Xzreti. Timeline Photos.
You know we love the numbers at MIT, so how could we stop at just one recognition! Timeline Photos.
Happy 12/12/12 12:12 everyone! Timeline Photos.
Happy Thanksgiving to all from the MIT family. What are you thankful for this year?

Making ‘nanospinning’ practical: Nanofibers have a dizzying range of possible applications, but they’ve been prohibitively expensive to make. MIT researchers hope to change that. Read more at http://mitne.ws/USRoeD. Timeline Photos.
Instead of Guess Where this week, let's go with #guesswhy! MIT Mascot Tim the Beaver is in Lobby 10 right now. Any clue what he's there for? Timeline Photos.

Tiny pores in graphene could give rise to membranes; may filter water or separate biological samples.

Read more at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/graphene-pores-and-membranes-1023.html. Timeline Photos.

New low-cost, durable carbon nanotube sensors can be etched with mechanical pencils.

Read more at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/drawing-with-a-carbon-nanotube-pencil-1009.html. Timeline Photos.

MIT Sloan marketing professor Catherine Tucker analyzes the boundaries of privacy in a connected world.

Read more about her work at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/faculty-profile-tucker-sloan-1002.html. Timeline Photos.
New banners hanging in Lobby 7 for inauguration tout the theme: One Community, Together in Service. Timeline Photos.
And we're back! Hope everyone is having a great first day of classes! #MIT. Timeline Photos.
What makes these shapes so special? http://mitne.ws/MRp7lf. Timeline Photos.

View highlights of all the social media buzz from Friday on Storify. MIT Commencement 2012. MIT's 146th Commencement Exercises took place on Friday, June 8, 2012 in Killian Court. Salman Khan '98 MEng '98, founder and executive director of the Khan Academy, was the guest speaker. Congratulations to the 939 undergraduates and 1,545 graduate students who received diplomas.

We're posting images form throughout the day at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/commencement-day-0608.html. Check back frequently for updates! Slideshow: MIT's 146th Commencement - MIT News Office.
Live now: The 146th Commencement pre-show. Ceremony begins in one hour. MIT Commencement: Doctoral Hooding - Webcast.

We are just a couple hours from the start of MIT's 146th Commencement ceremonies. Follow the action live on Twitter @MITcommencement. Send well wishes and Commencement day stories with the hashtag #MIT2012.
Watch live: The MIT doctoral hooding ceremony (begins at 11:30 a.m.) — http://mitne.ws/Nk9WQ1. MIT Commencement: Doctoral Hooding - Webcast.

What does it take to put on MIT's 146th Commencement ceremonies, which take place this Friday? #MIT2012. Engineering Commencement - MIT News Office. Innovations and traditions evolve with the history of MIT graduation.
The first in our 'Guess where?' series. Do you know where on campus this image was taken? Hint: It has a twitter account. Instagram.

Infinitely many MIT students walk into a café.

Armando: “I’ll have a 24-oz. dark roast.”
Brian: “I’ll have a 12-oz. dark roast.”
Celia: “I’ll have a 6-oz. dark roast, and we have more friends coming.”

The barista makes two 24-oz. coffees and hands them to the group.

Brian: “Are you kidding me? How is this going to be enough for everyone?
Barista: “Come on, guys. Know your limits.”

Artwork: "Positronium" by Jens Zorn, donated to the MIT Department of Physics on this date in 2007 to honor the 1951 discovery of positronium by the late physicist and MIT professor Martin Deutsch. Positronium is a system containing an electron and its anti-particle, a positron.

More on MIT's love of Archimedes: recreating his "death ray." http://mitsha.re/1qHv6ba #onlyatMIT

Photo: Stephanie Leishman/MIT. Timeline Photos.

#MIThistory: Why is there a "J" sign on MIT Building 44? In 1974, MIT Professor Samuel C. C. Ting discovered a new kind of heavy elementary particle. Since the last meson was named the K particle, Ting named the new one the J particle. Ting won the 1976 Nobel Prize for this discovery, and gave his acceptance speech in Chinese, the first Nobel laureate to do so.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/jparticle
http://mitsha.re/nobel-jparticle

(Photo: Stephanie Leishman/MIT) Timeline Photos.
¡Feliz Cinco de Mayo! A mariachi band serenaded students in Stratton earlier this afternoon. Photo: Stephanie Hatch Leishman. Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary:
MIT students reflect on the magic of making in a new video from MIT Mechanical Engineering. #eweek2017 Learn more: http://mitsha.re/sTZv309kazM

Video: MIT Mechanical Engineering. Researchers at MIT Mechanical Engineering have contributed to a major new study of the ocean's giant underwater "internal waves." The brainchild of MIT mechanical engineer Kripa Varanasi and his students, a new coating called LiquiGlide is set to make the transition from the laboratory to consumer and industrial markets. A new interface from MIT Mechanical Engineering uses human reflexes to keep a bipedal robot balanced.
messages: When not designing mobility-enhancing assistive technologies as a senior in MIT Mechanical Engineering, Matthew Cavuto spends time ballroom dancing and competing with the MIT fencing team. Matthew Cavuto: Getting a leg up on engineering. MIT senior will use Marshall Scholarship to work on devices that enhance mobility for the disabled.

Take a peek inside an MIT class with the feel and vibe of a hardware startup. The creativity, deadlines, teamwork, and passion are all here — and very real. #eweek2017 Learn more: http://mitsha.re/sTZv309kazM

Video: MIT Mechanical Engineering. Building Confidence at MIT.

Footwear developed at MIT converts human walking energy into portable electric power. #eweek2017

Video: MIT Mechanical Engineering. Energy harvesting footwear.

When not designing assistive technologies as a senior in MIT Mechanical Engineering, Matthew Cavuto spends time ballroom dancing and competing with the MIT fencing team. Matthew Cavuto: Getting a leg up on engineering. MIT senior will use Marshall Scholarship to work on devices that enhance mobility for the disabled.

The brainchild of MIT mechanical engineer Kripa Varanasi and his students, a new coating called LiquiGlide is set to make the transition from the laboratory to consumer and industrial markets. Kripa Varanasi: Innovating at interfaces. MIT engineer’s research on surfaces is improving everything from power plants to ketchup bottles.

"I want to create a robotic first responder that can potentially do more than a human and help in our lives." —Sangbae Kim of MIT Mechanical Engineering . Taking a leap in bioinspired robotics. Mechanical engineer Sangbae Kim builds animal-like machines for use in disaster response.

MIT students reflect on the magic of making in a new video from MIT Mechanical Engineering. Mind and Hand: The Magic of Making at MIT. The magic of making is told through the personal stories of MIT students, whose passion runs deep and from an early age.

In which MIT Mechanical Engineering Professor John Leonard uses math to exonerate the New England Patriots... #deflategate. Science says Patriots never tampered footballs. As Tom Brady returns to the field, the science shows that he and the Patriots did nothing wrong.

Introducing a more efficient way to monitor and maintain city streetlights, from MIT Mechanical Engineering: Drive-by monitoring for urban streetlights. System developed at MIT could automate inspection for efficiency and maintenance issues.

“What I saw in mechanical engineering was the ability to building something that integrates across different disciplines.” Rohit Karnik seeks sustainable solutions through nanotechnology. Engineer’s designs may help purify water, diagnose disease in remote regions of world.
MIT Mechanical Engineering is making a better world with a new spray that could drastically reduce pesticide runoff. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/OEyz303JBbM #MITBetterWorld. Making Droplets Stick.

Congrats to MIT Mechanical Engineering for their New England Emmy Award! 

Watch the winning film: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=36_pUKGOC-4 Department of Mechanical Engineering wins a New England Emmy Award for “Hope Regenerated”. Emmy-winning video chronicles Professor Ioannis Yannas’ discovery of organ regeneration in the 1970s.

“I thought everyone at MIT would be about science all the time. Instead I found strong humanities here and a rich intellectual culture.” —Marie Moudio, senior in MIT Mechanical Engineering. Finding wonderland. Senior Marie Elimbi Moudio enters a “weird place” and discovers a world of possibility.
A 3-D printing course from the MIT Mechanical Engineering teaches students to print glass and soft-serve 🍦 http://mitsha.re/DU9q3006RVj. media.giphy.com.

Researchers in MIT Mechanical Engineering have designed a system to generate electricity from coal with much greater efficiency — possibly reaching as much as twice the efficiency of today’s conventional coal plants. Hybrid system could cut coal-plant emissions in half. Combining gasification with fuel-cell technology could boost efficiency of coal-powered plants.
A new prediction tool from MIT Mechanical Engineering gives 2-3 minutes' warning of incoming rogue waves. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/YKvhy. media.giphy.com.
A microfluidic device from MIT Mechanical Engineering may speed up genetic engineering. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/YwIbU. media.giphy.com.

“I was the child that broke everything because I wanted to put it back together and see how it worked.” –Larissa Senatus '16, MIT Mechanical Engineering and Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program. Larissa Senatus learns about the world by doing. Mechanical engineering major hopes to bring hands-on learning opportunities home to Haiti.

Happy #NationalCoffeeDay! Here's MIT Mechanical Engineering's HERMES robot pouring a cuppa.

More on the bot's human-like reflexes: http://mitsha.re/SNPNj

Image: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Timeline Photos.

A new interface from MIT Mechanical Engineering uses human reflexes to keep a bipedal robot balanced. A bipedal robot with human reflexes. New human-machine interface keeps robot balanced, with human reflexes.

Engineers in MIT Mechanical Engineering have devised a way to give robots a more nimble grip. Watch: http://mitsha.re/QtAu7. Giving robots a more nimble grasp. Engineers use the environment to give simple robotic grippers more dexterity.

Promising new development from MIT Mechanical Engineering: A cheap prosthetic knee that mimics normal walking motion. A cheaper, high-performance prosthetic knee. Researchers design cheap prosthetic knee that mimics normal walking motion.

Meet MIT Mechanical Engineering student Natasha Wright, who is designing a cost-effective system to desalinate water!  #womeninSTEM. Powering desalination with the sun. PhD student Natasha Wright makes water safe to drink for rural, off-grid Indian villages.

Researchers at MIT Mechanical Engineering have contributed to a major new study of the ocean's giant underwater "internal waves." Researchers unravel secrets of hidden waves. Region of world’s strongest “internal waves” is analyzed in detail; work could help refine climate models.

After studying hundreds of centuries-old violins, acousticians and fluid dynamicists at MIT Mechanical Engineering have identified key design features that boost violins’ acoustic power. Power efficiency in the violin. New study identifies key design features that boost violins’ acoustic power.

A new study from MIT Mechanical Engineering explains the familiar post-rain smell known as petrichor. Rainfall can release aerosols, study finds. High-speed imaging captures raindrops releasing clouds of aerosols on impact.

A new model from MIT Mechanical Engineering explains unusual behavior in a variant of quicksand: http://mitne.ws/1wOIiwP 

Image: Martin Van Heckek/Leiden. Timeline Photos.

For Maria Yang, associate professor in MIT Mechanical Engineering,  innovation first manifests itself in early-stage design. Visual Thinking for Engineers. Professor Maria Yang has discovered valuable strategies and techniques for designing both consumer products and complex engineering systems, partnering with ...

What's it like living on the bottom of the ocean for 15 days? Grace Young '14 explains in a new video from MIT Mechanical Engineering. Living Undersea: High-speed video of marine life. Just returning from fifteen days living undersea as part of Fabien Cousteau's Mission 31 project, mechanical and ocean engineering alumna Grace Young '14 ref...

Get a better grasp with extra robotic fingers from MIT Mechanical Engineering: http://mitne.ws/1niOzkV  

Photo: Melanie Gonick/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Research from Kripa Varanasi and colleagues in MIT Mechanical Engineering made it into a recent "Dustin" comic strip! Learn about the real LiquiGlide: http://mitne.ws/1ly6tZU 

More comics by Steve Kelley & Jeff Parker: http://dustincomics.com. Timeline Photos.

"It is one of those iconic classes that those who take it never forget, an example of #engineering #education at its finest — and most fun.” http://mitne.ws/1gQFtqA. 2.009: An Iconic MIT Engineering Class. Taught by award-winning professor David Wallace, 2.009: Product Engineering Processes is a rigorous capstone class for undergraduates in the Mechanical Engin...

MIT Mechanical Engineering researchers design a microfluidic platform to see how #cancer cells invade specific #organs. More: http://mitne.ws/1eEQjPl

(Photo: Jessie Jeon) Timeline Photos.

New MIT Mechanical Engineering analysis of endometriosis patients could help scientists develop better #treatments and more revealing diagnoses. More: http://mitne.ws/1eEQ32S

(Image: Wikipedia) Timeline Photos.

New approach developed at MIT Mechanical Engineering could generate #power from #sunlight efficiently and on demand. More: http://mitne.ws/1eQzm2f

(Photo: John Freidah) Timeline Photos.
New #laser doping method from MIT Mechanical Engineering could enable new infrared #imaging systems. More: http://mitne.ws/Kw3KpT. Timeline Photos.
MIT Mechanical Engineering professor David Gordon Wilson was an early proponent of the concept of energy-use fees to curb carbon emissions. More: http://mitne.ws/1goOxDT. Timeline Photos.
Mechanical engineering research on display at the Hart Nautical Gallery in Building 5 at #MIT. #science #tech. Timeline Photos.

Throughout her time at MIT, mechanical engineering senior Madeline Salazar has always kept her East Los Angeles neighborhood close to her heart and mind. “I feel there’s a need for you to go back and help your community, the people who have gone through the same things as you,” she says. Find out more about her studies and innovations: http://mitne.ws/ZpaSs0. Timeline Photos.

MIT mechanical engineering students John Queeney and Quantum Wei recently built a 3D printer using open-source designs and instructions. Their printer – which took about 200 man-hours to build – uses ABS plastic.  One of the students' coolest builds was a miniature version of MIT's iconic Great Dome. Check it out! (Photos courtesy of John Queeney and Quantum Wei.) 3D-printing MIT's Great Dome.

Sanjay Sarma appointed as MIT’s first director of digital learning — Mechanical engineering professor will shepherd efforts to integrate elements of online education into traditional MIT courses. http://mitne.ws/URkJjR. Timeline Photos.

“The real innovation is enabling the car to share [control] with you,” says Sterling Anderson, a PhD student in MIT Mechanical Engineering. “If you want to drive, it’ll just … make sure you don’t hit anything.” Mechanical engineers develop an ‘intelligent co-pilot’ for cars - MIT News Office. Semiautonomous system takes the wheel to keep drivers safe.

Researchers at MIT Mechanical Engineering have found that relatively simple, microscale roughening of a surface can dramatically enhance its transfer of heat.  Better surfaces could help dissipate heat. Heat transfer in everything from computer chips to powerplants could be improved through new analysis of surface textures.

http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0 

(Photo of MIT research associate Luiz Godoy by M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/MosrEQ

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1ftpWZa

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1bbflQA (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos. http://mitne.ws/143WYve (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.
messages:
Experience the captured moments of Commencement day here: http://mitsha.re/SikW3010oGe

Photo: M. Scott Brauer. Timeline Photos.

Meet Kristala Jones Prather, a professor in MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) who is coaxing bacteria to develop new, useful substances: http://mitsha.re/TlKOk #AdaLovelaceDay

Photo: M. Scott Brauer. Timeline Photos.

Tonio Buonassisi, associate professor of mechanical engineering at MIT, is teaming up with Brazilian researchers to advance solar energy technologies, with support from the MIT-Brazil Program Seed Fund. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/1CR9PX6

Photo: M. Scott Brauer. Timeline Photos.

"The kinetochore is the most fascinating structure in the cell. I fell in love with it as a machine and structure to look at.” Iain Cheeseman of the MIT Department of Biology explores the structures that control cell division: http://mitne.ws/10vdHLN

Photo: M. Scott Brauer. Timeline Photos.

Leading health care economist Jonathan Gruber weighs in on a proposed cost-benefit analysis of smoking. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1112Ppn

Photo: M. Scott Brauer. Timeline Photos.

A new #robotic #fish developed by researchers from MIT EECS Department and CSAIL - MIT can change direction almost as rapidly as a real fish. More: http://mitne.ws/1ftpWZa

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Physics Professor Robert Simcoe peers deep into the universe’s past to identify the first #stars. More: http://mitne.ws/MosrEQ

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

After working in the private sector, Kristala Jones Prather returned to academia and launched her own lab at #MIT, where she designs new ways to #engineer #bacteria to synthesize useful chemical compounds such as #biofuels. More: http://mitne.ws/1bbflQA (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.
A simple scheme for self-assembling #robots: Small cubes self‑propel, leap onto each other, and snap together to form modular robots. http://mitne.ws/18B7tJP (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Associate Professor Ruben Juanes’ studies of how fluids move underground could help with cleaner #energy production and water supplies. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/1eGaz5b (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

“Hopefully the technologies we are developing will help the research community to discover therapeutics for various neurological diseases." - MIT Associate Professor Mehmet Fatih Yanik. More: http://mitne.ws/14ifUeH #science (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

“That’s the classic problem I’m most interested in: How do cells regulate their own behavior?” - Michael Laub, #MIT associate professor of #biology. More #science at:http://mitne.ws/1bLryyU (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Associate Professor Pierre Lermusiaux leads an MIT group that develops methods to better predict ocean behavior for a wide range of applications. See more about his research: http://mitne.ws/1a3Xkq1 (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Innovations by Laura Popa (left) and Dana Weinstein at MIT could enable more efficient use of radio spectrum, changing the game for wireless devices. http://mitne.ws/11ErGih (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers have found a way to make steel with zero greenhouse-gas emissions, and cheaply. http://mitne.ws/143WYve (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Best of the Week: Stories on exciting research advances against cancer and the dengue virus, plus a description of a new approach that uses folded DNA to control the nanostructure of inorganic materials. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0 

(Photo of MIT research associate Luiz Godoy by M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

MIT research associate Luiz Godoy and his colleagues have discovered a means of weakening melanoma cells by cutting off their supply of nitric oxide. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/14RAgtI

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

The search for solar systems like our own: Associate Professor Josh Winn’s hunt for exoplanets may someday reveal habitable, Earth-like worlds. Find out more about his work: http://mitne.ws/YmWjnQ 

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Institute Professor Phillip Sharp, co-founder of biotech giant Biogen Idec, talks about the factors that have made the Kendall Square area — which is adjacent to MIT — a hotbed of innovation. http://mitne.ws/YRjNAP 

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Best of the Week: A 'cheetah' bot that could propel advances in robotics, and research that quantifies the speed of technological change. http://mitne.ws/vKR7Y0 

(Photos: M. Scott Brauer; Wikipedia/Casey Fleser) Timeline Photos.

MIT's Biomimetic Robotics Lab presents its "cheetah" robot, a 70-pound bot that may soon outpace its animal counterparts in running efficiency: Check it out and see what it can do:  http://mitne.ws/13JzUEI 

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

“Doing natural experiments requires the methodological tools, but that needs to be combined with a deep knowledge of the subject matter." — MIT Associate Professor Jens Hainmueller looks for experiments to answer tough political questions. http://mitne.ws/13FepVB MIT Political Science (Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Research conducted by Laura Schulz, an associate professor of brain and cognitive sciences at MIT, reveals that children use many of the same strategies employed in the scientific method to learn about the world around them. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/12kNnTb

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

MIT Professor Jonathan Gruber examines the online health-insurance exchanges that will operate in the United States as part of the federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. http://mitne.ws/Ua1kR2 

(Photo: M. Scott Brauer) Timeline Photos.

Full story: http://mitne.ws/1nn7zdV

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1gDHtBh

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/19a1Ofp

messages:
A new report from the MIT Sloan School of Management sizes up MIT’s impressive global entrepreneurial impact: http://mitsha.re/VGqxK 

Image courtesy of the researchers. Timeline Photos.

Rocket science FTW! The MIT Rocket Team recently took 1st place at the Intercollegiate Rocket Engineering Competition in Utah. Full story: http://bit.ly/1g6jsYw  

Photo courtesy of the MIT Rocket Team. Timeline Photos.
Bringing the power of #data to the people: MIT is launching a new Institute for Data, Systems, and Society. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1Clhfwr. Timeline Photos.
Drive-by imaging from MIT spinoff Essess, Inc. can quickly track energy leaks in homes and buildings. Full story: http://mitne.ws/17dOWHn. Timeline Photos.

Researchers in the MIT Department of Biological Engineering have created a new computer model that allows them to design the most complex 3-D DNA shapes ever produced. Watch: http://mitne.ws/1yOHkow  

Image courtesy of the researchers. Timeline Photos.

Congrats! Elliot Akama-Garren ’15, Anisha Gururaj ’15, and Noam Angrist ’13 are among the 32 Americans announced yesterday as 2015 Rhodes Scholars! This year’s three Rhodes Scholars from MIT tie the Institute’s 2009 record for the most recipients in a single year. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1uwriJP. Timeline Photos.

Hundreds recently attended the MIT-China Innovation and Entrepreneurship Forum, fostering collaboration between U.S. and Chinese entrepreneurs. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1uQEhuH 

Photo courtesy of MIT-CHIEF. Timeline Photos.

New circuit design could unlock the power of experimental superconducting computer chips. Full story: mitne.ws/1zf1rij  

Photo: Adam N. McCaughan. Timeline Photos.
MIT startup ProtoPrint Solutions connects India's garbage dumps to 3-D design. Full story: http://mitsha.re/101JuUX. Timeline Photos.

Glowing nanoparticles could provide a new tool for probing the inner workings of cells. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1uFXj6B

Image courtesy of the researchers. Timeline Photos.
Using NASA's NuSTAR telescopes, astronomers have found the brightest pulsar ever detected, with the energy of 10 million suns. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1pQXfeQ. Timeline Photos.

From Afghanistan to Cambridge, MIT System Design and Management grad student Jillian Wisniewski makes systems for better intelligence. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1rWPmHZ 

Photo (with husband Isaac) courtesy of Jillian Wisniewski. Timeline Photos.

Resistance is futile: Two new MIT technologies could enable novel strategies for combating drug-resistant bacteria. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1pookok 

Photo: Janice Haney Carr/CDC. Timeline Photos.

A novel liquid metal battery from Prof. Donald Sadoway + colleagues could make wind and solar energy more competitive. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1ponUhZ

Photo: Felice Frankel. Timeline Photos.

Exciting physics news: The MIT-led Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer particle detector on the International Space Station has detected positrons that hint at the origin of #darkmatter. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1BS6Md5. Timeline Photos.

Want to hide like an octopus or squid? Engineers at MIT have developed new materials that reproduce cephalopods’ ability to quickly change colors and textures. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1wo5mnJ  

Images courtesy of the researchers. Timeline Photos.

Professor Sangeeta Bhatia, who combines clinical and engineering perspectives to tackle health challenges with tiny medical devices, has won the $500,000 Lemelson-MIT Prize. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1rAqXoJ

Photo courtesy of the Lemelson-MIT Program. Timeline Photos.

All too often, patients receive the wrong medications by mistake. Now, MIT spinoff Mint Solutions offers a scanning system that ensures patients get the right pills. Full story: http://mitne.ws/VSO0C4

Illustration: Mint Solutions. Timeline Photos.

Engineers at MIT have created tissue scaffolds to help the body grow new bone. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1uPyWEC 

Image courtesy of Nasim Hyder and Nisarg J. Shah. Timeline Photos.

A new algorithm lets delivery drones monitor their own health during long missions. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1ogzFWZ  

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT (Drone photos courtesy of the researchers.) Timeline Photos.

MIT is going to Mars! Yesterday, NASA announced that an MIT-developed instrument called MOXIE will be one of seven payloads on the upcoming Mars 2020 mission to the Red Planet. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1zArAoj. Timeline Photos.

A new study led by MIT Department of Biological Engineering associate professor Eric Alm has found that bacteria in the human digestive tract change with diet and other lifestyle factors. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1pOVcIL. Timeline Photos.

The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard today announced a $650 million commitment to the Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research, with the goal of galvanizing mental illness research. Full story: http://mitne.ws/WAKFJh  

Photo courtesy of the Broad Institute. Timeline Photos.

In the movie Terminator 2 (T2), the shape-shifting T-1000 robot morphs into a liquid state to squeeze through tight spaces or to repair itself when harmed. Now, a phase-changing material developed by MIT researchers could allow even low-cost robots to perform the same feat. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1wlz4bn. Timeline Photos.

Researchers at MIT have discovered that ocean bacteria go through daily routines, too. Full story: http://mitne.ws/VPKXvb  

(Image: Ed DeLong and David Karl) Timeline Photos.

"Maker" education: MIT spinoff NuVu Studio takes kids out of the classroom and lets them invent. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1naVT0y

(Photo: Liz Linder) Timeline Photos.

In what is being called "an enormous breakthrough," fresh evidence from MIT researchers suggests a new particle discovered in 2012 is the Higgs boson. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1j60pIz  

(Image courtesy of Monica Vazquez Acosta/CERN) Timeline Photos.

Engineers at MIT and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory have designed a new nanostructured material that has record stiffness at low density. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1nn7zdV

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

"Her work is a defining example of the value of thinking both big and small to make sense of the complex interplay of life and the environment."  Biologist Sally 'Penny' Chisholm is the newest recipient of MIT's Killian Award, the Institute's highest faculty honor. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1lW8wsT 

(Photo: Richard Howard) Timeline Photos.

A new algorithm may soon let you morph selfies into the style of your favorite photographer. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1jwtagw

(Image courtesy of the researchers and MIT-Adobe 5K dataset) Timeline Photos.

Yesterday, four students with the Lemelson-MIT Program showed off their innovative science projects at the annual White House Science Fair. This year, the event focused on encouraging and highlighting girls and women in #STEM. Full Story: http://mitne.ws/1isIUld. Timeline Photos.

Researchers uncover secret of a ubiquitous pigment’s ability to absorb a broad spectrum of light. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1vLX4a3  

(Image courtesy of Chun-Teh Chen) Timeline Photos.

An MIT balloon carried a #BostonStrong banner into the stratosphere as part of a recent charity competition. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1lKjkf4   

(Image courtesy of the MIT Global Space Balloon team.) Timeline Photos.

High-flying turbine from MIT startup Altaeros Energies captures stronger, steadier winds. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1mviaVP  

(Photo: Altaeros Energies) Timeline Photos.
MIT Media Lab's CityFARM and spinoff Grove are reinventing how we harvest food. Full story: http://mitsha.re/1fwxn8Q. Timeline Photos.
MIT announced today a major new campuswide initiative to promote transformative, cross-disciplinary research relating to the environment. Full story: http://mitsha.re/1kOPfJj. Timeline Photos.

MIT has received a major gift from Mohammed Abdul Latif Jameel '78 aimed at ensuring the world's food and water supply for the 21st century. The gift establishes the Abdul Latif Jameel World Water and Food Security Lab (J-WAFS), spearheading research that will combat world-wide water and food-supply scarcity. Full story: http://mitsha.re/Ro6ubH. Timeline Photos.

"A team of researchers from MIT and more than 2,000 coauthors known only by online handles such as 'crazyman4865,' 'magret,' and 'Riley_Light' on Sunday reported a new map of a neural circuit in the eye that helps detect movement." Full story: http://mitsha.re/1fLQSdB

Connect with EyeWire: https://eyewire.org #citizenscience. Timeline Photos.

The MIT Self-Assembly Lab is building materials that can form structures on their own! Full Story: http://mitne.ws/1hwdxJa  

More on the Self-Assembly Lab: http://www.selfassemblylab.net. Timeline Photos.

Kwami Williams '12 is translating his engineering degree into a life-changing startup in Ghana. Full story: http://mitsha.re/QYjKnl  

More on the multidisciplinary Flexible Engineering Degree program: http://mitsha.re/1hNFlsW. Timeline Photos.
MIT.nano, a new facility focusing on innovation in nanotechnology, will soon rise in the heart of campus. Full story: http://mitsha.re/1m6fBrg. Timeline Photos.
New injectable oxygen-monitoring device could aid #cancer diagnosis and treatment. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1msyHJ6. Timeline Photos.
First-generation senior Salvador Esparza finds roles in the lab, in the dorm, and onstage. Full story: http://mitsha.re/1kuOEwG. Timeline Photos.

Uncovering the secrets behind a marine creature’s defensive armor — one that is exceptionally tough, yet optically clear. Full story: http://mitsha.re/1pu93Ff (Image: Ling Li and James C. Weaver) Timeline Photos.

Sophomore Cimran Virdi is the first MIT women's indoor track and field athlete to win an individual event at NCAAs. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1gKaIFr (Photos: DSPics.com and Lauren Kuntz) Timeline Photos.
MIT MechE "RoboClam" replicates a clam’s ability to burrow into soil while using very little energy. Full story: http://mitne.ws/Qbk2XZ (Photo: Donna Coveney) Timeline Photos.
Wonderful to see Boston Marathon bombing survivor Adrianne Haslet-Davis dance at #TED2014 on a bionic leg developed by #MIT's Hugh Herr. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1j7FHx1. Timeline Photos.

MIT MechE group shows xylem tissue in sapwood can filter #bacteria from contaminated #water. More: http://mitne.ws/1kjaHqn

(Image courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

MIT Mechanical Engineering #robot may speed up drug testing for stroke patients by 70 percent. More: http://mitne.ws/1kyyx4n

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

CSAIL - MIT researchers develop a storage system for #bigdata analytics that can dramatically speed up the time it takes to access #information. More: http://mitne.ws/1eD83Hh

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

MIT Mechanical Engineering researchers develop a slippery coating that could prevent the scaling that fouls #oil wells and #power plants. More: mitne.ws/1hJAVlb

(Image courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

Large-scale tests performed by MIT Mechanical Engineering in the lab and the South China Sea reveal the origins of underwater #waves that can tower hundreds of feet. More: http://mitne.ws/1gDHtBh

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

New approach to use of 2-D carbon material opens up unexpected properties, could unleash new uses. More: http://mitne.ws/1dytTMD

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

New MIT Mechanical Engineering method could lead to near-doubling of heat-transfer #efficiency from power-plant condensers. More: http://mitne.ws/19a1Ofp

(Photo courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.
MIT engineers have transformed bacterial cells into living calculators that can divide, take square roots and more. http://mitne.ws/13lIgh5 (Illustration courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary:
(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/OBPfCA (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/O9BiMs

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1mVa6jJ

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1gliMbe

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
messages:
Good luck to all #BostonMarathon runners! May your feet carry you swiftly through every smoot. 👏

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

...and to all a good night. Happy Christmas to all from MIT!

Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT. giphy.com.

Chemists at MIT have determined how rain cleanses the atmosphere http://mitsha.re/RuQqa

Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Can rain clean the atmosphere? Study explains how rain droplets attract aerosols out of the atmosphere.

Happy Independence Day! 

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Happy birthday to Robert Robinson Taylor, MIT's first black graduate, who was recently honored with a U.S. postage stamp! Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1E9SYeo

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Good luck to all those running in the Boston Marathon! 

Illustration by Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

A new device from engineers at MIT could soon make large biological circuits practical. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1pfyBda  

Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT engineers have transformed the genome of the bacterium E. coli into a long-term storage device for memory. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1xwK60e  

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Got a second? New work from Draper Laboratory + MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics enables portable atomic clocks: http://mitne.ws/1wTAMEr 

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

A new study coauthored by Sara Ellison of MIT Economics finds gender diversity in the workplace can help the bottom line. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1yK4caT

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

MIT researchers have made a breakthrough discovery "of fundamental importance" to the understanding of pancreatic cancer that may allow for much earlier detection of the disease. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1rESOZ3  

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

A detailed quantitative study has found that online classes like those on the edX platform really do work, even among learners with the least preparation. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1vgOvlY

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT #MOOCs. Timeline Photos.

A new book by MIT Economics Professor Peter Temin explains how John Maynard Keynes’ ideas are relevant to today’s global economy. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1ybQM7r 

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Solar-powered desalination from MIT Mechanical Engineering could deliver clean water for off-grid villages in India and elsewhere. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1xxTfsy

Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

An energy win-win: A system proposed by researchers at MIT recycles materials from discarded car batteries into new, long-lasting solar panels that provide emissions-free power. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1o5quIR

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Visualizing big data: A new tool from CSAIL - MIT identifies sources of aberrant results and recomputes visualizations without them. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1rAGtSz

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Seeing is hearing: Researchers at CSAIL - MIT have developed a "visual microphone" that can extract speech from a vibrating potato-chip bag filmed through soundproof glass. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1mf7Qyh 

Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

New research suggests human communication is more like that of other animals than we realize. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1nx4mu2

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Economist David Autor analyzes education’s centrality in Americans' economic outcomes. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1jb8hr6

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

In her new book, MIT's Eugenie Brinkema takes a closer look at how visual cues in film play with our emotions. More: http://mitsha.re/1g84pGU

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
New research reveals some nanoparticles commonly added to consumer products can significantly damage #DNA. Full story: http://mitsha.re/1jtZDXS (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
New algorithm for determining orientation of objects could aid #robots in navigation, scene understanding. Full story: http://mitsha.re/PxxbtG (Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
MIT researchers cure a liver disorder in mice by replacing a mutated gene with a normal one. More: http://mitsha.re/1pu4LxH (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
MIT project democratizes the design of visually rich, interactive websites http://mitne.ws/1hx9Xuu #dataviz (Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

New study from MIT MechE researchers shows that the inner-ear membrane uses tiny pores to mechanically separate sounds. More: http://mitne.ws/OBPfCA (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

New microscopy technique captures 3-D images of cells as they flow through a microfluidic channel. This may help scientists separate stem cells at varying stages of development or distinguish healthy cells from cancerous ones. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1lWakCO (Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

#MIT scientists identify a plasma plume that naturally protects the Earth against solar storms. More: http://mitsha.re/1iqUpyI

(NASA images used in a photo composite by Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics team proposes storing extra #rocket fuel in #space for future missions. More: http://mitne.ws/1mVa6jJ

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

#MIT spinout Meka Robotics, recently acquired by Google, creates ‘sociable’ humanoid #robots that could help advance human-robot interaction. More: http://mitne.ws/1gliMbe

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

New MIT EECS Department CSAIL - MIT strategies for managing the local memory banks known as ‘caches’ could improve #computer chips’ performance while reducing their #energy consumption. More: http://mitne.ws/O9BiMs

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

#MIT startup Viztu Technologies developed commercial #software that generated 3-D models from 2-D photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1gGoSI6

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

New research from MIT Sloan School of Management shows boost for leading-edge and low-profile work in the life sciences happens after authors are honored. More: http://mitne.ws/1f1O9Zq

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

New The Picower Institute for Learning and Memory MIT Brain and Cognitive Sciences study identifies #drug that could improve treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder. More: http://mitne.ws/1b6dxsY

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Happy New Year from all of us at #MIT! 

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

#MIT study that examines how old memories fade away could lead to possible new treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder. More: http://mitne.ws/1eQsVAB (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

"Wi-Vi" system developed at CSAIL - MIT could have possible uses in disaster recovery, personal safety and #gaming. Find out what it's about: http://mitne.ws/128u9f9 (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

In the near future, a buzz in your belt or a pulse from your jacket may give you instructions on how to navigate your surroundings. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/17M5VP0 (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
Researchers are analyzing data from the first edX course for clues to how students learn online. More: http://mitne.ws/116JsrM (Graphic: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

A new algorithm solves a major problem with homomorphic encryption, which promises to make cloud computing perfectly secure. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/19XzlsL (Graphic: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

MIT researchers have examined why innovation thrives in cities, and their findings could have important consequences for urban planning. More: http://mitne.ws/134JqP9 (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.
MIT study shows how we interpret confusing statements in conversations. http://mitne.ws/ZMbTvt  (Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

MIT researchers are developing a new system called DBSeer that should help problems such as the pricing of cloud services and the diagnosis of web application slowdowns. DBSeer's algorithms use machine-learning techniques to build accurate models of performance and resource demands of database-driven applications. http://mitne.ws/13QXhwo

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

What should the United States do to retain foreign talent in the STEM fields? Three MIT experts discuss this and other aspects of the challenges facing foreign-born entrepreneurs under current immigration policy, as well as the implications for the country's economy. http://mitne.ws/YZR4XI

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

A newly released study conducted by MIT scholars highlights ways that manufacturing can spur innovation and economic growth in the United States. http://mitne.ws/13adBI0

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

How language could have evolved: Researchers from MIT, along with a scholar from the University of Tokyo, say the balance of evidence suggests that human language is a grafting of two communication forms: first, the elaborate songs of birds, and second, the more utilitarian, information-bearing types of expression seen in a diversity of other animals. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/Xnb6yc 

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Storing data in individual molecules: Find out more about a new technology that could improve the storage capacity of computer hard drives 1,000‑fold. http://mitne.ws/XYlxa2

Graphic: The new molecules are known as "graphene fragments," because they largely consist of flat sheets of carbon (which are attached to zinc atoms). That makes them easier to align during deposition, which could simplify the manufacture of molecular memories. Credit: Christine Daniloff/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering have designed one of the strongest, lightest materials known. A new study by researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering shifts the focus to the first few days of an epidemic, determining how likely the 40 largest U.S. MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering Professor Dara Entekhabi discusses NASA's mission to study how soil, water, and carbon interact.
messages:
Researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering have designed one of the strongest, lightest materials known. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/IKvk307LqwW

Video: Melanie Gonick/MIT. One of the strongest lightweight materials known.

A new study from the  MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering sheds light on how marine microorganisms self-assemble into communities on particles, and how these dynamics shape particle degradation. Microscale marine interactions may shape critical carbon cycles. New research finds interactions between microorganisms and marine particles may have significant effects on oceanic carbon cycling.

Researchers in MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering are seeking to redesign concrete — the most widely used human-made material in the world — by following nature’s blueprints. Finding a new formula for concrete. Researchers look to bones and shells as blueprints for stronger, more durable concrete.

A new model of sediment flow in coastal vegetation developed by researchers from the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering could restore marine plant life: http://mitne.ws/1FkvC4a. Predicting sediment flow in coastal vegetation. Model could help engineers design erosion-prevention strategies in marshes, wetlands, aquatic forests.
For World Water Day, watch "Research for a Thirsty World," a new video from students in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering: http://mitsha.re/1Om6qTk. Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering Professor Dara Entekhabi discusses NASA's mission to study how soil, water, and carbon interact. Full story: http://newsoffice.mit.edu/2015/3-questions-dara-entekhabi-nasa-smap-satellite-0126

Image courtesy of NASA. 3 Questions: Dara Entekhabi on NASA’s soil-moisture mission. MIT professor is lead scientist on three-year mission to study how soil, water, and carbon interact.

Researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering have found that collagen can produce forces 300 times stronger than those generated by muscles: http://t.co/8zOEB2JJVg

Image courtesy of the researchers. New analysis explains collagen’s force. Experiments and simulations show that adding or removing water makes the material push and pull.

How does #Ebola spread? Lydia Bourouiba of the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering explains what we know. 3 Questions: Lydia Bourouiba on Ebola virus transmission. Research on disease transmission through aerosol droplets raises questions about Ebola’s spread.

Theresa Oehmke, an senior in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, travels the globe in pursuit of her interests at the boundaries between water and land. Her story: http://mitne.ws/1HFSHU1 

Photo: Allegra Boverman. Timeline Photos.

A surprising discovery from the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering and the Weizmann Institute of Science: Corals are not passive as once believed; rather, they are active engineers of their own environment. http://mitne.ws/1w2MY3C

Photo courtesy of the researchers. Timeline Photos.

In surprising new discovery, MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering scientists show that #bacteria is more likely to adhere to tube walls when #water is moving. More: http://mitne.ws/1mCT2yS

(Image courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering & MIT Mechanical Engineering researchers develop first detailed model for a 3-D strand of curly #hair. More: http://mitne.ws/1guno0r

(Illustration: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics & MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering study shows that network carriers receive more complaints than cheaper #airlines, regardless of actual service quality. More: http://mitne.ws/Mzp8LO. Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering  study shows no correlation between a manufacturer’s total expenditure with a supplier and the cost of a #supply disruption. More: http://mitne.ws/1kPe9rq. Timeline Photos.

Homing in on stressed #coral: Researchers from MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering find that sulfurous chemical known as ‘smell of the sea’ serves as clarion call for coral pathogens. More: http://mitne.ws/1dukWEq. Timeline Photos.

Congratulations! MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering. Congratulations to the MIT Steel Bridge team for winning first place in economy and second place overall at the national competition held May 31-June 1 at the University of Washington in Seattle. (L to R) Alexis Ludena, Leonidia Garbis, Pierre Ghisbain, Alex McCarthy, Maria Tou, Grant Iwamoto, Nicky Soane, Sharone Small, Dagin Faulkner, and Matt Pires.
Take a look inside MIT's CEE department. Department snapshot: Civil and Environmental Engineering - MIT News Office. From bacteria to bridges, CEE researchers tackle natural and built environments.

A new study by researchers in the MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering shifts the focus to the first few days of an epidemic, determining how likely the 40 largest U.S. airports are to influence the spread of a contagious disease originating in their home cities. New model of disease contagion ranks U.S. airports in terms of their spreading influence - MIT News. Airports in New York, Los Angeles and Honolulu are judged likeliest to play a significant role in the growth of a pandemic.

Photos: Maia Weinstock/MIT. #onlyatMIT
