messages: Lego has approved the Lego NASA Women set designed by MIT staff member Maia Weinstock, which celebrates the history of women in STEM. 👏 🎉. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
The MIT Mystery Hunt begins today! The goal: Solve puzzles to find a coin hidden on campus. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/fWw1307Yv1w. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Happy Ada Lovelace Day! Here are four of MIT's fantastic #womeninSTEM, rendered in LEGO: professors Paula Hammond, Maria Zuber, Sangeeta Bhatia, Millie Dresselhaus.   Photos: Maia Weinstock. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Still going strong: Institute Professor Millie Dresselhaus then and now http://mitsha.re/ra4C304VeoA #ThrowbackThursday. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Must-see TV: MIT’s thriving maker culture is on display in the current season of BattleBots on ABC. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/e551301NZW1. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Celebrating the MIT Class of 2016. Full story: mitsha.re/jiJB300U528 #MIT2016. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

MIT design is on full display at this week's Venice Architecture Biennale (La Biennale di Venezia). Full story: http://mitsha.re/2BGe300EuTQ. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Famed Italian glassmaker Lino Tagliapietra recently brought his team to MIT's W. David Kingery Ceramics and Glass Lab. 

“My goal is only experimental new things, new material; new colors are possible, new techniques, and different ways I try to do something,” Tagliapietra says.

Full story: http://mitsha.re/W4an300usMc. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

For the first time ever, MIT Softball is going to the College World Series! Full story: http://mitsha.re/4J5S300xyHO

Photos: MIT Engineers Athletics
Follow the team on Instagram: http://instagram.com/mitsoftball/ Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
A glimpse of all the action at MIT Open House today! Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Hundreds of students, staff, faculty, and alumni volunteered for the inaugural Together in Service Day, a collaboration between the MIT Priscilla King Gray Public Service Center and the City of Cambridge (Official). Thank you! http://mitsha.re/4mWPT0. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Add us on Snapchat (MITsocial) and look for our story on MIT's Open House this Saturday, April 23. #MIT02139 
 mitsha.re/4mSge8. Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)

MIT's Baker House, through the eyes of 2016 McDermott Award-winner an Adjaye Associates principal David Adjaye: http://mitsha.re/108HOy 

Learn about Adjaye and Arts at MIT McDermott Award: http://mitsha.re/108HAJ. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Yummy pies for Pi Day, courtesy of Class of 2020 early-admitted students Jasmine L., Jenn L., and Reuben M! (Photos via MIT Admissions.) Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

#TBT Building E52, seen in 1950 and today, was dedicated last week as the newly renovated Morris and Sophie Chang Building. E52 houses offices for the MIT Sloan School of Management and  MIT Economics department. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/Z2pje. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Hats off to all the women at MIT and around the world. Happy #InternationalWomensDay. #IWD2016. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Go Tech! A team of MIT students has won the first round of SpaceX's #Hyperloop contest. Congrats, MIT Hyperloop! http://mitsha.re/XNOwJ. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

A meeting of minds in Mumbai: MIT President Reif, Ratan Tata, members of the MIT Tata Center for Technology and Design, and grad students discuss MIT’s work and deepening relationship with India.  #MITIndia

Photos: Benjamin Miller/MIT Tata Center. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Wishing a happy 86th birthday to Buzz Aldrin ScD ’63. May your next solar orbit be the best yet! Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Seen this morning: Tribute to David Bowie in Lobby 7. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

PhD student Adrian Dalca undertook a 5-year venture to take 1 million photos of Boston and MIT. Learn about his Boston Timescape Project: http://mitsha.re/WUkBe Project page: http://mitsha.re/WUk1N. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

This week, new plans were presented to the City of Cambridge, Massachusetts, for MIT's proposed Kendall Square Initiative. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/WNQbl. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Creativity + sustainability = MIT Trashion Show. http://mitsha.re/W6e5j

Photos: Wisima (Sam) Nipatnantaporn. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Top 15 posts of 2015 – No. 11: Matt Damon to speak at Commencement in the spring #MIT2016 http://mitsha.re/VNVts. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

What's it like in finals week to look up from your notes to see President Reif, Chancellor Barnhart, and a big basket of cookies? Sweet!

Photos: Karla Casey. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Born on this date in 1804: scientist, educator and MIT founder William Barton Rogers! Read his "autobiography" from MIT Admissions: http://mitsha.re/VAeM9. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
Happy 85th birthday to Millie Dresselhaus, MIT's pioneering "queen of carbon!" http://mitsha.re/UwoZA #womeninSTEM. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Good, clean fun! MIT students took part in chillaxing activities around the Institute yesterday as part of "DUE for a Recharge," which coincided with #NationalStressAwarenessDay.

Photos via MIT Edgerton Center and the Division of Student Life. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

On Inside Kendall Square day, part of the ongoing HUBweek celebration in greater Boston, a look at the past and future of #KendallSquare, via MIT Technology Review: http://mitsha.re/TaBuX     #HUBweek #tbt. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Hope you're enjoying the #SuperBloodMoon! Here's the view from Cambridge, before the eclipse and during totality.

Photos: Maia Weinstock/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

In preparation for tonight's supermoon eclipse, enjoy this new Apollo photo archive featuring MIT alumni who've been there in person — Buzz Aldrin ScD '63 (Apollo 11), Edgar Mitchell ScD '64 (Apollo 14), and Charles Duke SM '64 (Apollo 16): http://mitsha.re/SHcTE

Photos: NASA. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

“There is no compromise to be made by being an athlete and studying STEM.” –Carrington Motley '16

Learn how Motley, an MIT Mechanical Engineering major, balances track and field with research on vehicle mobility in sand: http://mitsha.re/SwGBL. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Featured this week in The New York Times: How MIT Libraries' Jana Dambrogio studies the secret art of letterlocking http://mitsha.re/Sotdt

More on letterlocking research at MIT: http://mitsha.re/SoxvC. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Happy #LaborDay! And THANK YOU those who keep MIT running smoothly throughout the year. 👏

Learn more about the MIT Dept. of Facilities: http://web.mit.edu/facilities/

Photos: M. Scott Brauer. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

“Every one of you has what it takes.” Yesterday, President Reif and other MIT leaders welcomed the Class of 2019 to campus. Full story: http://mitsha.re/RE5c9

Photos: Dominick Reuter. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Chemistry artwork at MIT

#aroundMIT #SciArt #ACSBoston #chemistryrules. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

What does an engineer look like? Here are just a few faces of the MIT School of Engineering. Share your own with #ILookLikeanEngineer, a new hashtag that celebrates diversity in engineering. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Curious to know what a semester at MIT Sloan School of Management is like? Photo blog by MBA student Ankita Kaul: http://bit.ly/1h0Azv7. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Did you know? MIT computer scientist Margaret Hamilton wrote critical flight software that helped Apollo 11 land on the moon on this day in 1969. Her story: http://bit.ly/1zGLNYy. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Fun facts about LEGO MIT, as seen in the Legoland Discovery Center in Somerville, MA:

-It contains more than 20,000 LEGO pieces and over 30 LED lights.

-The dome structure, a model of Building 10, is hollow but strong.

-It is part of the largest indoor LEGO "Miniland" in the world, with Boston/Cambridge landmarks made with some 1.8 million bricks and 3,000+ minifigures. 

-Tyler Holmes, assistant to the center's master LEGO builder, says the MIT model was "probably the most difficult of all the buildings in the Boston scene because of the dome."

Photos: Maia Weinstock/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

This morning, NASA's New Horizons craft made history, visiting Pluto on behalf of humanity. Co-investigator and MIT Professor Rick Binzel spoke with MIT News about the #PlutoFlyby milestone: http://mitne.ws/1gzJl2T

And from the MIT Alumni Association, a rundown of known MIT contributors to New Horizons: bit.ly/1UKZO3S Congrats to all on this incredible achievement! Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

#PrattKeeping, MIT-style. Wrangling robots is all in a day's work for CSAIL - MIT PhD student Ariel Anders!

Photo: Jose-Luis Olivares, Adam Connor-Simons, Maia Weinstock/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Happy Tau Day!

Photos: Stephanie Leishman and Emer Garland. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

To mark the #WeekofMaking, a look back at MIT's first Mini Maker Faire, held last October: http://mitne.ws/1sb5qYe #TBT

Photos: Josh Ramos. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

A group of students from MIT and Harvard are biking across the country, stopping in communities along the way in an effort to get kids excited about science. Learn more about their efforts: http://mitsha.re/1IFGgdE. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.
It's a beautiful day to graduate! Welcome, family and friends of #MIT2015 🎓 Watch the live webcast: http://mitsha.re/mitwebcast. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Impressive feat: A new microscope developed by the MIT Department of Physics can freeze and image 1,000 fermionic atoms at once! Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1cTxsDn. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

In a visit to MIT, Nobel Prize-winning chemist Mario Molina debunked three climate science myths and called for better communication of climate risks. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1FeeQsg. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

With help from the MIT Space Balloon Team, Institute mascot Tim the Beaver recently traveled to the edge of space for charity. Watch the video: http://mitne.ws/1HcPnl3

Photos courtesy of MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Get ready for a brand new Kendall Square! Designs for new MIT buildings around east campus were shared yesterday at two community meetings. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1bAFDD7. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

For NCAA Division III Week, MIT students and staff have been displaying their school spirit! Whether you're on campus or off, share your MIT colors tomorrow, April 10, with the hashtag #MITPride, and MIT Engineers Athletics may share on Instagram (@MITAthletics) and Twitter (@MITEngineers). Go Tech!!

Also: Don't miss this video of MIT students describing what it means to be a DIII athlete! http://mitsha.re/1Fr0dOa. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

"Many rhythms, one song." Recent photos from the PULSE celebration sponsored by the MIT Black Students' Union. See the full set at: http://mitsha.re/1C4BP9m 

Photos: Joshua Woodard. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

On Wednesday, MIT graduate students picked up their GradRat rings at a special Bush Room social!

Learn about the GradRat design and history: http://mitsha.re/16zSUcZ

Photos: Maia Weinstock/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Hundreds in the MIT community gathered Wednesday for a luncheon to honor the memory of Martin Luther King Jr., with talks reflecting on the need for greater inclusion and communication — both on campus and in the world at large. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1D2QcsU 

Photos: Dominick Reuter. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Chemistry grad student Jolene Mork is studying energy transfer in quantum dots — nanocrystals so small that they exhibit quantum-mechanical properties. Learn about Mork's most recent work via the MIT Materials Processing Center: http://mitne.ws/1BXeWlU. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

MIT will soon house a new lab devoted to socially responsible and sustainable real estate development, thanks to an $118 million gift from alumnus Samuel Tak Lee ’62, SM ’64. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1yFg3H4

Photos of the signing ceremony by Bryce Vickmark. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Happy #Newtonmas! Isaac Newton was born Christmas Day, 1642. This apple tree in MIT's President's Garden carries forth his wisdom: It is a direct descendant of the actual tree believed to have inspired Newton's theory of gravity. http://mitsha.re/1GXUNxf

Photos: Maia Weinstock & Stephanie Leishman/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Hacking Ebola with MIT Hacking Medicine: More than 100 spent this past weekend at MIT helping to devise better personal protections, diagnostics, and medical records in the face of the deadly disease. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1sGednm  

Photos courtesy of MGH Center for Global Health. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

On this date in #MIThistory: The nucleus of what would become the MIT Libraries was donated to MIT on Dec. 15, 1862. http://mitsha.re/1svErJs 

Photos: Christopher Harting and Stephanie Leishman/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

This week, eight student teams presented the results of a semester of work in course 2.009 (Product Engineering Processes). Capturing this year’s theme of “Adventure,” the product prototypes included sporting accessories, medical devices, and helpful devices for musicians and parents. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1yxaZEe

Photos: Stephanie Leishman/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Members of the MIT community engaged in an important dialogue about race this week, with demonstrations and a standing-room-only #BlackLivesMatter panel discussion. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1zHJmr2 

Photos: Dominick Reuter. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

To mark Computer Science Education Week, CSAIL - MIT hosted 150 local students for its 1st annual #HourofCode demo fair, tied to the international initiative aimed at getting young people excited about programming. Researchers showed off their work, and musician will.i.am appeared virtually with a special message to the MIT attendees about practicing coding. http://mitne.ws/1yIZc5W

Photos: Jason Dorfman/CSAIL. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Last week, some 20 teams of students worked together to create a giant Rube-Goldberg contraption at MIT. Full slideshow of the MIT Museum's annual F.A.T. Chain Reaction: http://mitne.ws/1s2Aki6

Photos: Samara Vise/MIT Museum. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

In his Compton Lecture at MIT yesterday, National Institutes of Health (NIH) Director Francis Collins spoke about health research and science communication, urging an MIT audience to “reflect on what our role is as scientists and citizens of the world.” http://mitne.ws/1thvDoA 

Photos: Dominick Reuter. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

At last week's MIT AeroAstro Centennial Symposium, 11 astronauts — all MIT alumni — and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk celebrated the 100th anniversary of MIT Aeronautics and Astronautics. Full story: http://mitne.ws/ZTKrxp 

Photos: Dominick Reuter. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Founded in 1949, the MIT Science Fiction Society maintains what may be the world’s largest open-shelf collection of science fiction. Peek inside with a story and video from MIT News: http://mitne.ws/1BY0WoT 

Photos: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT #onlyatMIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

On Friday, students in one of MIT's iconic courses, 2.009 (Product Engineering Process), took to Killian Court for a massive obstacle course challenge. Storify with pics + tweets: https://storify.com/MIT/2-009-in-2014. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

On campus this afternoon, chess Grandmaster Larry Christiansen took on 10 members of the MIT Chess Club at once! #onlyatMIT

Learn about the MIT Chess Club: http://mitsha.re/1AfroJK 

Photos: Maia Weinstock/MIT. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Welcome, Class of 2018! Yesterday, President L. Rafael Reif greeted MIT's newest students at the traditional Freshman Convocation ceremony. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1wt4rWL  

Photos: Dominick Reuter. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

"The neighborhood I live in is interesting to say the least. One of the world epicenters of technology and science, with a wide range of architectural styles. Of course, MIT has buildings all around, some historic red brick, others marvels of modern design with sweeping lines and bold colors." http://mitsha.re/1uiod5p 

Photos courtesy of Tom Kershaw. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

"If you want to do something, put time into it. If you think it’s cool, other people will, too.” Learn how these way-cool high-speed images by Kyle Hounsell '13, MNG '14 were made: http://mitsha.re/1sz5nHb via MIT Spectrum. Photos from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s post.

Here's an interactive Pinterest map of MIT campus. Have you visited any of these places? The list is incomplete; what other MIT landmarks and locations would you include? http://mitsha.re/1d4mU07. MIT Campus. Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) is using Pinterest, an online pinboard to collect and share what inspires you.

Great write-up about the work out of the Langer Lab. M.I.T. Lab Hatches Ideas, and Companies, by the Dozens. Dr. Robert Langer’s lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is on the front lines of turning discoveries into a range of drugs and drug delivery systems.

Throwback to our May pageant, at which MIT celebrated 100 years in Cambridge and reaffirmed its values of mind, hand, and heart.

Buongiorno, Lozano-Pérez, Ochsendorf, Paxson, and Prather receive MIT’s top undergraduate teaching honor. Pictured below, clockwise, from top left: Kristala L. J. Prather (photo by M. Scott Brauer); Jacopo Buongiorno (photo by Despoina Chatzikyriakou); Tomás Lozano-Pérez (photo by Melanie Gonick); Heather Anne Paxson (photo by Dominick Reuter); and John Ochsendorf (photo courtesy MacArthur Foundation) More: http://mitne.ws/1lDIyLm. Timeline Photos.

In visit to #MIT, White House advisor Valerie Jarrett calls for greater inclusion in education. Fun fact: Jarrett's great-grandfather, Robert Taylor, was the Institute’s first African-American graduate. More: http://mitne.ws/1cGgLcZ (Photo: Dominick Reuter) Timeline Photos.

#MIT hosts the first of three conferences on #bigdataprivacy policy. More: http://mitne.ws/1ncdgw3

Martin Schmidt named provost; Cynthia Barnhart named chancellor. Two faculty members named to MIT’s most senior academic posts first arrived at the Institute as students in the early 1980s. More: http://mitne.ws/1eterV9 

(Photo: Dominick Reuter) Timeline Photos.

British Prime Minister David Cameron got a first-hand look yesterday at MIT’s culture of innovation in robotics, advanced prosthetics and entrepreneurship. http://mitne.ws/18IUING (Photo: Dominick Reuter) Timeline Photos.

MIT professor Maria Zuber is working to uncover clues to the moon's early evolution through data obtained via NASA’s Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory (GRAIL) mission — an ambitious undertaking she conceived and helmed. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/Z1RWNf

(Photo: Dominick Reuter) Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary: MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. Read up on the latest news and research from the Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences Department at MIT. A new model from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences may provide the answer. Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences | MIT OpenCourseWare | Free... The department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences explores the the solid earth, fluid earth, the biosphere, and their interactions, as well as planetary science, solar system dynamics, and observational astronomy. Meet Colette Heald, associate professor in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences and MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering who studies how particles affect air quality and climate.
messages: Researchers in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences have observed a star beating for its eccentric planet. #ScienceValentines 💓. The heart of a far-off star beats for its planet. Scientists observe first planet-induced stellar pulsations.

Research from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences found that certain greenhouse gases can cause sea levels to rise for hundreds of years after the pollutants have been cleared from the atmosphere. Short-lived greenhouse gases cause centuries of sea-level rise. Through warming effects, methane and other gases impact rising seas long after leaving the atmosphere.

A team led by MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences; NASA; and Université de Liège (ULg) scientists has discovered that two potentially habitable planets in nearby system are rocky. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/80G6302te3E

GIF: NASA/ESA/STScl. i.giphy.com.

Researchers from MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences , Princeton University, and elsewhere have developed a new technique to monitor the seasonal changes in Greenland’s ice sheet. Tracking Greenland’s ice melt with seismic waves. Technique uses vibrations generated by ocean waves to monitor ice sheet’s seasonal changes.

Is there life beyond the solar system? Three exoplanets co-discovered by scientists in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences are raising new hopes of finding out. Scientists discover potentially habitable planets. Just 40 light years from Earth, planets are best targets so far for search for extraterrestrial life.

Meet Colette Heald, associate professor in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences and MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering who studies how particles affect air quality and climate. #womeninSTEM. Colette Heald: There’s something in the air. Chemist studies atmospheric gases and particles, and how they affect air quality and climate.

Learn about climate change from MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences professors! Global Warming Science, a free course from MITx on edX, starts this week: http://mitsha.re/YoT3E. Timeline Photos.

Good news! A study from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences finds that our planet's geomagnetic field won't be flipping anytime soon. Earth not due for a geomagnetic flip in the near future. Researchers find geomagnetic field intensity is double the long-term historical average.

“We really owe microbes a lot, because there would be no complex life on Earth without these bugs.” –Tanja Bosak, scientist in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. Microbe sleuth. Tanja Bosak examines how life and the Earth evolved in tandem during their early history together.

MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences researchers are using stalagmites to learn how the American West dried out. Stalagmites pinpoint drying of American West. Research suggests western U.S. deserts were relatively wet up until 8,200 years ago.

Tomorrow, humans make history when our little spacecraft flies past Pluto. And MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences professor Richard Binzel has a front-row seat as a New Horizons scientist...so feel it! http://bit.ly/1Da5KbS. Timeline Photos.

What causes massive storms on Saturn? A new model from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences may provide the answer. Small thunderstorms may add up to massive cyclones on Saturn. New model may predict cyclone activity on other planets.

“The climate system is incredibly tied up with life.” –Mick Follows of MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. An ocean of opportunity. Mick Follows uses tiny marine microbes to model climate change.

“Madison is a shining example of how academic excellence and athletic success can coexist.’’. Campus Angle: Madison Douglas, Concord-Carlisle/MIT fencing - The Boston Globe. The Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences major has a 121-59 career record as women’s squad leader.

A new study from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences suggests that intense volcanism may have played a significant role in wiping out the dinosaurs. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1BB4qBU 

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

A new study from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences provides the first experimental evidence that our solar system was shaped by an intense magnetic field.  http://mitne.ws/1xEBy8v 

Image: MIT Paleomagnetism Laboratory. Timeline Photos.

Happy birthday, Building 54! MIT's iconic tower and home to the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences turns 50 this week: http://sciencem.it/1x6n9Af

Photo: Stuart Darsch. Timeline Photos.

Researchers at the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences say a large earthquake may occur 5 miles from Istanbul. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1qn0jUY 

Image: NASA, and Christine Daniloff and Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT. Timeline Photos.

When did dinosaurs first appear in North America? An MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences study sheds new light: http://mitne.ws/1pMi654  

Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT (Background photo courtesy of Malka Machlus/Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University.) Timeline Photos.

20 years ago today, then-MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences and Hubble Space Telescope researcher Heidi Hammel '82 captured this image of an impact from Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, the pieces of which crashed into Jupiter over seven days in July, 1994. Read what it was like to have a front seat for one of the most dynamic events that astronomers and planetary scientists have ever witnessed: http://mitsha.re/WcL6sA. Timeline Photos.

The Search for Earth 2.0: MacArthur Genius Grant awardee Sara Seager is on a mission to find an Earth twin. http://mitsha.re/1hVpFkd (Photo: Sam Ogden)

View this and other stories on the news page for the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences http://mitsha.re/1hVpQft. Timeline Photos.

A new study co-authored by Kerry Emanuel of the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences concludes that powerful tropical cyclones — a.k.a. hurricanes — have shifted their peak intensity farther from the equator and closer to the poles in recent decades. More: http://mitne.ws/REv6Nn  

(Image: NOAA) Timeline Photos.

Happy #EarthDay! Become an expert on the workings of our planet with free open course offerings from MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences and MIT OpenCourseWare. 

For those of you on or near campus, a listing of Earth Week events at MIT: http://sustainability.mit.edu/earthday. Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences | MIT OpenCourseWare | Free... The department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences explores the the solid earth, fluid earth, the biosphere, and their interactions, as well as planetary science, solar system dynamics, and observational astronomy.

MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences researchers calculate #river networks’ movement across a #landscape. More: http://mitne.ws/1g3lAfu

(Photo courtesy of Taylor Perron) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Biology MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering scientists discover extracellular vesicles produced by #ocean microbes. More: http://mitne.ws/1euQJ8n

(Image: Steven Biller/Chisholm Lab) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences Researchers find immense heating at high pressures helps spread intermediate-depth #earthquakes. More: http://mitne.ws/1dyrsK0

(Image courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

New MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences method will help scientists determine the mass of exoplanets that are not measurable in any other way. More: http://mitne.ws/1dTgsHL

(Image: Christine Daniloff/MIT, Julien de Wit) Timeline Photos.

While the #Arctic Ocean is largely a #carbon sink, MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences researchers find parts are also a source of atmospheric #carbon dioxide. More: http://mitne.ws/IFMuN5. Timeline Photos.

New research from MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences shows that rain as acidic as undiluted lemon juice may have played a part in killing off plants and organisms around the world during the most severe mass extinction in #Earth’s history: http://mitsha.re/1jBicXK. Timeline Photos.

Read up on the latest news and research from the Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences Department at MIT. MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. Oceans Ahoy! Read all about oceanography in EAPS, meet atmospheric chemistry graduate student Sarvesh Garimella, review member news and more in the Spring issue of EAPSpeaks: http://bit.ly/10ElFzb.

“Unfortunately, the results of the study suggest a relatively high sensitivity of tropical extreme rainfall to global warming,” says Paul O’Gorman, an assistant professor in Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences Department, MIT. “But they also provide an estimate of what that sensitivity is, which should be of practical value for planning.” When it rains, it pours - MIT News Office. Study estimates rate of intensification of extreme tropical rainfall with global warming.

“This thing missed, but chances are, at this size, we will one day find an object headed for an impact,” says Richard Binzel, a professor of planetary sciences in MIT’s Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences. “Depending on where it’s falling, you might need to know whether it’s going to survive passage through the atmosphere, and how many fragments [will make impact]. We’d like to have the capability to deliver those kinds of answers, if we need to.” Explained: Near-miss asteroids - MIT News Office. What to do in the event of an asteroid streaking toward Earth? Activate the asteroid ‘fire drill.’

While scientists there seek to answer questions about trees and terrain, Schilling is interested in the maps and models of the region’s resources. "I like the idea that math is a juncture between practical impact and elegant ideas. You see something that’s very conceptual, but if you know how to tweak it the right way, it will have very profound practical applications.” - Find out more about MIT PhD student Kuang Xu's research http://mitne.ws/16zkfs1 (Photo: Allegra Boverman) Timeline Photos.

Uh oh...more snow ahead! Here's how MIT is preparing for today's storm: http://mitsha.re/1C89SHo. MIT Alumni Association. How bad were your winters at MIT? 

An unbelievably snowy winter continues into spring: MIT taking precautions for today's storm http://bit.ly/1FeSaqm.

Dealing with the ❄❄❄ back in 1948: "I am very desirous that the Institute of Technology have a competent group of engineers make an immediate study as to ways and means of removing the huge [snow] accumulation ... whether it be by the use of flame throwers or chemicals or otherwise."

Full story of this moment in #MIThistory from the MIT Alumni Association blog: http://mitsha.re/1uxHmN2. Timeline Photos.

Institute Professor Emeritus Noam Chomsky will speak today at the MIT Alumni Association Faculty Forum Online. Watch the live session via public webcast beginning at 12 p.m. EST: http://mitsha.re/15si0tN 

Alumni may submit a question for Prof. Chomsky by registering here: http://mitsha.re/15si24M. Timeline Photos.
Happy 101st birthday, Tim! An exclusive interview with our favorite engineer from the MIT Alumni Association's Slice of MIT blog: http://mitsha.re/1BiRhxo. Timeline Photos.

Papercraft MIT! Watch an animated holiday message to everyone in the MIT community from President Reif and Christine Reif: http://mitsha.re/1vTe5eQ

Image courtesy of the MIT Alumni Association. Timeline Photos.
Looking for an MIT-inspired holiday gift? Try the new MIT Hatch'd store, featuring items created by Institute affiliates and MIT alumni. http://mitsha.re/1FJcJuX. Timeline Photos.

Philippe Kletzkine SM ’83 was manager for the Rosetta Mission's Philae probe, which landed on the surface of a comet today. His story from the MIT Alumni Association: http://mitsha.re/1ubwacd. Timeline Photos.

The Mass. Ave. bridge will soon be getting an MIT makeover! Here's the scoop from the MIT Alumni Association's Slice of MIT blog. http://bit.ly/1rnY5zs. MIT Alumni Association. Not mood lighting, more like Smoot lighting!

Thanks to an anonymous gift, the world-famous Smoot markings on the Harvard Bridge will soon be illuminated by state-of-the art LED bulbs. http://bit.ly/1rnY5zs.

Did you know? MIT has more astronaut alumni than any other non-military academic institution. #AeroAstro100. MIT Alumni Association. More astronauts call MIT their alma mater than any other non-military academic institution. Here are the 38 MIT men and women who have gone to space for science: http://bit.ly/1vDSpaI 
Source: NASA.

A throwback to the first week of classes 35 years ago, via the MIT Alumni Association: Registration Day, 1979. #tbt. MIT Alumni Association. First year students began their MIT adventure this week. To celebrate, here's a throwback to registration day 1979. Recognize anyone? #tbt.

Hey alumni, the MIT Alumni Association wants to see your #brassrat! Share photos with that hashtag on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram. MIT Alumni Association. Thank you to the over 30 alumni and students who have shared photos of their #brassrat from Poland to California to Rio. We still want to see yours! Share a photo of your brass rat on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram with the hashtag #brassrat and show us where you are.

Travel the world with the MIT Alumni travelers! Upcoming destinations include Cuba, Japan, and the Azores and Canary Islands: http://mitsha.re/1pRAiuh. MIT Alumni Association. The MIT Alumni Travel Program group currently traveling in Peru shows off their Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) pride atop Machu Picchu - Peru.

Everyone loves a good laugh from The Onion. The MIT Alumni Association has chosen 10 of their funniest articles with MIT story lines. Which is your favorite? The Onion's Best (Fake) Stories About MIT. More than 50 stories include mentions of MIT on the Onion website. We've listed our 10 favorites.

Members of MIT’s Class of 2018 will soon descend upon campus to get their feet wet — literally. Why does MIT require students to pass a swim test? Nicole Morell of the MIT Alumni Association dives into this Institute tradition: http://mitne.ws/1niRQR0

Photo courtesy of the Division of Student Life. Timeline Photos.
#TBT history lesson: Ever wonder how MIT got a front door on Massachusetts Ave.? Read the full story from the MIT Alumni Association's Slice of MIT blog. http://mitsha.re/1qNgKaD. Timeline Photos.

Engineer-guitarist Tom Scholz '69, SM '70 performed in Maine recently with his band, Boston. He is also one of the musicians profiled in a new article on scientists who ROKK: http://mitsha.re/1mctd7a

More on Scholz from the MIT Alumni Association: http://mitsha.re/TQTc8A

(Photo: Kamal Asar) Boston.

Happy Friday! Enjoy this periodic table of chocolate-dipped strawberries, as seen by Prof. Patrick Henry Winston ’65, SM ’67, PhD ’70.

Story behind the berries via the MIT Alumni Association: http://mitsha.re/1mpKQjE. Timeline Photos.

Hope everyone had a blast at #TechReunions! Enjoy this recap from the MIT Alumni Association: http://mitne.ws/1lxQBvh. MIT Alumni Association. Here's a photo from #TechReunions that's too good not to share.  

Lawrence Castro '64 dons his red jacket while maneuvering through the Charles River on a stand-up paddle board. 

 Photo: Darren Castro '92, SCD '97.

Dianna Cowern ’11, a.k.a. Physics Girl, has just won The Flame Challenge, an international contest hosted by actor/STEM advocate Alan Alda inviting scientists to create accurate, vivid answers to deceptively simple questions. Watch Cowern's winning video, "What is color?" below, then read her interview with the MIT Alumni Association: http://mitsha.re/UraMRV . What is Color? Flame Challenge Winner 2014. This is the winning entry for the 2014 Flame Challenge put on by Alan Alda and the Center for Communicating Science. http://flamechallenge.org The competitio...

Kofi Annan SM '72, a graduate of the MIT Sloan School of Management, addresses the class of 1997. #tbt #MIT2014

Full list of past MIT Commencement speakers, via MIT Alumni Association: http://mitsha.re/1l8FfNH. Timeline Photos.
The story of a Star Trek spacecraft restored by an MIT alum: http://bit.ly/16edP0A via MIT Alumni Association. Timeline Photos.

"The colors of these ribbons are the official colors of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as defined by the 'Report of the Committee to Determine Official M.I.T. Colors' accepted by the Alumni Association on January 19, 1931.” #throwbackthursday #tbt #greyandcardinal #mithistory. Timeline Photos.

ThingMagic, founded by five #MIT alumni, helped bring radio-frequency identification #technology to the supply chain. More: http://mitne.ws/1e8rV6t

(Photo: ThingMagic, a division of Trimble) Timeline Photos.

How well do you know MIT? http://mitsha.re/J5D1Ps. MIT Alumni Association. The crossword puzzle turns 100 years old this week. In honor, try an MIT-themed puzzle that features alumni, landmarks, and traditions. See how well you know MIT!

We’ll start you off with a hint. 22 down: Super hero alumnus. http://bit.ly/18R50JF.
Cool! MIT Alumni Association. Entrances. http://ift.tt/HLg97a.
LIVE: Watch MIT’s 2013 doctoral hooding ceremony http://mit.tv/186xLq3 MIT Alumni Association. Timeline Photos.

MIT sophomore Trevor Walker has reached the College Championship finals on TV game show Jeopardy. MIT Alumni Association. Trevor Walker '15 returns to the Jeopardy podium tonight, after having won the quarter-final and semi-final of the College Championship series. http://bit.ly/13z1nI2.

Happy Holidays from MIT! 

Please enjoy this year's holiday card from President Rafael Reif and his family (via the MIT Alumni Association) — http://alum.mit.edu/holiday2012/ Timeline Photos.

Let's get MIT a medal in the Alumpics! Vote for us in the Academics category today! MIT Alumni Association. Today in the Alumpics: Academics. 
 
Professor Emeritus Walter Lewin swings from a pendulum during his now-famous final lecture at MIT. Why? To demonstrate that a pendulum's period remains constant regardless of mass (obviously).

We are not tape delayed! This is live and we need your likes! 

Share the photo with alumni, friends, and anyone who’s ever wanted to see a human pendulum! Let’s go, MIT!

clusters.summary:
Recap of the ceremony and speeches: http://mitne.ws/1hE8KrI

(Photo: Maia Weinstock, featuring MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) ) Timeline Photos. Medallions of the MIT seal from the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) foundry. More on the winners: http://mitsha.re/1g6sNNh #stem MIT Department of Biology MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) MIT EECS Department MIT Mechanical Engineering. Congratulations to Tyler Jacks, director of the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research and professor in the MIT Department of Biology, for being named this year's Killian Award winner! MIT Department of Biology MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering study reveals immune #cells that are critical to combating the parasite that causes #malaria in early stages of infection.
messages: “Hearing loss is a real problem as people get older. It’s very much of an unmet need, and this is an entirely new approach,” says Robert Langer, the David H. Koch Institute Professor at MIT, a member of the David H. Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, and one of the senior authors of the study. Drug treatment could combat hearing loss. Researchers discover a drug combination that can regenerate hair cells in the inner ear.

“We have presented results showing that the spleen is the main organ that defines the shape of the circulating red blood cells,” says Ming Dao, a principal research scientist in MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE). How the spleen filters blood. Computer model finds slits in the spleen impose a “physical fitness test” on red blood cells.

It's the Monday after Commencement, so that means the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) has updated its bulletin board! 

Photo: Maia Weinstock/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Enjoy the beauty of science? Behold the new scientific imagery at the Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Center's public galleries. Scientific art lights up Main Street. Art and science converge in the public galleries at MIT's Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research.
Science = art. Explore the online gallery of the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer: http://mitsha.re/YaiT3 #SciArt. Timeline Photos.

“If you just focus on what you know, you’re blinding yourself to new opportunities.” Tyler Jacks, professor in the MIT Department of Biology and head of the David H. Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, is the recipient of the 2016 Killian Award. Targeting cancer from many angles. Killian Award recipient Tyler Jacks fosters interdisciplinary, innovative cancer research.

New research from the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) paves the way for rechargeable batteries with almost indefinite lifetimes: http://mitsha.re/R03QP

Image: Yan Wang. Going solid-state could make batteries safer and longer-lasting. New research paves the way for rechargeable batteries with almost indefinite lifetimes, researchers say.

Congratulations to Tyler Jacks, director of the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research and professor in the MIT Department of Biology, for being named this year's Killian Award winner! Tyler Jacks receives MIT’s Killian Award. Cancer biologist and Koch Institute director recognized with MIT faculty’s top honor.
The magic of glass and metal: The MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) has just reopened its shiny new glass lab, forge, and foundry! MIT Glass Lab, Forge, and Foundry.

Colorful scientific art brightens the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research public galleries. Learn about these works: http://mitsha.re/18nWFTh

Photo: Maia Weinstock/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Medallions of the MIT seal from the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) foundry. Watch how they're made in this brief video: http://mitne.ws/1C8LTgg

DMSE is home to students who are builders and creators. They strive to understand the how and why of materials and apply them to change our world. Hands-on education is valuable, so students and instructors, often immersed in a high-tech world, treasure the tactile experience of melting, annealing, cooling, hammering, and bending. Learn more: http://dmse.mit.edu/

Photo: Stephanie Leishman/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Sorting with sound: A new acoustic device that distinguishes tumor cells could help assess cancer’s spread. http://mitne.ws/1vKMVZW

Illustration: Christine Daniloff/MIT 
cc: MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) Timeline Photos.

Bryan Hsu PhD '14 and Professor Paula Hammond of MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) and the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research have created a nanoscale, biodegradable film that could provide steady doses of medicine for a year or more. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1kixfff  

Photo: Dominick Reuter. Timeline Photos.

MIT graduates follow many career paths. MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) grad Ayr Muir '00, SM '01 went on to found Clover Food Lab, a thriving vegetarian restaurant business.  Clover Food Lab’s secret ingredient? Data. Lots of it. - The Boston Globe. How the Cambridge vegetarian fast-food phenom went from one truck to six—plus five restaurants, a deal with Whole Foods, and an imminent expansion to D.C.

Lorna Gibson of the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) is studying the structure of bamboo in order to find new uses as a building material. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1pcwjb8

Photo: Jennifer Chu/MIT. Timeline Photos.

Researchers in the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) have discovered how gold nanoparticles can easily penetrate cells, making them useful for delivering drugs. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1qXr1Qo 

Image: Reid Van Lehn. Timeline Photos.

The halls of MIT the Monday after Commencement... Congrats to all newly minted graduates! Recap of the ceremony and speeches: http://mitne.ws/1hE8KrI

(Photo: Maia Weinstock, featuring MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) ) Timeline Photos.

MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard sequencing of cancer cell genomes reveals potential new drug targets for an aggressive type of lung cancer. More: http://mitne.ws/1fAcbwz (Image: Jose-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research and MIT Department of Biology Professor Michael Hemann seeks better ways to deploy chemotherapy #drugs and overcome tumor resistance. More: http://mitne.ws/1g8D5qB

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research and MIT Department of Biology biologists identify extracellular #proteins that help aggressive #tumors spread through the body. More: http://mitne.ws/1g4EWfS

(Photo: Dominick Reuter) Timeline Photos.

Low-cost urine test developed by MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research MIT EECS Department engineers amplifies signals from growing tumors to detect #disease. More: http://mitne.ws/1h6UynV

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

New MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering #vaccines that catch a ride to immune #cell depots could help fight cancer and HIV. More: http://mitne.ws/M9tOaa

(Image: Haipeng Liu and Darrell Irvine) Timeline Photos.

New nanoparticles designed by MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research and MIT Chemical Engineering researchers offer best-ever gene silencing, could help treat liver diseases. More: http://mitne.ws/NzliTu

(Image: Gaurav Sahay, Yizhou Dong, and Omid Veiseh) Timeline Photos.

The MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering Foundry provides a space for students, faculty and staff to come #innovate, #create and get their hands dirty in the process. More: http://mitne.ws/1idtAd2

(Video Melanie Gonick, MIT News)  The Foundry at MIT. Within the Department of Materials Science and Engineering lives a place where students can come and put their materials knowledge into practice. The Foundry...

Marshall Scholar & MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering student Colleen Loynachan tackles materials science problems with a photographer’s perspective. More: http://mitne.ws/1dQBViP

(Photo: Allegra Boverman) Timeline Photos.

New device from MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research MIT Mechanical Engineering can measure masses as small as one millionth of a trillionth of a gram. More: http://mitne.ws/JVLuWt

(Image courtesy of Selim Olcum and Nate Cermak) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Biology MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering study reveals immune #cells that are critical to combating the parasite that causes #malaria in early stages of infection. More: http://mitne.ws/JVLaXN

(Image: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering  researchers find that contrary to conventional wisdom, cathodes made of disordered lithium compounds can perform better than perfectly ordered ones. More: http://mitne.ws/1euS8fl

(Image courtesy of the researchers) Timeline Photos.

New MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering technique using nanoparticle alloys allows #heat to be focused or reflected just like electromagnetic #waves. More: http://mitsha.re/JRimyV

(Illustration courtesy of Martin Maldovan) Timeline Photos.

MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering & RLE at MIT - Research Laboratory of Electronics at MIT Professor Silvija Gradečak is looking for better materials for #solar cells, LEDs, and other #technology, one molecule at a time. More: http://mitne.ws/1bs2U5V. Timeline Photos.

Congratulations to Kate Koch, Colleen Loynachan, Kirin Sinha, and Grace Young, the four winners from #MIT of the Marshall Scholarship! More on the winners: http://mitsha.re/1g6sNNh #stem MIT Department of Biology MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE) MIT EECS Department MIT Mechanical Engineering. Timeline Photos.
