More: http://mitne.ws/H7WUEV (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1jxPRFA

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1ebJbKm (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/15eksjF (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos. More: http://mitne.ws/1hHeBt0 (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.
messages:
Prof. Holmström heard the news at home this morning: "I'm still wondering whether I'll wake up or whether this is the real thing."

Learn about his Nobel Prize win: http://mitsha.re/4HV73051x63

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

Happy Thanksgiving!

Photo: Bryce Vickmark | Cookies: Victoria Palay. Timeline Photos.

“Science, at the end of the day, is done by people just like you and me.” –Sergio Cantu, PhD student in MIT Department of Physics 

Learn how Cantu is studying lasers to increase computational speed and security: http://mitne.ws/1Hq90Uu

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

"Sangeeta Bhatia is a role model for women in science and engineering."

For International Women's Day, watch a new video from the Lemelson-MIT Program profiling Prof. Bhatia: http://mitsha.re/1zsZbyX

Photo: Bryce Vickmark #IWD2015. Timeline Photos.

“Uncovering bridges between different disciplines through common scientific fundamentals is something that keeps me really driven about doing research." Meet Bilge Yildiz of the MIT Department of Nuclear Science and Engineering: http://mitne.ws/1w2PiL4 

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

A new book by MIT's Clapperton Mavhunga explores the overlooked history of African technology. Learn more: http://mitne.ws/1vH2OjH 

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

Sofia Essayan-Perez, a senior in MIT Brain and Cognitive Sciences, is inspired by those around her to research autism and teach science in Nicaragua through the MIT Public Service Center. Her story: http://mitne.ws/ZeD5p4

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

Evelyn Wang ’00, an associate professor in MIT Mechanical Engineering, attended MIT as an undergraduate, but her connection to the Institute goes back much further than that: This is where her parents met, as graduate students from Taiwan, and married, in the MIT Chapel. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1nAsnye

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

“I defy any other institution to have students who are that *into* it.” Meet figure skater-turned-professor Arthur Bahr, who gets engineers to study Old English: http://mitne.ws/1AgukaS

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

A new gene manipulation method from the MIT Department of Biological Engineering could lead to novel #malaria drugs. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1vxEyVb  

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Timeline Photos.

PhD student Dina El-Zanfaly studies learning through making — with one eye on her home country, where she founded Fab Lab Egypt. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1nDlwr7

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

Mathematician Alice Guionnet looks for the magic hidden in huge data sets. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1pWw2dp  

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

Who's using your data? MIT's Tim Berners-Lee, Oshani Seneviratne, and Lalana Kagal are developing a new technology that would let individuals track how their private data is used online. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1kvIElu

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

Professor Fox Harrell works to enrich the subjective and ethical dimensions of the digital media experience. More: http://mitne.ws/1jxPRFA

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

Building with blocks: Architect Anton Garcia-Abril brings his experimental, industrial style to the MIT School of Architecture + Planning. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1jD6IXK 

(Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.
The complexonaut: Scott Aaronson travels the far reaches of computational complexity. More: http://mitsha.re/1g1ellp (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

New MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) nanotechnology could turn shrubbery into supercharged energy producers or sensors for explosives. More: http://mitne.ws/1ebJbKm (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

MIT management professor Vivek Farias says his ability to tackle tough business issues is mostly a byproduct of his pursuit of interesting questions.  Read about his work: http://mitne.ws/1bJ8i5u (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

An #MIT team led by Professor Michael Strano (right) and postdoc Nicole Iverson has built an implantable sensor that can monitor nitric oxide — a sign of inflammation, 
and possibly cancer — for more than a year. More: http://mitne.ws/1hHeBt0 (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

#MIT’s Paulo Lozano is designing tiny ion thrusters to cheaply and efficiently propel shoebox-sized satellites, known as “CubeSats,” through #space. More: http://mitne.ws/H7WUEV (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

Six members of the #MIT2017 class tell their stories as they begin their journey today at #MIT. Congratulations to all of our incoming freshmen! http://mitne.ws/17NjDl2 (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

“#Gaming is not separate from all the other things that are happening in society. It’s culture, and thus a part of it.” http://mitne.ws/18ogDrA - MIT sociologist T.L. Taylor studies the worlds of online gaming and e-sports (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

“By studying worms we can take a much more basic evolutionary perspective on the function of the innate immune system.” – Read more about #MIT biologist Dennis Kim’s research: http://mitne.ws/13h9uf1 (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

Newly tenured Associate Professor Tomás Palacios investigates the use of ‘extreme materials’ in electronics, which could reduce energy consumption and make computers far faster. More: http://mitne.ws/15eksjF (Photo: Bryce Vickmark) Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary: - MIT News Office. “This is the kind of thing we can do in the laboratory that you can’t do in the wild.” From yeast, researchers learn how populations collapse - MIT News Office. “We wanted to help inspire young people to change the world through engineering and science, and realized that the 10,000 superstar students we have at MIT are uniquely positioned to do that,” says Ian A. Waitz, dean of the School of Engineering and the Jerome C. Hunsaker Professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics. The helper - MIT News Office. Get to know the Class of 2016 - MIT News Office.
messages: At MIT, International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde calls for new technology and policies to meet population growth. Christine Lagarde: Thinking globally, speaking locally. IMF managing director calls for new technology, shifting policy to meet population growth.

A simple new device could diagnose Ebola in minutes. MIT Professor Lee Gehrke explains how it works in this Q&A with MIT News. 3 Questions: Lee Gehrke on a new paper diagnostic for Ebola. Simple device now in development could speed diagnosis and improve disease tracking.
MIT News has a fresh, new mobile-friendly look. Tell us what you think! http://newsoffice.mit.edu/ Timeline Photos.

This fall, Bernd Widdig has joined #MIT in a new position for the Institute, director of international affairs, where he will help to expand MIT’s global programs and engagements. Thinking globally - MIT News Office. Scholar and administrator Bernd Widdig holds a newly created position at MIT: director of international affairs.

Here's an experimental finding so unexpected that #MIT researchers initially thought it was a mistake. More: http://mitne.ws/16R0eAf. Cracked metal, heal thyself - MIT News Office. Unexpected result shows that in some cases, pulling apart makes cracks in metal fuse together.

New algorithm devised at #MIT could help #robots better understand the objects in the world around them. Better robot vision - MIT News Office. A neglected statistical tool could help robots better understand the objects in the world around them.

Two MIT professors — computer scientist Dina Katabi and astrophysicist Sara Seager — are among 24 recipients nationwide of 2013 MacArthur Fellowships, sometimes referred to as “genius grants.” More: http://mitne.ws/15Ttnbq. Dina Katabi and Sara Seager win MacArthur ‘genius grants’ - MIT News Office. Two MIT professors are among 24 recipients nationwide of this year’s unrestricted $500,000 prizes from the MacArthur Foundation.

Researchers from MIT’s Laboratory for Aviation and the Environment have announced sobering new data on air pollution’s impact on the health of people in the United States. More: http://mitne.ws/15migTr. Study: Air pollution causes 200,000 early deaths each year in the U.S. - MIT News Office. New MIT study finds vehicle emissions are the biggest contributor to these premature deaths.

MIT researchers have discovered a communication pathway between two brain structures — the amygdala and the ventral hippocampus — that appears to control anxiety levels. By turning the volume of this communication up and down in mice, the researchers were able to boost and reduce anxiety levels. More: http://mitne.ws/14Z7IAn. Brain circuit can tune anxiety - MIT News Office. New findings may help neuroscientists pinpoint better targets for antianxiety treatments.

An increasing number of firms are targeting products at developing countries. MIT researchers have found that designers will have more success in developing countries by targeting products to microentrepreneurs, particularly if such products are designed to help make these small businesses money. Targeting product design for the developing world - MIT News Office. The key, MIT study finds, is designing products that make money for the microentrepreneur.

New study suggests that people are often heavily influenced by positive opinions expressed online 
— and disregard negative views. More: http://mitne.ws/1evnWzR. Views you can use? How online ratings affect your judgment - MIT News Office. Study: Positive comments create an illusory snowball effect, while negative responses get cancelled out.

MIT researchers find ways to improve the safety of lithium-ion batteries used in electric and hybrid vehicles. Crash-testing lithium-ion batteries - MIT News Office. Laboratory crash tests show both vulnerabilities and ways to improve the safety of lithium-ion batteries used in electric and hybrid vehicles.

Study provides important indicators about the ways newly-insured people are using medical services in the United States. How Medicaid affects adult health - MIT News Office. Study: Health insurance helps lower-income Americans avoid depression, diabetes, major financial shocks.

See how an MIT doctoral student’s research on insulin led to a multimillion-dollar payday. The half-billion-dollar idea - MIT News Office. While at MIT, alumnus Todd Zion developed an insulin product that ultimately drew the attention of a pharmaceutical giant.

New research from MIT may allow scientists to develop a test that can predict the severity of side effects of some common chemotherapy agents in individual patients, allowing doctors to tailor treatments to minimize the damage. How to minimize the side effects of cancer treatment - MIT News Office. Measuring enzyme levels in patients may reveal healthy cells’ ability to survive chemotherapy.

MIT's “Neurotechnology Ventures” course encourages students to develop businesses based on concepts derived from the study of the brain, psychology, artificial intelligence, neurobiology or related fields. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/ZxNTX3. Students have engineering on the brain - MIT News Office. MIT class offers student teams a chance to create business ventures based on neurotechnology research.

Researchers bring the concept of an “artificial leaf” closer to reality. MIT researchers develop solar-to-fuel roadmap for crystalline silicon - MIT News Office. New analysis points the way to optimizing efficiency of an integrated system for harvesting sunlight to make storable fuel.

Mohamed Harding, a 17-year-old student from Freetown, Sierra Leone, talks about how knowledge gained from MIT OpenCourseWare has inspired him to create and propelled his dream of becoming an aircraft engineer. OCW brings educational opportunities to Sierra Leone - MIT News Office. Student builds robot from old toy parts using course materials from 6.270.

A must-see for those interested in urban mobility, design and the future of cities. A winning vision for the future of urban mobility - MIT News Office. Yoon and partner awarded grand prize in international competition.

MIT researchers have shown it is possible to build a nanometer-sized metal-oxide semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) — the type most commonly used in microprocessors — utilizing the compound indium gallium arsenide. http://mitne.ws/TPjpBN. Tiny compound semiconductor transistor could challenge silicon’s dominance - MIT News Office. MIT researchers develop the smallest indium gallium arsenide transistor ever built.

A peek inside the MIT EECS Department. Department snapshot: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science - MIT News Office. EECS places renewed emphasis on interdisciplinary research, partnerships with alumni and industry, and experiential learning.

Learn more about D-Lab's work. Bringing the world to innovation - MIT News Office. With up to $25 million in new USAID funding, MIT’s D-Lab will gain greater ability to help people in the developing world find their own solutions.

With 19 days to go until Election Day in the U.S., a new report from MIT and Caltech outlines the state of our election system. The state of the U.S. election system - MIT News Office. New report from MIT and Caltech notes gains in voting-machine technologies, but warns they could be cancelled out by errors introduced through mail and Internet voting.

A new approach that allows objects to become “invisible” has now been applied to an entirely different area: letting particles “hide” from passing electrons, which could lead to more efficient thermoelectric devices and new kinds of electronics. ‘Invisibility’ could be a key to better electronics - MIT News Office. MIT team applies technology developed for visual ‘cloaking’ to enable more efficient transfer of electrons.

“We’re not advocates of putting more information in front of the driver,” says Bryan Reimer, a research scientist at MIT’s AgeLab, and the lead author of an upcoming paper on the findings. Instead, Reimer says, the issue is, “How do we present the information that we do need in front of the driver in the most effective manner possible?” Smoother dashboard typefaces might enhance driver safety - MIT News Office. AgeLab study suggests ‘humanist’ lettering style is easier for drivers to read quickly.

Congratulations to Pulitzer Prize winner and MIT professor of writing Junot Díaz, who today won a MacArthur Fellowship. Junot Díaz wins MacArthur ‘genius grant’ - MIT News Office. Pulitzer Prize-winning author and writing professor receives unrestricted $500,000 prize.
Pay attention! You might remember this better. How attention helps you remember - MIT News Office. New study finds long-overlooked cells help the brain respond to visual stimuli.

So, what is a femtosecond? Explained: Femtoseconds and attoseconds - MIT News Office. As electronic and optical devices get ever faster, terms for ever-smaller increments of time are coming into wider use.

The latest from our faculty profile series: Meet Chris Zegras, an urban planner who is making an impact around the world. In profile: Chris Zegras - MIT News Office. MIT urban planner builds tools that help designers make cities cleaner and greener.

“The process may seem simple,” says Shahriar Khushrushahi, a postdoc in MIT’s Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, “but it is, inherently, supposed to be simple.” How to clean up oil spills - MIT News Office. MIT researchers devise a surprisingly simple but effective method for magnetically separating oil and water.
Meet just a few of the members from this year's freshman class. Get to know the Class of 2016 - MIT News Office. MIT’s freshman class represents 54 nations and is 46 percent female.

“Everyone believes the harm is how much money is spent, and that what’s driving the compulsive gamblers is a desire to make money. But … the ‘zone’ is really what’s driving this experience. The idea of winning money falls away when you get to the point of addiction.” Understanding gambling addiction - MIT News Office. For machine gamblers, it’s not whether they win or lose — it’s how much they play the game.

How MIT researchers might make your experience on Amazon, Orbitz, Facebook or other websites faster. Making Web applications more efficient - MIT News Office. A new system that automatically streamlines database access patterns can make large Web applications up to three times as fast.

“I have been working tirelessly to make our approaches scale to the complexity of a full humanoid. I have humanoids on my screen any time you look,” Tedrake says. “We’re going to try to smash the control problem for that.” Connoisseur of chaos - MIT News Office. Where other roboticists try to suppress the complex dynamics of mechanical systems, Russ Tedrake exploits them, to make control more efficient and versatile.

We are very excited about this study,” says Institute Professor Robert Langer. “It brings us one step closer to someday creating a tissue-engineered heart, and it shows how novel nanomaterials can play a role in this field.” Merging tissue and electronics - MIT News Office.

A multi-institution team led by MIT researchers has identified a galaxy cluster seven billion light-years away that dwarfs most known clusters, churning out a dazzling 740 new stars per year in the central galaxy. Most massive and luminous galaxy cluster identified - MIT News Office. Detection may confirm long-held theory.

“Higher temperatures lead to substantially lower economic growth in poor countries,” says Ben Olken, a professor of economics at MIT, who helped conduct the research. And while it’s relatively straightforward to see how droughts and hot weather might hurt agriculture, the study indicates that hot spells have much wider economic effects. The economic cost of increased temperatures - MIT News Office. Study: Warming episodes hurt poor countries and limit long-term growth.

In some isolated clinics in parts of Africa, the electricity needed to power lights and medical devices is generated by expensive imported diesel fuel; the water supply can be so cold in winter that health workers can’t even wash their hands properly. But a startup company established by a team of MIT students and alumni aims to change that. Bringing power to the people — and heat as well - MIT News Office. Sun-powered system developed by MIT students could provide electricity, heat and cooling to rural schools and clinics.

An array of tiny ball bearings in a box “tends to give a hexagonal symmetry, even though it’s in a square box,” says Professor Caroline Ross. “But that’s not what circuit designers want. They want patterns with 90-degree angles”. Research update: Chips with self-assembling rectangles - MIT News Office. New technique allows production of complex microchip structures in one self-assembling step.

“The ability to ensure that the bottom of the boat doesn’t have a mine attached to it is really critical to vessel security today," MIT's Franz Hover. Autonomous robot maps ship hulls for mines - MIT News Office. Algorithms enable robot to navigate and view propellers and other complex structures.

“Holography works, it’s beautiful, nothing can touch its quality,” says Douglas Lanman, a postdoc at the MIT Media Lab. “The problem, of course, is that holograms don’t move. To make them move, you need to create a hologram in real time, and to do that, you need … little tiny pixels, smaller than anything we can build at large volume at low cost. So the question is, what do we have now? We have LCDs. They’re incredibly mature, and they’re cheap.” Glasses-free 3-D TV looks nearer - MIT News Office. A new method for producing multiple-perspective 3-D images could prove more practical in the short term than holography.

In clinical trial, a cocktail of three naturally occurring dietary compounds shows success in restoring memory in patients with early Alzheimer's. Nutrient mixture improves memory in patients with early Alzheimer’s - MIT News Office. In clinical trial, mixture developed at MIT appears to help overcome loss of connections between brain cells.

“Water is not most usefully thought of as a scarce resource,” says Larry Susskind. “It’s a flexible resource. It’s not that there’s not enough water. It’s that we waste it and don’t invest in the technologies that would allow us to make more efficient uses of it. Book details a new model for sharing water - MIT News Office. Sure, water is in great demand — but that doesn’t mean supply is a zero-sum game among neighboring countries, an MIT professor says in a new book.

The key to the new process is very precise control over the size of the holes in the graphene sheet. “There’s a sweet spot, but it’s very small,” says Jeffrey Grossman — between pores so large that salt could pass through and ones so small that water molecules would be blocked. A new approach to water desalination - MIT News Office. Graphene sheets with precisely controlled pores have potential to purify water more efficiently than existing methods.

Making the invisible visible: New software amplifies changes in video that are too subtle for the naked eye. http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/amplifying-invisible-video-0622.html. Researchers amplify variations in video, making the invisible visible - MIT News Office. New software amplifies changes in successive frames of video that are too subtle for the naked eye.

“The field of ultrasound is still developing. Ultrasound will partially replace CT scans, reduce radiation exposure to patients and make diagnosing easier when away from the high-cost hospitals. It can help our world provide care at a more reasonable cost with a new paradigm of care.” Sharper ultrasound images could improve diagnostics - MIT News Office. New system developed at MIT allows precise measurements and tracking of disease progression.

“Sometimes it’s important to come up with an alarm immediately, even if you are not yet positive exactly what it is happening,” says Christopher Amato. “If something bad is going on, you want to know about it as soon as possible.” . System improves automated monitoring of security cameras - MIT News Office. New approach uses mathematics to reach a compromise between accuracy, speed.

“In the wild, you do see things change suddenly, and this model is a reasonable explanation, but it’s very hard to prove that this is happening,” Jeff Gore says. “This is the kind of thing we can do in the laboratory that you can’t do in the wild.” From yeast, researchers learn how populations collapse - MIT News Office. Findings could help fishery and wildlife managers monitor their stocks before disaster strikes.

Do you smile when you’re frustrated? Most people think they don’t — but they actually do, a new study from MIT has found. Is that smile real or fake? - MIT News Office. A computerized system developed at MIT can tell the difference between smiles of joy and smiles of frustration.

Getting a shot at the doctor’s office may become less painful in the not-too-distant future. Device may inject a variety of drugs without using needles - MIT News Office. Jet-injected drugs could improve patient compliance, reduce accidental needle sticks.

“We don’t know how proteins that reside in the nuclear membrane actually get there. We don’t understand how viruses interact with the pore and how they go through. And we don’t understand how such an enormous spectrum of substrates can go through the same pore,” Thomas Schwartz says.  Piece by piece - MIT News Office. MIT biologist Schwartz relishes the challenge of picking apart the cell’s most complex structure.

"Suppose that I'm a node in a network, and I see a communication coming in, and it is corrupted by noise," says Muriel Médard, a professor of electrical engineering and computer science. "I could try to remove the noise, but by doing that, I'm in effect making a decision right now that maybe would have been better taken by someone downstream from me who might have had more observations of the same source." The elusive capacity of networks - MIT News Office. Calculating the total capacity of a data network is a notoriously difficult problem, but information theorists are beginning to make some headway.
ROBOTS! Whirr, click, hum: Robots go at it in 2.007 finale - MIT News Office. Competition concludes mechanical design class, unleashing a wide variety of spinning, pumping and striking robots.

“It’s been absolutely fascinating to be a freshman advisor,” says President Susan Hockfield. “I learned a lot about the freshman experience. I’ve seen them grasp the challenges of MIT.” Some MIT freshmen get high-level advisors - MIT News Office. Top administrators ‘walk the talk’ by advising members of the Class of 2015.

“If we can create equipment that will help grocery stores manage things more precisely, and maybe lower their losses by 30 percent, that would be huge,” says Swager, the John D. MacArthur Professor of Chemistry. Comparing apples and oranges - MIT News Office. New sensor can accurately measure fruits’ ripeness, helping prevent loss of produce from spoilage.

Ultimately, the researchers hope it can be made using an inexpensive manufacturing process that could be applied to optical devices, the screens of smartphones and televisions, solar panels, car windshields and even windows in buildings. Through a glass, clearly - MIT News Office. MIT researchers find a way to make glass that’s anti-fogging, self-cleaning and free of glare.

“We wanted to help inspire young people to change the world through engineering and science, and realized that the 10,000 superstar students we have at MIT are uniquely positioned to do that,” says Ian A. Waitz, dean of the School of Engineering and the Jerome C. Hunsaker Professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics. MIT launches student-produced educational video initiative - MIT News Office. Original short videos, in collaboration with Khan Academy, aim to fuel K-12 students’ interest in engineering and science.

In robotics, “today’s technology is going to look so incredibly primitive in a couple of decades,” Brooks said. The robot revolution is just beginning - MIT News Office. Rodney Brooks outlines his vision of the future to student entrepreneurs.

Nancy Leveson, professor of aeronautics and astronautics and engineering systems at MIT, says increasing complexity is also making systems more vulnerable to accidents.  Engineering a safer world - MIT News Office. Workshop explores safety in nuclear power plants, occupational health, aviation and medicine.

Congratulations to Professor Nancy Lynch, named today as the 2012-2013 Athena Lecturer by the ACM-W Lynch named Athena Lecturer by ACM - MIT News Office. Professor honored for advances in distributed systems that enable dependable Internet and wireless network applications.

“The microelectronics industry has changed computation, communications and consumer electronics in a big way,” says Charles Sodini, the Clarence J. LeBel Professor of Electrical Engineering at MIT and a co-founder of the MEDRC. “The medical device industry looks like one the microelectronics industry could affect as well.” . Their own devices - MIT News Office. MIT’s Medical Electronic Device Realization Center forges a path connecting microelectronics and new health-care tools.

The latest installment in our "Future of Manufacturing" series. Moving microfluidics from the lab bench to the factory floor - MIT News Office. The Center for Polymer Microfabrication designs manufacturing processes for a new generation of diagnostic tools.

Slideshow up from this weekend's games. Congrats again to the men's basketball team who will pllay in the Final Four of the NCAA Div. III tournament for the first time in the program's 112-year history! Men's basketball advances to NCAA Div. III Final Four - MIT News Office. Engineers defeat Franklin & Marshall 69-54.

Sometimes the fastest pathway from point A to point B is not a straight line: for example, if you’re underwater and contending with strong and shifting currents. But figuring out the best route in such settings is a monumentally complex problem — especially if you’re trying to do it not just for one underwater vehicle, but for a swarm of them moving all at once toward separate destinations. Sometimes the quickest path is not a straight line - MIT News Office. New methods and software developed at MIT can predict optimal paths for automated underwater vehicles.
Our latest student profile: Jacob Wamala. The helper - MIT News Office. Senior puts engineering skills, desire to serve toward improving the lives of disadvantaged and marginalized populations.

A new study co-authored by MIT economist David Autor shows that the rapid rise in low-wage manufacturing industries overseas has indeed had a significant impact on the United States. The disappearance of U.S. manufacturing jobs frequently leaves former manufacturing workers unemployed for years, if not permanently, while creating a drag on local economies and raising the amount of taxpayer-borne social insurance necessary to keep workers and their families afloat.  When (and where) work disappears - MIT News Office. Study: Overseas manufacturing competition hits U.S. regions hard, leaving workers unemployed for years and local economies struggling.

“If you want to create a system with 50 circuits that are all working together as part of a computation that the cell is running, then you need each one of those individual circuits to not interfere with all the others. So it becomes an exponentially challenging problem to build each additional new circuit and show that it doesn’t interact with all the others,” Voigt says. Toying with biological systems - MIT News Office. By swapping microbial genes, Chris Voigt designs cells with novel functions.

"We have a huge opportunity, at this moment, to bring manufacturing back," President Barack Obama said during last night's State of the Union address. But how can we achieve that goal? Learn more about an MIT study group that is looking into what it will take. MIT faculty see promise in American manufacturing - MIT News Office. Study group is tackling hard questions about what it will take to stoke renewal.

“For every one of these 36 flavors, someone hated it and someone liked it. If you try to identify a flavor that the whole panel likes, you end up settling for a little bit less.” The mathematics of taste - MIT News Office. By using ‘genetic programming’ to crossbreed algorithms, researchers help flavor companies figure out what their customers like.

“When you go skiing off the path, you don’t ski in a way that you can always stop before the first tree you see,” Frazzoli says. “You ski and you see an opening, and then you trust that once you go there, you’ll be able to see another opening and keep going.” Speed limit for birds - MIT News Office. MIT researchers find critical speed above which birds — and drones — are sure to crash.

A team of researchers, including an MIT postdoc, has found a dark dwarf galaxy about 10 billion light years from Earth. It is only the second such galaxy ever observed outside our local region of the universe, and is by far the most distant. Astronomers find a dark matter galaxy far, far away - MIT News Office. Discovery could offer clues on the nature of dark matter.

"...Under some circumstances, the improvement can be dramatic — a tenfold increase in speed. The new algorithm could be particularly useful for image compression, enabling, say, smartphones to wirelessly transmit large video files without draining their batteries or consuming their monthly bandwidth allotments." The faster-than-fast Fourier transform - MIT News Office. For a large range of practically useful cases, MIT researchers find a way to increase the speed of one of the most important algorithms in the information sciences.
Clever math could enable a high-quality 3-D camera so simple, cheap and power-efficient that it could be incorporated into handheld devices. 3-D cameras for cellphones - MIT News Office.

clusters.summary: Kerry Emanuel of the MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change contributes to AAAS - The American Association for the Advancement of Science What We Know report on climate change. In light of this weekend's international agreement to curb fossil fuel emissions, the MIT Energy Initiative highlights MIT research and strategies shared at the #COP21 climate talks. The student-led group Fossil Free MIT and the MIT administration have reached an agreement on MIT climate action that brings to an end the group’s months-long sit-in. http://mitne.ws/13rD2mv MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. That's the purpose of the MIT Climate CoLab: http://mitsha.re/Vhaax #COP21.
messages: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said in an address at MIT that the effort to limit climate change was a dire “race against time,” but one that could be successful due to the economic promise of renewable energy. John Kerry: Climate drive an urgent “race against time”. At MIT, U.S. Secretary of State highlights peril of climate change, economic promise of clean energy.

Podcast: MIT Professor Kerry Emanuel speaks with Warm Regards about Hurricane Matthew, climate, and vulnerability. The Climate Context of Hurricane Matthew. This week, we have a special interview with Kerry Emanuel, a meteorologist and climate scientist who specializes in hurricane physics. We’re talking to him today about Hurricane Matthew, which is thre.

Prof. Kerry Emanuel and 16 others from MIT joined scientists around the U.S. in an open letter drawing attention to the serious consequences of withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement. 3Q: Kerry Emanuel on a “Parexit” and the serious risks of climate change. In open letter, 375 National Academy of Sciences members warn against opting out of Paris Agreement.

Carbon pricing policy, including its optimal design and implementation, is a significant area of focus for many MIT faculty members and researchers. MIT joins Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition. Led by World Bank and IMF, coalition seeks to price emissions to tackle climate change.

U.S. Secretary of Energy and former MIT professor Ernest Moniz spoke at the student-run MIT Energy Conference 2016, noting the prospects for jobs in energy-related fields are booming. Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz touts great opportunities in energy. New international agreement on “Mission Innovation” could lead to major progress on climate change.

The student-led group Fossil Free MIT and the MIT administration have reached an agreement on MIT climate action that brings to an end the group’s months-long sit-in. Agreement on climate-related action reached by MIT administration and student-led group. Four-part plan signals effort to build on last year’s climate action plan, and an end to months-long protest.

Ideas wanted! The MIT Climate CoLab has opened 10 contests seeking climate change solutions. What's your idea? MIT lab opens 10 contests on climate change. Proposals submitted will help crowdsource the makings of national and global climate action plans.
At this week's MIT on Climate: Science + Action symposium, calls for science-based climate action: http://mitsha.re/XGXYv. Timeline Photos.

History in the making! In light of this weekend's international agreement to curb fossil fuel emissions, the MIT Energy Initiative highlights MIT research and strategies shared at the #COP21 climate talks. Sharing climate research and strategies in Paris. MIT events throughout climate talks underscore Institute’s global perspectives and partnerships.

MIT Energy Initiative report from #COP21: How MIT and Climate Interactive are bringing empathy to the UN climate talks with a negotiation role-play. Climate negotiation role-play in Paris feels like the real thing. "World Climate" simulation, developed by MIT and Climate Interactive, challenges perceptions about climate negotiations and countries’ development needs.
Can collective intelligence save the planet from climate change? That's the purpose of the MIT Climate CoLab: http://mitsha.re/Vhaax #COP21. Timeline Photos.

"It’s time to stop talking and start doing. MIT is at its best when people roll up their sleeves and get to work." –Maria Zuber. 3 Questions: Maria Zuber on MIT’s climate action plan. MIT’s vice president for research looks ahead to implementation.

"Humanity must reorder the global energy status quo." Introducing MIT's new five-year #climatechange plan: http://mitsha.re/TG4Hp. MIT announces five-year plan for action on climate change. Hundreds of millions sought for low-carbon research; advocacy for carbon pricing; a call to the alumni and beyond.

Prof. Paul O'Gorman examines how climate change is impacting extreme weather events, such as Boston's record-breaking snowfall last winter: http://mitsha.re/Rlj1V

Photo: Bryce Vickmark. Paul O’Gorman: Extreme storm modeler. Atmospheric scientist tracks climate change’s effects on extreme storms.

"Solving big problems is in MIT’s DNA. And there is no greater problem confronting humanity today than climate change." http://mitsha.re/1Go9lXc 

View the full Report of the MIT Climate Change Conversation Committee: http://mitsha.re/1Go9cDj. Timeline Photos.

How can we make "Planet MIT" sustainable? This Earth Day, join the MIT Climate Change Conversation: http://mitsha.re/1Gjqvrt 

Photo: Rawhead Rex/Flickr CC BY-NC-SA. Timeline Photos.

Should MIT divest from fossil fuels? Last week, as part of the MIT Climate Change Conversation, the Institute held a unique campus debate to consider the pros and cons. MIT hosts debate on pros and cons of fossil-fuel divestment. Participants discuss a proposed elimination of oil, gas, and coal companies from endowment portfolio.
How can we prepare for a changing climate? Submit your suggestion to the Climate CoLab, which is crowdsourcing high-impact ideas on how to tackle climate change.

"Some days, just recycling your soda cans just doesn't seem like enough. So what can you do? Enter Climate CoLab. 

This is a crowdsourcing platform where people like you and I can work with experts to create, discuss, and select proposals for what to do about climate change." Why MIT Thinks You (Yes, You!) Can Solve Climate Change. Climate change: We all know it's a huge problem, and most of us want something done about it. Unfortunately, nation-state level approaches haven't made any significant headway. According to Thomas W. Malone, Robert Laubacher, and Laur Fisher of the MIT Center for Collective Intelligence, "top-down approaches that have been tried for decades—like efforts to pass national legislation and to negotiate international agreements—while important, haven’t yet produced the kind of change scientists say is needed to avert climate change’s potential consequences."

How can we *really* save the planet? At MIT's Climate CoLab, competitors battle for the ultimate prize: a sustainable future. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/1rjMjqp

Enter the lab's climate solutions contests: http://mitsha.re/1f0epqO

#MIT #EarthDay. Timeline Photos.

Kerry Emanuel of the MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change contributes to AAAS - The American Association for the Advancement of Science What We Know report on climate change. Read the report here: whatweknow.aaas.org. Want to learn more? Emanuel is also teaching a new edX course that is currently underway on global warming science: http://mitne.ws/1kFIbju. MITx: 12.340x: Global Warming Science | edX. Some college-level mathematics (calculus, including ordinary differential equations) and physics (electromagnetism, mechanics) as well as high-school chemistry are required. Beyond these...
#MIT #economist Benjamin Olken has co-authored a new survey on the burgeoning research about the effects of the changing #climate. More: http://mitne.ws/IoN6aD. Timeline Photos.

As the focus on cleaner energy sources increases, MIT researchers are examining what unintended consequences these might have on the changing climate.  http://mitne.ws/13rD2mv MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. Timeline Photos.

“The environmental change avoided by reducing greenhouse-gas emissions is substantial and actually means less land used for crops” - John Reilly, co-director of MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. Seeing Green: Saving Forests or Food Prices? A growing population and rapid development will put a strain on land used to grow food over the next century. But if reforestation is used to avoid climate change it will create further strain, says a new MIT study.

An MIT survey released today shows that 95 percent of major cities in Latin America are planning for climate change, compared to only 59 percent of such cities in the United States. Survey: Latin American and Asian cities lead way in planning for global warming - MIT News Office. U.S. cities trail when it comes to preparing for climate change.

clusters.summary:
MIT School of Architecture and Planning. MIT School of Architecture + Planning. A look at how urban studies at MIT are changing cities around the world: http://mitsha.re/SEwIHJ 

More on the new Center for Advanced Urbanism in the MIT School of Architecture + Planning: http://mitsha.re/1lbEl3t   . More images on the MIT Student Architecture Blog: http://mitsha.re/ZF9Paj

Photo: Evelyn Ting, MIT School of Architecture and Planning. Philip Ewing is the first recipient of the Robert R. Taylor fellowship in the MIT School of Architecture + Planning.
messages: The MIT School of Architecture + Planning has launched a new entrepreneurship accelerator, DesignX, to cultivate and assist students and faculty developing products, systems, and companies that focus on design and the built environment. Entrepreneurship by design. New DesignX accelerator speeds innovation at the School of Architecture and Planning.

“We contribute to the making of society rather than simply representing it.” –Hashim Sarkis, dean of the MIT School of Architecture and Planning. Democracy and design. Architect and dean Hashim Sarkis believes good design builds a better society.

Interplanetary architecture: Students and faculty in the MIT School of Architecture + Planning are designing habitats for #Mars. Interplanetary architecture. Faculty and students grapple with 3-D printing a habitable structure on Mars.

Hashim Sarkis, the new dean of the MIT School of Architecture and Planning, wants to change what we talk about when we talk about cities. The Power of Ideas: Hashim Sarkis. Hashim Sarkis, the new dean of MIT’s School of Architecture and Planning, wants to find new ways to talk about urban space.

Hey! What's your thesis? Students in the MIT School of Architecture and Planning show off their work on the Arch Kiosk blog: http://mitsha.re/1y5UABo

Image courtesy of David Moses. Timeline Photos.

"Unblocked," a project by architecture students Evelyn Ting and Shiyu Wei, is "a prototype for a new kind of pop-up exhibition space. Made from mylar, it is a lightweight system that can be pre-cut to specific geometries and stitched together offsite, and expanded and assembled onsite." More images on the MIT Student Architecture Blog: http://mitsha.re/ZF9Paj

Photo: Evelyn Ting, MIT School of Architecture and Planning. Timeline Photos.

Sheila Kennedy, professor of the practice of architecture in the MIT School of Architecture and Planning, has twice been recognized in recent months for her outstanding innovative works. This month, she was honored with the $100K Berkeley-Rupp Prize. Full story: http://mitne.ws/1qYKi6P. Timeline Photos.

Watch "Swing Time," a new project from the Dept. of Architecture's J. Meejin Yoon, in motion: https://vimeo.com/105524405 . MIT School of Architecture + Planning. A doubleheader for the architects tonight: Department Convocation @ 6:30, 'Swing Time' debut @ 7. All welcome, all at the Lawn on D in South Boston. Details: http://www.lawnond.com/d-street-arts/swing-time-opening-reception/

Assistant Prof. Azra Akšamija PhD ’11 explores how art and architecture can help us make sense of cultural conflicts. Read about her work in The Tech: http://mitsha.re/1ppqkwp

Full line of helmets at Akšamija's "Spring Collection, 2014": http://mitsha.re/1ppqzrs

Photos courtesy of Azra Akšamija. MIT School of Architecture and Planning. Timeline Photos.

The MIT School of Architecture and Planning is well represented at this year’s Venice Architecture Biennale, open now through November 23. The U.S. Pavilion, pictured here, was co-curated by architecture professor Ana Miljacki. See how other MIT affiliates and alumni contributed: http://mitsha.re/1rLtJMT

Photo courtesy of the School of Architecture + Planning. Timeline Photos.

Rethinking architecture: The MIT Industrial Liaison Program shines a spotlight on Mark Goulthorpe and his ideas about the next generation of high-performance buildings. http://mitne.ws/1nfM0Pf 

Photo: Mark Goulthorpe, MIT School of Architecture and Planning. Timeline Photos.

A look at how urban studies at MIT are changing cities around the world: http://mitsha.re/SEwIHJ 

More on the new Center for Advanced Urbanism in the MIT School of Architecture + Planning: http://mitsha.re/1lbEl3t   . Center for Advanced Urbanism. The Center for Advanced Urbanism is committed to fostering a rigorous design culture for the large scale; by focusing our disciplinary conversations about architecture, urban planning, and systems thinking, not about the problems of yesterday, but of tomorrow.

Happy birthday, I.M. Pei '40! The world-renowned architect and graduate of the MIT School of Architecture + Planning has made an enormous mark on campus, with designs for the Green Building, Weisner Building, Landau Building, and Dreyfus Building. He turns 97 today.

(Photos: Maia Weinstock & Wikimedia Commons) #architecture #MIT. Timeline Photos.

Philip Ewing is the first recipient of the Robert R. Taylor fellowship in the MIT School of Architecture + Planning. How did a high school project lead him to discover his interest in #architecture? Watch: http://mitsha.re/1qeSCNu. An Interview with Philip Ewing: The First Recipient of the Robert R. Taylor Fellowship. An interview with MIT graduate student Philip Ewing who talks about how he decided to become an architect, his interest in the field of Computation and what ...

MIT Senseable City Lab MIT School of Architecture + Planning study shows a regular decline in length of #socialmedia messaging during public events as the volume of messages increases. More: http://mitne.ws/1kjap2N

(Illustration: Christine Daniloff and José-Luis Olivares/MIT) Timeline Photos.

Adèle Naudé Santos, dean of the MIT School of Architecture + Planning, to step down. With focus and sustained effort, she added strength and vitality to a School whose creativity and scholarship have become increasingly integral to #MIT. More: http://mitne.ws/L62RDH 

(Photo: Judith M. Daniels) Timeline Photos.
New book, edited by MIT School of Architecture + Planning  historian, examines the evolution of #modernism during its postwar heyday at #MIT. More: http://mitne.ws/1a3jvxz. Timeline Photos.

New MIT Senseable City Lab MIT School of Architecture + Planning study uses network data to show #communication patterns and divisions in many major nations. More: http://mitne.ws/1kY6YNH

(Image: MIT Senseable City Lab) Timeline Photos.

clusters.summary:
MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences. Congrats to Melissa Nobles, the new dean of the MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences! Get to know the "Musical Institute of Technology" with a new book from the MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences: http://mitsha.re/TIU6d 

Photos: Jon Sachs/MIT SHASS. The Open Documentary Lab (OpenDocLab), located in MIT's School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences, explores the chall... In talk, MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences professor examines the implications of the military drawdown for regional rivals India and Pakistan. Study from MIT Economics & MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences: U.S.
messages: Campaign rhetoric. Sexism. Racism. Polling data. Here's what 12 scholars in the MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences think about #Election2016: Analyzing the 2016 election: Insights from 12 MIT scholars. Experts from the School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences weigh in on topics from polling to rhetoric to individual campaign issues.

On World Day of Social Justice, insights from Melissa Nobles, dean of the MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences, on advancing racial and ethnic justice: http://mitsha.re/YykTX. Timeline Photos.

Happy World Anthropology Day! Meet the people at MIT who bring anthro to life: http://mitsha.re/YtGKl  

Image: MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences. Timeline Photos.
Celebrate #NationalCatDay with Nyan Cat, who graces the halls of the MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences. ~=[,,_,,]:3 Timeline Photos.

Eran Egozy ’95, an MIT electrical engineering and computer science major and a concert-level clarinetist, met music major Alex Rigopulos ’92, ’94 when both were grad students at MIT’s Media Lab. They went on to establish Harmonix Music Systems, which in 2005 released the video game Guitar Hero.  MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences. “You actually feel like a rock god." 
— Eran Egozy '95

messages: Do you prefer good news or bad? A new study from the MIT Sloan School of Management finds people react more strongly to good medical news than to bad. Genomes, good news, and you. Personal genomic data makes a bigger impact when it portends well, a new study finds.

Friday inspiration: Joe Bellantoni, blind after a car accident, is about to graduate from the MIT Sloan School of Management. From a near-death experience to an Executive MBA. After losing his sight in an auto accident, Joe Bellantoni is giving back to his community while enhancing his career, with the help of his wife and MIT Sloan.

"Unconscious bias doesn't just affect women. It affects all constituencies." MIT Sloan Women in Management event wraps up a year focusing on bias issue - MIT Sloan School of... The Breaking the Mold event highlighted how academics are thinking about unconscious bias.

On #WorldFoodDay, learn how two students at the MIT Sloan School of Management created an app providing surplus food to those in need. New business app designed to reduce food waste. MIT Sloan MBA students found Spoiler Alert app to match surplus food inventory with those in need.

A new study from the MIT Sloan School of Management shows how airlines could juggle delays more equitably by distributing disruptions among themselves: mitsha.re/RoT08. Making the air fair. New study shows flight delays can be distributed more equitably among airlines.

"Though there’s been more talk about paternity leave in recent years, most of the debate around work-family issues still centers on women. There’s a long way to go to make this a conversation about everyone." –Lotte Bailyn, professor in the MIT Sloan School of Management. Lotte Bailyn: The Thought Leader Interview. For more than 50 years, the MIT professor has challenged companies and policymakers to redefine the rules of work and family.

A new study from the MIT Sloan School of Management finds that for teens convicted of similar offenses, those who face detention suffer more significant life consequences. Study: Juvenile incarceration yields less schooling, more crime. Teen offenders who serve time finish school less often, become repeat offenders more often.
How do we choose what to buy? New work from the MIT Sloan School of Management describes how our brains rank consumer products.
In honor of #WomensHistoryMonth, hats off to some of the women of MIT Sloan Executive Education! http://mitsha.re/1N8RIyi. Timeline Photos.

More than 3,100 attended the 9th annual MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference, the biggest meeting yet of sports-data experts. Here are six key insights from the event. Six keys to sports analytics. Massive MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference reveals state of growing field.

Thomas Malone of the MIT Sloan School of Management co-authors a piece in today's NYTimes exploring the new science of effective teamwork. Why Some Teams Are Smarter Than Others. It’s about listening, empathy and having more women.

Happy birthday to computing legend Grace Hopper, b. Dec. 9, 1906! Hopper spoke at MIT in 1961 as part of an MIT Sloan School of Management event called "Management and the Computer of the Future." Read her full remarks: http://mitsha.re/12Zjgnp. Timeline Photos.

The sixth annual MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference, held this past weekend, hit on a number of topics in professional sports — and yes, that includes Linsanity. Hail to the geeks - MIT News Office. At this year’s MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference: cutting-edge basketball research and, yes, plenty of discussion about Jeremy Lin.

Take a peek at some of the research underway as part of the annual Sloan Sports Analytics Conference, which kicked off this morning. Game on - MIT News Office. As MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference kicks off, scholars and fans have produced a growing avalanche of quantitative research.

“There is reason to believe that men are making financial decisions in a way that reflects the influence of the ratios of men and women,” says Joshua Ackerman, an assistant professor of marketing at the MIT Sloan School of Management and one of the researchers who performed the study. “Seeing more men around them in these environments activates a competitive mindset, which leads to a short-term, spend-now approach.” Gender spenders - MIT News Office. Study suggests yet another cause of personal debt: searching for the ideal mate.
